This Date In History: 1986 August 8: Rob Reiner's film based off of Stephen King's novella Stand By Me hits theatres, srnghevat Jvy Jurngba, and Corey Feldman. September 18: The newly sworn-in President of the Republic of the Philippines, Corazon Cojuangco-Aquino, delivers a bipartisan address to the US House of Representatives. (part 1, part 2, part 3) October 9: Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical adaptation of The Phantom of the Opera debuts on the West End in London, UK, featuring Sarah Brightman, Steve Barton, and the Phantom himself, Michael Crawford. This Date In History: December 1988 - January 1989 December 10: American actor Richard S. Castellano, best known as Pete Clemenza from The Godfather, along with Lovers and Other Strangers, passes away. December 24: Capcom releases Mega Man 2 (Rockman 2) in Japan on the NES, selling nearly 1.5 million copies. December 31: American Flash animator and voice actor, Christopher "Kirbopher" Niosi, creator of TOME (Terrain of Magical Expertise), is born. January 8: The Andrew Lloyd Webber musical Starlight Express closes its Broadway show after 761 performances which began on March 15, 1987. January 9: The Pat Sajak Show premieres on CBS. This Date In History: April 1989 April 26: GAME F***K Inc., is founded in Tokyo, Japan by Ken Sugimori and Satoshi Tajiri. April 28: Tom Petty's album High Moon Fever premieres, featuring "Free Fallin'", "I Won't Back Down", and "Running Down A Dream". This Date In History: July 1989 July 29: Kiki's Delivery Service, the first Studio Ghibli film distributed under the partnership of Disney and Studio Ghibli, is released in Japan. This Date In History: September 1989 September 28: Philippine President Dictator Ferdinand Marcos passes away in his estate in Honolulu, Hawaii. This Date In History: October 1989 October 28: Tom Petty's single "Free Fallin'" is released. This Date In History: November 1989 - January 1990 November 4: The Phantom of the Opera (dir. Dwight H. Little) premieres in theatres, featuring Robert Englund as Erik/The Phantom, Jill Schoelen as Christine, and Bill Nighy, with music from Misha Segal. November 22: Back to the Future Part II (dir. Robert Zemeckis, scr. Bob Gale), featuring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly, and Christopher Lloyd as Doc Brown, Lea Thompson, Elisabeth Shue, Thomas F. Wilson, and Flea, with a cameo from Elijah Wood, is released in theatres. December 12: Vietnamese American voice actress Kimlinh Tran (website here) is born. She's well known for voicing loads of characters, from furries to tomboys, and she voices this cute flying orange creature in one of my favorite video games, Dust: An Elysian Tail. (TW: ableist slurs and mild spoilers of the game in the video) Link here. December 13: American singer Taylor Swift is born in Reading, PA, USA. December 15: The Wizard (dir. ), a Super Mario 3 ad movie featuring Fred Savage, Beau Bridges, Christian Slater, and Jenny Lewis of Kilo Riley, is released in theatres. Anyone remember the Power Glove? It's so baaaaaad... December 17: The Simpsons' first full length episode is broadcast on Fox in the U.S. (article only) December 22: American singer Jordin Sparks is born. December 30: American skateboarder Ryan Sheckler is born. This Date In History: April 1990 April 9: American TV personality, journalist, and singer Ruba Wilson is born. This Month In History: February 1991 February 28: Irish actress Sarah Bolger (In America, Stormbreaker, The Spiderwick Chronicles, From Up On Poppy Hill, The Tudors, Once Upon A Time, Into the Badlands) is born. This Date In History: November 1991 - January 1992 November 21: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past (The Legend of Zelda: The Triforce of the Gods) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. (more rap dancing!) December 3: Philips, along with Magnavox and Sony, launch the CD-i. December 4: Super Castlevania IV, which debuted in Japan on October 31, is released on the Super NES in North America. December 12: The Sega CD, or the Sega-Mega CD, is released in Japan. December 28: Pretty Soldier Sailor Moon starts its serialization on the Shojo magazine Nakayoshi. Also, since ScarlettMi mentioned Hook yesterday, here's another appreciation post for...Rufio! (assume any and all TWs) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Um8mMa5w41A http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JsJxIoFu2wo January 4: (TW: flashing lights) The arcade-themed game show Nick Arcade premieres on Nickelodeon. This Date In History: February 1992 - May 1992 February 11: Jacob Black Sharkboy Taylor Lautner is born. March 4: Disney animator Art Babbitt passes away. March 7: Sailor Moon starts its anime run in Japan on TV Asahi. March 14: Fire Emblem Gaiden (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. March 20: Shining Force: The Legacy of Great Intention is released on the Sega Genesis in Japan. March ??: Ultima Underworld: The Stygian Abyss the first first-person 3D video game, is released on PCs. April 3: (TW: bright, flashing lights) The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past (article here), is released in North America on the Super NES. April 16: (TW: gore, shootings) Hard Boiled, a John Woo film featuring Chow Yun-fat, Tony Leung Chu-wai, Teresa Mo, and its long take in a hospital, premieres in Hong Kong. April 27: Kirby's Dream Land, the first game featuring Kirby, is released on the Game Boy in Japan. April 29 - May 4: The Los Angeles Riots are incited in Koreatown after the anger of the beating of Rodney King by two police officers. May 5: (TW: gore, Nazi imagery, Nazism) Wolfenstein 3D, one of the first commercial first-person 3D video games by id software debuts on PCs. May 5: Lionel Richie's album Back To Front premieres, featuring singles "Do It To Me", and "My Destiny". May 7: John Frusciante leaves the Red Hot Chili Peppers, only to return in 1998. May 9: The 37th EuroVision Song Contest takes place in Malmo, Sweden, with Linda Martin for Ireland as the champion, for her song "Why Me". May 10: The Hamlet production at the Criterion Theater NYC closes after 45 performances. May 10: Filipina singer Charice Pempengco is born. Here's her performance of Jennifer Hudson's "And I'm Telling You I'm Not Going" on Star King in 2007. May 11: The 1992 Philippine Presidential elections begin, as one of the first general elections under the recent 1987 Philippine Constitution, with leading candidate Fidel V. Ramos beating out the tough-talking Senator Miriam Defensor-Santiago. May 13: Frank Stallone (brother of Sylvester Stallone) beats Geraldo Rivera at boxing. May 17 - 20: "Black May" in Thailand occurs between the people and the current government of another tyrant General Suchinda Kraprayoon. May 18: (TW: domestic abuse) Bille August's The Best Intentions, featuring Shmi Skywalker (Anakin Skywalker's mother) and a screenplay by Ingmar Bergman, wins the Palme D'Or at the 45th Cannes Film Festival. May 21: Actress Olivia Olson (Love Actually, Marceline in Adventure Time, Vanessa in Phineas and Ferb) is born. And I'm so excited to get to this point in history, because this is an...Olivia Olson Appreciation Post! Since Mark's a Beyonce fan, here's her cover of Halo: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8Q02hVfjnc May 25: Elton John's single "The One" premieres. May 28: Amanda Goad wins the National Spelling Bee with the winning word "lyceum." This Date In History: June 1992 - September 1992 June 1: Super Star Wars is released on the SNES in North America, later released in Japan on December 18, and in Europe on April 2, 1993. June 2: Wilson Phillips release their second album Shadows and Light, featuring "Give It Up", which was released as a single on July 28. June 3 - 14: The 1992 NBA Finals with the Chicago Bulls (MJ!) against the Portland Trail Blazers takes place. (skip to 1:40 for the intro) http://youtu.be/YLvTGBy-ESg?t=1m40s June 5: (TW: gore, terrorism mention) Patriot Games, based on Tom Clancy's Jack Ryan novel series, premieres in theatres. June 10: Street Fighter II: The World Warrior, (the first video game I've ever played! Article here) is released on the Super Famicom, debuting on the SNES in North America on July 15, and in Europe on December 17. June 16: Lunar: The Silver Star is released on the Sega CD in Japan. Other games released in June were: Bomber Man World, which was released in arcades in Japan. (article only) Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis (article here), which was released on PCs in North America. (TW: ableist slurs) June 19: Batman Returns to theatres, with Tim Burton as director, Michael Keaton as the eponymous Batman, Michelle Pfeiffer as Catwoman, and Danny DeVito as the Penguin. June 22: The Supreme Court rules that hate speech violates the First Amendment. June 24: Billy Joel gets his honorary high school diploma. June 25: Les Miserables has its opening night in the Vinorhady Theatre, Prague. June 26: The Supreme Court rules that fund soliciting can be banned at airports. June 27: LAPD Police Chief Daryl Gates "retires" as chief and a day later, steps down as commissioner of the LAPD. June 30: Fidel V. Ramos is sworn in as President of the Republic of the Philippines. June 30: Uruguay has a solar eclipse that lasts for 5 minutes. June 30: The Iron Lady Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher (boo!) joins the House of Lords as Baroness Thatcher of Kesteven. July 4: Steffi Graf wins the Women's Singles, while Andre Agassi wins the Men's Singles of the 1992 Wimbledon Championships. July 8: Melrose Place, a spin-off of Beverly Hills 90210, premieres on Fox in North America. July 13: Yitzhak Rabin becomes Prime Minister of Israel. July 14: Mario Paint debuts on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released on the SNES in North America on August 1, and in Europe on December 10. July 16: Ross Perot ends his campaign for President. July 17: The Slovak National Council declares independence from Czechoslovakia. July 17: (TW: flashing lights) Recca: Summer Carnival '92 (article here), a very fast-paced space shooter, debuts on the Famicom in Japan. The game is later released on the 3DS Virtual Console on December 12, 2012 in Japan, in Europe and Australia on August 15, 2013, and in North America on September 5, 2013. July 18: Another small movie from Studio Ghibli, Porco Rosso premieres in Japan, grossing over $34 million in box office receipts. July 20: Vaclav Havel resigns as President of Czechoslovakia. July 31: A little movie called Buffy the Vampire Slayer, featuring a screenplay by a certain guy named Joss Whedon, along with Kristy Swanson as Buffy, premieres. July 31: Ecco the Dolphin makes a splash on the Sega CD in Europe. August 1: Kirby's Dream Land is released on the Game Boy in North America, and is later released in PAL regions on August 3. August 3: Unforgiven, Clint Eastwood's swan song to the Western, is released in theatres. August 12: Canada, Mexico, and the United States announce a deal on the North American Free Trade Agreement. August 13: International Left Handers Day is first observed in the UK. August 13 - 16: The 25th San Diego Comic-Con International is held in the San Diego Convention Center and DoubleTree Hotel, with a record of 25,000 in atttendance. August 15: Nickelodeon premieres a Saturday night programming block SNICK. August 17: Mara Clara, a Philippine telenovella 1,209 episodes long, begins its broadcast on ABS-CBN. August 20: Strictly Ballroom, Baz Luhrmann's first film, premieres in Australia. August 24: Diplomatic relations are established between the People's Republic of China and South Korea. August 27: Super Mario Kart (article here) is released on the Super Famicom, and is released in North America on the Super NES on September 1, and later released in Europe on January 21, 1993. August 27: The Heights broadcasts on Fox. August 27: (TW: gore, nudity) New Dragon Gate Inn (New Dragon Inn) (article here, a remake of the 1967 wuxia (martial arts) film by King Hu, Dragon Gate Inn (Dragon Inn) (article here), premieres in Hong Kong, featuring Tony Leung, Maggie Cheung, Brigitte Lin, and Donnie Yen. August 31: A dynamite explosion occurs in a Philippine mine, resulting in 500 fatalities. This Date In History: September 1992 September 1: Zhang Yimou's (director of Raise the Red Lantern) film The Story of Qiu Ju (Qiu Ju Goes To Court), based on Chen Yuanbin's novella The Wan Family's lawsuit, premieres in the 49th Venice Film Festival. September 5: Batman: The Animated Series first swoops on to Fox Kids. September 5: The Heights' single based on the show The Heights on Fox, "How Do You Talk to an Angel" is released. September 12: NBC is the first network to cancel all of their children's Saturday morning cartoon programming. Nooooo! :( September 12: A young director named Manoj Nelliyattu Shyamalan makes his debut with his first film, Praying With Anger, which premiered at the 17th Toronto International Film Festival. September 17: The US House of Representatives votes (280-128) to give the FCC control of cable TV rates. September 19: Nickelodeon Guts, famous for its Awesome Aggro Crag (whoa steady there, Mike!), featuring Mike O'Malley and Moira Quirk as hosts, premieres on Nickelodeon. http://youtube.com/watch?v=3TOPl_FyLaM September 19: The 17th Toronto Film Festival People's Choice Award is won by Strictly Ballroom, while the FIPRESCI International Critics Award is won by a little film called Reservoir Dogs. September 24: The Sci-Fi Channel launches by broadcasting Star Wars. September 24: Art of Fighting, which follows the Fatal Fury 'verse, premieres in arcades in Japan. September 27: Marlon Wayans and Alexandra Wentworth join the cast of In Living Color. September 27: Dragon Quest V premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. This Date In History: October 1992 October 1: Cartoon Network launches. October 1: Ross Perot re-enters the US presidential election. October 2: The Mighty Ducks premieres in theatres, along with a wide release for Glengarry Glen Ross, after its premiere in the Venice Film Festival, and Of Mice and Men. October 5: A cable bill veto was overturned by Congress. October 6: (TW: ableist slurs, child exploitation, child abuse, abduction, smoking in video) Soul Asylum's album Grave Dancers Union debuts, featuring "Runaway Train", released as a single on June 1, 1993. October 6: British actor Denholm Elliott (Dr. Brody in Indiana Jones) passes away. October 7: (TW: gore, dismemberment) Mortal Kombat is released in North America on arcades. October 9: Expos√© release their self-titled album, featuring "I'll Never Get Over You (Getting Over Me)", later released as a single on February 1993. October 9: (TW: terrorism mention) Another Steven Seagal movie, Under Siege premieres. October 9: (TW: imperialism) Ridley Scott's 1492: Conquest of Paradise premieres in theatres. October 9: (TW: gore) Army of Darkness, featuring Bruce Campbell, premieres worldwide, except in the US. October 10: Yu Yu Hakusho, based off of the manga by Yoshihiro Togashi, premieres in Japan on TV Tokyo. (fun fact: the creator of Sailor Moon and Yu Yu Hakusho are married, I think) October 10: My Patrasche, an animated show based on the 1872 novel by Marie de la Remee, A Dog of Flanders, premieres on NTV in Japan. October 13: 4 Non Blondes release their debut album, Bigger, Better, Faster, More! featuring their single "What's Up", later released as a single in 1993. October 13: American voice actor Aaron Dismuke (Lbhat Uburaurvz from Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood, Nycubafr from 2003!Fullmetal Alchemist, Van Fanel in the Funimation dub of Vision of Escaflowne) is born. October 15: Another controversial game, Night Trap, for the Sega CD, is released. October 15: American actor Vincent Martella (Phineas in Phineas and Ferb, Everybody Hates Chris, Hope in Final Fantasy XIII) is born. October 20: Beverly Hills 90210's soundtrack album is released. October 21: (TW: flashing lights) Super Mario Land 2: Six Golden Coins is released on the Game Boy in Japan, featuring Wario. October 22: Actress Sofia Vassilieva (My Sister's Keeper) is born. October 23: (TW: blood, smoking) Quentin Tarantino's second film, Reservoir Dogs, widely premieres in theatres. October 23: Emperor Akihito becomes the first Emperor of Japan to stand on Chinese soil. October 27: The UK releases a stamp celebrating Tolkien's 100th anniversary. October 30: Landstalker: The Treasures of King Nole (article here) debuts on the Sega Genesis in Japan, later released in North America and Europe in 1993. The game was later added to the Wii Virtual Console in North America on September 3, 2007, and in Europe on October 5, 2007. October 30: The first game in the point-and-click Putt-Putt series, Putt-Putt Joins the Parade (article here) is released on PCs. October 31: The Catholic Church reinstates Galileo after 359 years of excommunication. This Date In History: November 1992 November 2: Super Mario Land 2: Six Golden Coins is released on the Game Boy in North America, and later in Europe on January 28, 1993. November 3: Whitney Houston's cover single of "I Will Always Love You" debuts. November 5: Bobby Fischer beats Boris Spassky to win the chess title in Belgrade, Serbia. November 8: (TW: racism) 300,000 protestors in Berlin demonstrate against racism. November 11: The Church of England approves ordaining female priests. November 13: Francis Ford Coppola's film, Bram Stoker's Dracula, premieres in theatres. November 13: Evander Holyfield vs. Riddick Bowe (Holyfield: 28 W, Bowe: 31 W, link goes to "tale of the tape") takes place in the Thomas & Mack Center, Las Vegas, Nevada, USA. Bowe wins by unanimous decision (all three judges favored Bowe). November 17: The soundtrack of the upcoming movie The Bodyguard is released. November 17: NBC Dateline airs a demo of GM trucks, blowing up on impact, which was later revealed to be rigged by the network. November 18: (TW: smoking, drinking mention, racism) Malcolm X premieres in theatres. November 20: A fire breaks out in Windsor Palace, causing 50 million pounds worth of damage. November 21: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 debuts on the Sega Genesis, later released in Australia on December 1. The game was later ported to the Wii Virtual Console on June 11, 2007 in North America, June 19, 2007 in Japan, and July 6, 2007 in Europe. November 23: Fresh off of his gold medal win from the 1992 Olympics, the "Golden Boy" Oscar De La Hoya (39 W-6 L, the link shows his record) begins his debut as a professional boxer in Inglewood, California, USA. November 24: "Sonic 2sday (Tuesday)" happens, celebrating the release of Sonic the Hedgehog 2 in North America and Europe, the first worldwide release in video game history. the link explains why popular videogames are usually released on Tuesdays. November 25: Another little movie from Disney called Aladdin has its world premiere. Robin Hood 2.0, or The Bodyguard also premieres, featuring awesome music by Whitney Houston, and a screenplay by Lawrence Kasdan of Indiana Jones and Star Wars fame. This Date In History: December 1992 December 1: The Young and the Restless broadcasts its 5000th episode. December 4: Mega Man 5 (Rockman 5) is released on the Famicom in Japan, later to the NES in North America on December 31, and in Europe on March 10, 1993. December 4: US lands in Somalia. December 5: Captain Planet and the Planeteers ends its original run. December 6: Tiny Toon Adventures finishes its third broadcast season. December 6: (Spoilers in the intro video) Final Fantasy V (the first Final Fantasy game I've played, yessssss!) is released in Japan on the Super Famicom. (commercial here) Now we're at this point in time, this is a...Final Fantasy V Appreciation Post! (spoilers) Here's a taste of the gameplay. Here's one of the themes from the game. Here's Yoshitaka Amano's concept art of the jvaq qenxr in the logo. December 9: Prince Charles of Wales and Princess Diana of Wales publicly announce their separation. December 11: Mega Man III is released on the Game Boy in both Japan and in North America, while Europe gets its release around 1993. December 11: A Few Good Men, from a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin, is released in theatres. December 12: Darkwing Duck premieres its final episode. December 13: (TW: gore, dismemberment) Two University of Colorado students debut a short film called The Spirit of Christmas. December 14: Riddick Bowe is stripped of his WBC Heavyweight Title after refusing to fight Lennox Lewis. December 18: Toys premieres in theatres, introducing Jamie Foxx. December 20: South African President F.W. de Klerk dismisses or suspends 23 military officers, plus 6 generals, on their unfounded suspicion of their disruption of negotiations with the African National Congress. December 21: Stella Adler, American acting teacher, passes away. December 23: Scent of a Woman, a remake of a 1974 Italian film, Darkness and Honey, premieres in theatres. (article only) December 24: Swedish dance pop band Ace of Base release their debut album Happy Nation in Scandinavia, featuring "Wheel of Fortune", previously released as a single in April 1992 and "All That She Wants" (TW: smoking, alcohol), previously released in November 1, 1992. December 24: Peyo, creator of the Smurfs, passes away. December 27: Les Miserables opens in Copenhagen, Denmark. December 29: Ecco the Dolphin makes a splash in North America, later in Japan on July 30, 1993. I made an error in the history post referring to Ecco that this game was released on the Sega CD in Europe, but it actually debuted on the Sega Genesis in Europe. Ecco would be released on the Sega CD in 1993, sorry about that! Other events in 1992 include: Duke Nukem, released in North America on July 1, 1991, is released in Europe. Australian singer Rick Price releases his single "Heaven Knows", peaking third on the Australian charts on July 1992 and lasting 23 weeks on the Top 40 ARIA chart. Ang Lee makes his directorial debut with the film Pushing Hands, later released in North America on June 2, 1995. (1995 trailer here). Cybersix, an Argentine-penned comic book series, begins its serialization in the Italian comic magazine Skorpio. Zenki (Demon Child Zenki) begins its serialization in Monthly Shonen Jump in Japan. This Date In History: January 1993 ??: MicroProse releases a point-and-click game Return of the Phantom on PCs. January 6: Dancer Rudolf Nureyev, and trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie pass away. January 6: The Journeyman Project, featuring the actor who played Klim Dokachin from TNG, premieres on Macs and PCs. January 7: The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated with Jerry Rawlings as its president. January 8: Michael Jordan scores his 20,000th point. January 8: NBC offers David Letterman the "Tonight Show" job. January 9: Latvian singer Aminata is born. Here's her performance from EuroVision. January 10: The first of Krzysztof Kieslowski and Krzysztof Piesiewicz's Three Colours trilogy, Three Colours: Blue, featuring Juliette Binoche, premieres in Warsaw, Poland. January 11: WWF's Monday Night Raw premieres on the USA Network in the US. January 14: David Letterman moves his show from NBC to CBS. January 15: Alive premieres in theatres. January 15: Santa Barbara ends its run on NBC. January 18: Martin Luther King Jr. Day observed in all 50 states in America. January 20: (TW: smoking pic in article) Audrey Hepburn (Holly Golightly in Breakfast at Tiffany's) passes away. January 24: The first African American Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall passes away. January 25: The Irresponsible Captain Tylor, based on the light novel The Most Irresponsible Man In Space by Hitoshi Yoshioka, premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. January 25: The Irresponsible Captain Tylor (article here), based on the light novel The Most Irresponsible Man In Space by Hitoshi Yoshioka, premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. January 25: Filipina actress Kylie Padilla is born. January 26: Canadian actor Cameron Bright (The Twilight Saga, X-Men: The Last Stand) is born. January 28: British actor Will Poulter (Son of Rambow, Voyage of the Dawn Treader, The Maze Runner) is born. January 31: The 9th Sundance Film Festival takes place. This Date In History: February 1993 February 1: Sting releases his single, "If I Ever Lose My Faith In You." February ??: Star Wars: X-Wing (article here) debuts on PCs and Macs. (skip to 6:04 to see the gameplay) February 3: From Walt Disney Pictures, Homeward Bound: The Incredible Journey, a remake of the 1963 film The Incredible Journey from the 1961 novel of the same name, premieres in theatres. February 3: The federal trial begins for the four police officers involved in the beating of Rodney King. February 5: Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Hollywood screenwriter, producer, and director (All About Eve) passes away. February 6: Riddick Bowe takes on Michael Dokes (Bowe: 32 W, Dokes: 50 W-3 L-2 D) for the lineal heavyweight championship in Madison Square Garden, New York City, New York, USA. February 11: Filipina actress Marlann Flores (my cousin!) is born. February 11: Shane Mosley, good friend and rival to Oscar De La Hoya, (48 W-9 L-1 D) starts off his professional boxing career in Hollywood, California, USA. February 12: (TW: gore, carnage, spoilers in the second video) A small film by Peter Jackson called Dead Alive, called Braindead in the US, premieres in US theatres, previously released in New Zealand on August 13, 1992. Here's one of my favorite scenes in that film. February 13: Double Dare ends its run on Nickelodeon. February 17: Filipino actor AJ Sarte Perez is born. February 19: American actress Victoria Justice (Victorious, The Suite Life of Zack and Cody) is born. February 19: Ace of Base's album Happy Nation premieres in Europe. February 19: Army of Darkness premieres in US theatres. February 20: Whitney Houston's "I Have Nothing" from The Bodyguard soundtrack album is released as a single. February 21: Star Fox is released on the Super Famicom, released on the SNES in North America on March 26, and in Europe on June 3. February 26: American actress Taylor Dooley (Lavagirl from The Adventures of Sharkboy & Lavagirl) is born. February 26: (TW: racism, racist stereotypes, gore) Falling Down premieres in theatres. February 27: Sailor Moon ends its first season. This Date In History: March 1993 March ??: Ken's Labyrinth (another childhood favorite!) is released on PCs. March 4: American singer Bobbi Kristina Brown is born. March 5: Albert Odyssey (article here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. March 5: Sting's album Ten Summoner's Tales debuts, featuring "It's Probably Me", "If I Ever Lose My Faith In You", and "Fields of Gold". March 6: (TW: flashing lights, spoilers in the video) Pretty Soldier Sailor Moon R, the second season of Sailor Moon, premieres on TV Asahi in Japan. Junichi Sato leaves the director's chair after episode 13 of this series, with Kunihiko Ikuhara taking over. (Source for the logo) March 8: Beavis and Butt-head premieres on MTV, following the footsteps of Ren & Stimpy. March 12: Nick Arcade finishes its run on Nickelodeon. March 12: Ogre Battle: The March of the Black Queen, the precursor to strategy RPGs such as Final Fantasy Tactics and Tactics Ogre, premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. March 16: Vanessa Williams & Brian McKnight's single from the Beverly Hills 90210 Soundtrack album, "Love Is" debuts. March 19: The Twisted Tales of Spike McFang (Ultra Demon World War! Little Dorabo!) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. March 23: Kirby's Adventure premieres on the Famicom in Japan. March 24: Doogie Howser M.D. ends its run on ABC. March 26: The Ray Combs-era Family Feud ends its run on CBS. March 31: Brandon Lee passes away during the shooting of The Crow. This Date In History: April 1993 April 2: The Adventures of Huck Finn, featuring Elijah Wood and Courtney B. Vance of Law & Order fame, premieres. April 2: Cop and a Half, directed by the Fonz himself, Henry Winkler, featuring Burt Reynolds, premieres in theatres. April 2: Mobile Suit Victory Gundam premieres on TV Asahi in Japan. April 3: Capcom's RPG Breath of Fire: The Dragon Warrior (commercial here), the first game of the Breath of Fire series, debuts on the Super Famicom in Japan. (Source for the logo) The game would later be ported to the GameBoy Advance on July 6, 2001 in Japan, to North America on December 1, 2001, and to Europe on December 14, 2001. April 7: The Sandlot ("for-ev-ver") premieres in theatres. April 8: American opera singer Marian Anderson passes away. (Source for the image) April 16: Benny and Joon premieres, featuring Johnny Depp, Mary Stuart Masterson, Aidan Quinn, and The Proclaimers' 1988 single "I'm Gonna Be (500 Miles)". April 17: (TW: alcohol mention) Director Akira Kurosawa's final film, Madadayo! (Not Yet!) premieres in theatres. April 21: Walker, Texas Ranger, featuring Chuck Norris, premieres on CBS. April 22: DuckTales 2 premieres on the SNES. April 23: Lords of Thunder (Winds of Thunder) premieres on the TurboDuo in Japan. (article only) April 23: Xak III: The Eternal Recurrence is released on the NEC in Japan. April 28: Super Bomberman (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. April ??: Cadillacs and Dinosaurs premieres on arcades. This Date In History: May 1993 May ??: Shadowrun is released on the SNES in North America. May ??: (TW: flashing lights) Gaiapolis (article here) is released on arcades. May 1: Kirby's Adventure is released on the NES in North America, and worldwide on December 1. May 1: Goof Troop ends its run on the Disney Channel, later syndicated to ABC and other channels. May 5: Quantum Leap finishes its run on NBC. May 5: Studio Ghibli premieres a TV movie, based on the novel by Saeko Himuro and with character designs by Katsuya Kondo, Ocean Waves (I Can Hear The Sea) in Japan. May 6: Guardian War (Powers Kingdom) (article here) premieres on the 3DO in North America, which was odd since the 3DO console was not publicly released in North America until later in October. May 7: American silent movie actress Mary Philbin, known as the silent movie Christine Daae from the 1925 Phantom of the Opera adaptation, passes away. May 7: (TW: fire, partial nudity) Kenneth Branagh's adaptation of the Shakespeare comedy Much Ado About Nothing (article here) premieres in US theatres. May 8: (TW: flashing lights in music video) Haddaway's album The Album (Haddaway) debuts in Europe, featuring the single "What Is Love?" May 11: Filipino Australian actor-singer James Reid is born. May 12: The Wonder Years ends its run on ABC. May 13: American actress Debby Ryan is born. May 13 - 24: (assume any and all TWs) The 46th Cannes Film Festival begins, where Farewell My C*******e and The Piano tied for the Palme D'Or. Other films in the festival included: Kenneth Branagh's Much Ado About Nothing Wim Wenders's Faraway, So Close! Steven Soderbergh's King of the Hill Joel Schumacher's Falling Down Abel Ferrara's Body Snatchers Takeshi Kitano's Sonatine Akira Kurosawa's Madadayo! (Not Yet!) The jury of the festival included Gary Oldman, Louis Malle (director of My Dinner With Andre), Claudia Cardinale (actress from Fitzcarraldo, The Pink Panther), Abbas Kiarostami, and Tom Luddy. May 14: American actress-singer Miranda Cosgrove (iCarly, School of Rock, Drake & Josh) is born. May 15: The 38th EuroVision Song Contest takes place in Millstreet, County Cork, Ireland, with Niamh Kavanagh for Ireland as the champion, for the song "In Your Eyes". May 15: The Piano, directed by New Zealander Jane Campion, and featuring Anna Paquin (True Blood, Castle In The Sky, Fly Away Home), premieres at the 46th Cannes Film Festival, with a release in France on May 19, and in August 5 in Australia. May 15: The Alamodome opens in San Antonio, Texas, USA. May 17: Intel's Pentium processor is publicly unveiled. May 19: The UK edition of the game show Blockbusters ends its run on ITV, continuing for another season on Sky One in the UK. May 20: Cheers ends its run. May 20: Filipina actress Devon Seron is born. May 21: (TW: flashing images) Hot Shots! Part Deux premieres in theatres. May 22: Saved By The Bell ends its run on NBC. May 24: Sega introduces their game ratings system. May 28: (TW: fire, flashing lights) Super Mario Bros., the flop film based on the video game series, premieres in theatres. May 29: Juan Manuel Marquez (56 W-7 L-1 D) starts off his professional boxing career in Mexico City, Distrito Federal, Mexico. June 1: Super Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back is released on the SNES in North America, later released for the Super Famicom in Japan on December 17, and in Europe on February 24, 1994. This Date In History: June 1993 June 1: Sting's "Fields of Gold" debuts as a single. June 1: The Labyrinth of Time is released on PC, Macintosh, and Amiga CD32s in North America. (article only) June 3: Nintendo releases their newer NES/Famicom top loader model. June 5: Ninja Scroll premieres in theatres in Japan. (article only) June 5: Conway Twitty passes away while having surgery. June 6: (TW: flashing lights) The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening (Japanese commercial here, US commercial here, article here) is released in Japan for the Game Boy, later released in North America on August, and in Europe on November 18. (enjoy the commercials!) June 7: Prince changes his name to an unreadable symbol, where everyone else later dubbed him as The Artist Formerly Known As Prince. June 9 - 20: The 1993 NBA Finals takes place, with the Chicago Bulls taking on the Phoenix Suns, with the Bulls winning the championship for a third time in a row. June 11: Jurassic Park, based on Michael Crichton's novel, premieres worldwide. June 11: Shining Time Station ends its original run. June 15: Leisure Suit Larry 6: Shape Up or Slip Out! premieres on PCs and Macintosh. (article only) June 17: (TW: flashing lights) Gargoyle's Quest II premieres on the NES in Europe, previously released on the Famicom in Japan on July 17, 1992, and the NES in North America on October 1992. June 18: Once Upon A Forest, based on the novel A Furling's Story by Rae Lambert, premieres in US theatres, featuring the ex-Phantom Michael Crawford, Ben Vereen, and a musical score by James Horner. The film was later released in the UK on October 22, and in Australia on December 23. The dinosaurs stomped over this movie too, I think. (Source of the poster) June 19: William Golding, author of Lord of the Flies, passes away. June 20: Jeeves and Wooster, featuring Stephen Fry and Hugh Laurie as the titular duo, ends its run on ITV, which began in April 22, 1990. Here's a scene from the first episode. June 21: Whitney Houston's "Run To You" is released as a single. June 22: Betrayal at Krondor (article here), based on Raymond E. Feist's Riftwar saga series, is released on PCs. June 22: Former First Lady Pat Nixon passes away from lung cancer. June 24: British mathematician Andrew Wiles proves Fermat's Last Theorem. Here's his proof for further detail. June 25: (TW: blood, gore) Mortal Kombat II is released in arcades. June 25: Shining Force Gaiden II: The Sword of Hajya premieres on the Sega Game Gear in Japan. (article only) June 25: The first game in the Lufia series, Lufia and the Fortress of Doom (Biography of Estpolis) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. June 25: Dennis the Menace premieres in theatres. June 25: Sleepless in Seattle, featuring Ingmar Bergman's cinematographer as this film's cinematographer, premieres in theatres. June 25: Late Night with David Letterman ends its run on NBC. June 26: Ariana Grande is born. June 26: Roy Campanella, three-time MVP for the Los Angeles Dodgers, passes away. June 28: The Chicken Soup for the Soul series by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen starts off with Chicken Soup for the Soul. June 30: Les Miserables opens in Dublin at the Point Theatre. This Date In History: July 1993 July 2: Pope John Paul II hospitalized for CAT-scan testing. July 7: (TW: bright, flashing lights) Samurai Shodown (Samurai Spirits) (article here) is released in arcades in Japan. July 10: A Different World finishes its run on NBC, which premiered on September 24, 1987. July 11: Street Fighter II Turbo: Hyper Fighting is released on the Super Famicom in Japan, and released internationally on the SNES in August. July 12: Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Sunset Boulevard, based on the 1950 Billy Wilder film of the same name, premieres in the Adelphi Theatre in West End, London, UK. July 14: Super Mario All-Stars (Japanese commercial here, US commercial here), a compilation of remastered Super Mario games, premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released for the SNES in North America on August 1, and for PAL regions on December 16. July 14: Yoshi's Safari (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan, later to the SNES in North America on September 1993, and later to PAL regions on the same year. July 16: The Disney-produced cult classic Hocus Pocus puts a spell on everyone as it flies into theatres. July 19: The Irresponsible Captain Tylor ends its run. July 23: (TW: spiders, flashing lights) Castlevania Chronicles (article here), a remake of the original 1986 Castlevania game, is released on the Sharp X68000 in Japan. (Source for the cover) July 27: Mariah Carey's single "DreamLover" debuts. July 28: English singer Cher Lloyd is born. July 28: Robin Hood: Men In Tights premieres in the US, later released to French theatres on December 17, featuring Westley, Dave Chappelle, and Patrick Stewart himself as King Richard. July 30: The video game based off of the classic anime Cyborg 009 premieres on the Sega CD in Japan. July 30: Armed Dragon Fantasy Villgust, previously released on the Super Famicom on May 23, 1992, is released on the Famicom in Japan. (article only) July 31: Exile: Wicked Phenomenon is released in North America for the Turbo Duo, with localization work from Working Designs. This Date In History: August 1993 August 1: (TW: bats, flashing lights) Aero the Acro-Bat (article here) is released on the Sega Genesis in North America. August 3: Sheryl Crow's debut album Tuesday Night Music Club premieres, featuring "Run Baby Run", "All I Wanna Do" and "Strong Enough". August 4: Director Ang Lee's second film and surprise hit, The Wedding Banquet, premieres in the US. August 6: (TW: bright lights, flashing lights, spoilers in the video) Square releases Secret of Mana (Legend of the Sacred Sword 2), the second installment of the Mana series, which the first Mana game was given the name Final Fantasy Legend in North America, (article here, commercial here) on the Super Famicom in Japan. August 6: The Fugitive premieres in theatres. August 10: Billy Joel releases his final album, River of Dreams. August 11: American actress Alyson Stoner (Phineas and Ferb) is born. August 11: Searching For Bobby Fischer (dir. Steven Zaillian, screenwriter for Schindler's List, and the US remake of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo), featuring Ben Kingsley, Joe Mantegna, Laurence Fishburne, and Joan Allen, premieres in theatres. August 11: Pope John Paul II visits Mexico. August 12: Pope John Paul II starts his visit in the US. August 18: Manhattan Murder Mystery premieres in theatres. August 19 - 22: The 26th San Diego Comic-Con opens in the San Diego Convention Center and the Doubletree Hotel in San Diego, CA, USA, with 28,000 people in attendance. August 19: Toy companies Mattel and Fisher-Price merge. August 20: Surf Ninjas, featuring Rob Schneider and Ernie Reyes, Jr., premieres in theatres. (enjoy the slang!) August 26: American actress Keke Palmer is born. August 26: The Bride With White Hair, featuring Leslie Cheung and Brigitte Lin, premieres in theatres in Hong Kong. August 27: The Adventures of Brisco County Jr. premieres on Fox, featuring Bruce Campbell of the Evil Dead series, and co-created and executive produced by the future writer of Lost, Carlton Cuse. August 27: Jyutei Senki premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. (article only) August 28: (TW: bright, flashing lights) Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers, based off of the Super Sentai series in Japan, debuts on Fox Kids. (Source for the logo) August 29: American actor Lucas Cruikshank (Fred Figglehorn) is born. August 30: The Late Show With David Letterman premieres on CBS. August 30: The 150 millionth visitor visits the Eiffel Tower. August 31: Mariah Carey's album Music Box debuts, featuring singles "DreamLover", "Hero", her cover of Harry Nilsson's cover of "Without You", and "Anytime You Need A Friend". This Date In History: September 1993 September ??: Plok (article here) is released on the SNES in North America, later released on the Super Famicom in Japan on December 10. September 3: Mortal Kombat is released on the SNES, and was labeled as "The Most Controversial Video Game of 1993." September 3: (TW: gore) Iron Monkey (US trailer here) premieres in Hong Kong, featuring Jet Li and Donnie Yen, and directed by Yuen Woo-ping, the future choreographer of The Matrix. September 4: Filipino French actor Herv√© Villechaize (Fantasy Island, The Man With The Golden Gun) passes away. September 4: B*****s premieres on the Disney Channel. September 6: Dale's Supermarket Sweep, the UK version of the US game show Supermarket Sweep, debuts on ITV. September 6: The Adventures of Sonic the Hedgehog premieres, featuring Jaleel White as the voice of Sonic. September 6: The Master of Orion (article here) is released for the PC and Macintosh. September 7: The notoriously bad Chevy Chase Show premieres on Fox. September 8: The Joy Luck Club, a film based on Amy Tan's novel of the same name, produced by Oliver Stone, premieres. September 9: Gunstar Heroes (article here) premieres on the Sega Genesis in North America, later released in Japan on September 10, and later to Europe in October 1993. September 10: Mark's favorite show, The X-Files, premieres on Fox. September 10: Bill Nye The Science Guy premieres on PBS. September 10: (TW: gore) True Romance, featuring Christian Slater, premieres in theatres. September 10: (TW: gore, one character has a gun to his own head) Sonatine, Japanese comedian Takeshi Kitano's directorial debut film, premieres in Japan, featuring the music of Joe Hisaishi, Studio Ghibli's composer. September 11: (TW: brutal violence) A Bronx Tale, Robert De Niro's directorial debut film, premieres in theatres, featuring Robert De Niro, Chazz Palminteri, and the future Eli "Weevil" Navarro. September 11: (TW: HIV/AIDS mention) The TV film And the Band Played On... (dir. Roger Spottiswoode), based on the book by Randy Shilts, premieres, featuring Ian McKellen, Matthew Modine, Alan Alda, Richard Gere, Glenne Headly, Saul Rubinek, Lily Tomlin, Jeffrey Nordling, B.D. Wong, Nathalie Baye, Phil Collins, Steve Martin, Anjelica Huston, and Richard Jenkins. September 11: Legends of the Hidden Temple (another childhood favorite and one of my favorite game shows ever!) debuts on Nickelodeon. Be warned there may be scary moments in these clips: Here's the first episode of the show. As well as a perfect temple run from a later season. September 11: Other shows that premiered in the US included: Droopy, Master Detective (Fox Kids) SWAT Kats (Cartoon Network) Saved By The Bell: The New Class (TNBC) The New Adventures of Captain Planet (Cartoon Network) September 12: SeaQuest DSV premieres on NBC. September 12: Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman, featuring Teri Hatcher and Dean Cain as Lois and Clark, premieres on ABC. September 13: Late Night with Conan O'Brien premieres on NBC, and Ricki Lake premieres. September 14: Meat Loaf and Jim Steinman's long-awaited album Bat Out of Hell II: Back Into Hell debuts, featuring the single "I Would Do Anything for Love (But I Won't Do That)". September 14: Counting Crows makes its debut with their album August and Everything After, featuring their single "Mr. Jones". September 14: Saved By The Bell: The College Years debuts on NBC, and Madeline, based on characters by Ludwig Bemelmans, debuts on the Family Channel in the US. September 15: Return to Zork (commercial here, article here) premieres on the PC and Macintosh. This game was the final release for developer Infocom. September 16: The Sinbad Show premieres on Fox, and Frasier premieres on NBC. September 16: Fatal Fury Special, an update of Fatal Fury 2, premieres on arcades in Japan. September 16: (TW: mentions of gore) Here's a New York Times article highlighting the violence in Mortal Kombat. September 17: The Age of Innocence, a Martin Scorsese picture based on Edith Wharton's novel, starring Winona Ryder, Daniel Day-Lewis, and Michelle Pfeiffer, with narration by Joanne Woodward, premieres in theatres, and What's Love Got To Do With It, starring Angela Bassett and Laurence Fishburne, which premiered in the US on June 25, premieres in the UK. (article only on the second film) September 17: The Commodore Amiga CD32 is released in Europe. September 18: The following shows premiere: Rocko's Modern Life (Nickelodeon) Cro, CityKids, Tales from the Cryptkeeper, and Sonic the Hedgehog, the SatAM version (ABC) Cafe Americain, and The Mommies (NBC) All-New Dennis the Menace, Cadillacs and Dinosaurs, and Marsupilami (featuring Odo as Stewart the Elephant) (CBS). September 19: Torneko's Great Adventure: Mystery Dungeon (article here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. September 20: Dave's World premieres on CBS. September 21: NYPD Blue premieres on ABC. September 23: Sonic CD (Japanese commercial here) is released for the Sega CD in Japan, later released in Europe and North America on November 19. September 24: Boy Meets World premieres on ABC. September 24: Myst (commercial here), a point-and-click adventure game, debuts on the Macintosh. September 24: Baraka (dir. Ron Fricke) has its wide release in theatres. September 24: The Konami cult classic Zombies Ate My Neighbors premieres on the Sega Genesis in North America, later to PAL regions on January 27, 1994. September 29: Grace Under Fire premieres on ABC. This Date In History: October 1993 October 1: Shining Force II is released on the Sega Mega Drive in Japan. October 1: Cool Runnings premieres in theatres. October 1: Gust Corporation, a video game company, is founded in Nagano, Japan. October 1: (TW: fetishization, racism, smoking) The film adaptation of David Henry Hwang's play M. Butterfly, featuring John Lone and Jeremy Irons, and directed by David Cronenberg, premieres. October 3: Secret of Mana is localized to North America on the SNES, later released to PAL regions on November 24, 1994. The game is later released on the Wii Virtual Console on September 9, 2008 in Japan, October 13, 2008 in North America, and December 26, 2008 in PAL regions. Now that we're in this point in history, this is a...Secret of Mana Appreciation Post! Here's some random music from the game: The intro music ("Fear of the Heavens") "Together Always" "The Color of the Summer Sky" "What the Forest Taught Me" "A Wish" October 3: (TW: smoking, nudity) Short Cuts, from the director of The Player, Robert Altman, premieres in theatres. October 3: Late Edition with Wolf Blitzer premieres on CNN. October 4: (TW: implied adultism in the video) PanaSonic, Sanyo, and GoldStar release the 3DO Interactive Multiplayer game console, to low expectations. October 7: Namco releases Ridge Racer (article here) on arcades in Japan. October 8: An indie film called Deadfall, featuring the atypicalities of Nicolas Cage, premieres in theatres. (article only) October 8: (TW: war scenes) Gettysburg, featuring Martin Sheen, Stephen Lang, Jeff Daniels and George Lazenby, with narration by W. Morgan Sheppard, premieres in theatres. October 9: The rematch between Chris Eubank and Nigel Benn (Benn: 37 W-2 L, Eubank: 35 W-0 L-1 D) takes place. October 10: The notoriously awful unofficial Zelda games Link: The Faces of Evil and Zelda: The Wand of Gamelon premiere on the CD-i in North America. October 10: If memory serves me right, Iron Chef (Ironmen of Cooking), a cook-off show (and one of my favorite shows ever), premieres on Fuji TV in Japan. The show was later dubbed and broadcast on Food Network, and the Fine Living Network in the US, featuring Hans Zimmer's Backdraft score. Allez cuisine! (Source for the logo) Since we're at this point in history, this is an...Iron Chef Appreciation Post! As a late Christmas gift, here's one mouth-watering episode. And as an early Valentine's gift, here's another one. October 15: (TW: plane crash, Vietnam war mention) Fearless (dir. Peter Weir) premieres in theatres, featuring The Dude himself, Isabella Rosselini, Rosie Perez, and John Turturro. October 15: The Beverly Hillbillies (dir. Penelope Spheeris) premieres in theatres. October 15: The Luxor Las Vegas opens its doors. October 16: Slam Dunk (article here), based off of the manga by Takehiko Inoue, premieres on TV Asahi in Japan. October 16: Filipino singer Jovit Baldivino is born. Here are his cover performances of Queen's "Too Much Love Will Kill You" and Europe's "Carrie". October 18: American actress Lois Kibbee passes away. October 22: Vay (article here) is released on the Sega CD in Japan. October 22: Sylphia is released on the PC Engine in Japan. October 25: American actor Vincent Price passes away. October 25: Sonic Chaos premieres on the Sega Master System in Europe. October 27: Treasure Island Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas has its grand opening. October 28: Bubsy In: Claws Encounters of the Furred Kind (gameplay here, article here) is released on the SNES in Europe. October 29: Castlevania: Rondo of Blood (Devil's Castle Dracula X: Rondo of Blood) is released on the PC-Engine CD in Japan. This game would not be released to North America until the release of Castlevania: The Dracula X Chronicles on October 23, 2007 for the PlayStation Portable (PSP). October 31: What's this? This is Halloween! Halloween! Halloween! The Nightmare Before Christmas premieres in theatres. Disney executives at the time thought this film was too dark, and downplayed its release. October 31: River Phoenix and Italian director Federico Fellini pass away. October ??: Virtua Fighter is released in arcades. This Date In History: November 1993 November ??: Star Wars: Rebel Assault premieres on PC, Macintosh, Sega CD, and the 3DO. November ??: The video game based off of Batman: The Animated Series premieres on the Game Boy in North America, and is later released in Japan on December. November ??: Sam & Max Hit The Road premieres on PCs. November ??: The first game in the Power Instinct series, Power Instinct, is released on arcades, Super Famicom, and the Sega Mega Drive (Sega Genesis) in Japan. November 3: The Nanny premieres on CBS, featuring Fran Drescher, and Dmitri the Vampire Charles Shaughnessy. November 3: Carlito's Way (dir. Brian De Palma), featuring Al Pacino, premieres in theatres. November 5: Megaman 6 (Rockman 6) is released on the Famicom in Japan. November 5: (TW: smoking, alcohol, Nazi mention, implied antisemitism) The Remains of the Day (dir. James Ivory), featuring Anthony Hopkins and Emma Thompson, based on Kazuo Ishiguro's novel of the same name, premieres in theatres. November 6: Riddick Bowe takes on Evander Holyfield again (Bowe: 34 W, Holyfield: 29 W-1 L) at the Caesars Palace Arena, Las Vegas, Nevada, USA, and a man parachutes nearly close to the ring during the 7th round. November 9: C√©line Dion releases her album The Colour of My Love featuring "When I Fall In Love" with Clive Griffin from the soundtrack of the film Sleepless in Seattle, her cover version of Jennifer Rush's single "The Power of Love", and "To Love You More". November 10: Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat opens at Minskoff Theatre at New York City, New York, USA. November 12: The first Ultimate Fighting Championship tournament for mixed martial arts, debuts at the McNichols Sports Arena in Denver, Colorado, USA. November 12: Equinox (Solstice II) (article here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released in North America on the SNES on March 1994, and in Europe on March 25, 1994. November 14: Puerto Rico votes against becoming the 51st US state. November 15: The Atari Jaguar (where the "bit wars" were at their climax) is released in North America, and to Japan on November 21, 1994. November 16: Russian president Boris Yeltsin closes down the Lenin museum. November 17: The US House of Representatives approve the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). November 18: (TW: alcohol and drug mention) Pearl Jam singer Eddie Vedder is charged with public drunkenness, and WWF owner Vince McMahon is charged with distributing steroids. November 19: Ys IV: Mask of the Sun (article here), from the Ys series, is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. November 19: Sonic Chaos is released on the Sega Game Gear in Japan as Sonic & Tails, and later released as Sonic Chaos in North America on November 23. November 20: Luke Perry marries Minnie Sharp at the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills, CA, USA. November 20: (TW: murder) Winnie Mandela's driver/bodyguard is murdered in Johannesburg, South Africa. November 22: Anthony Burgess, author of A Clockwork Orange and multilingual composer, passes away. November 23: Ace of Base release their second album and their first North American album The Sign, featuring hits such as "All That She Wants", "Don't Turn Around", "Wheel of Fortune", "Living In Danger", and "The Sign". November 23: Cybermorph premieres on the Atari Jaguar. November 24: We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story, produced by Steven Spielberg, and featuring a screenplay by John Patrick Shanley (Doubt) premieres in theatres. November 26: Sonic the Hedgehog is the first video game character to be featured as a float on the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. November 27: Enix releases Illusion of Gaia (Fantasy Chronicles of Gaia) (article here) on the Super Famicom in Japan. November 27: Kirby's Pinball Land (Japanese commercial here, US commercial here, article here) premieres on the Game Boy in Japan, later released in North America on November 30, and in Europe on December 1. November 28: The Adventures of Pete & Pete premieres on Nickelodeon. November 30: Trevor McFur in the Crescent Galaxy premieres on the Atari Jaguar. (article only) November 30: (TW: mention of guns) President Clinton signs the Brady Bill. This Date In History: December 1993 December ??: Isle of the Dead is released on PCs. (article only) December ??: The first game in the Lufia series, Lufia and the Fortress of Doom (Biography of Estpolis) (intro here) is released on the SNES in North America. December 1: Lunar: The Silver Star makes its North American release on the Sega CD by a California-based localization company called Working Designs. (enjoy this opening!) December 1: Counting Crows' "Mr. Jones" is released as a single. December 2: Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Sunset Boulevard opens in Los Angeles, California, USA. December 3: Duke Nukem II is released on PCs. December 3: Guillermo del Toro's debut film, which premiered in Cannes, Cronos, premieres in Mexican theatres. (article only) December 4: Musician Frank Zappa passes away. December 4: Tom & Jerry Kids ends its run on Fox Kids, which premiered on September 7, 1990. December 6: Enigma's album The Cross of Changes is released, featuring "Return To Innocence", later released as a single. December 6: Actor Don Ameche (Homeward Bound) passes away. December 7: Filipina Mexican American singer Jasmine Villegas, or Jasmine V, is born. December 8: American actress AnnaSophia Robb is born. December 9: Mansion of Hidden Souls (Tale of the Dream Mansion) (article here) premieres on the Sega CD and Sega Saturn in North America, later released on December 10 in Japan, and later to PAL regions. December 10: (TW: gore, carnage, Satanic imagery) The big bad 3D first-person shooter classic by id Software, Doom (Atari Jaguar commercial here), is released on PCs and Macintosh. Many ports of this game soon followed. Three other games are also released on this date: Jim Power: The Lost Dimension in 3-D is released on the SNES in North America. R-Type III: The Third Lightning is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. (article only) Namco releases their arcade classic, Dragon Buster, on the X86000. December 10: David Foster's Christmas Album broadcasts on NBC, featuring music from Foster's The Christmas Album featuring cover versions of carols from stars such as: Roberta Flack & Peabo Bryson Ben Vereen Johnny Mathis Wynonna Judd Vanessa Williams BeBe & CeCe Winans C√©line Dion Tom Jones Natalie Cole (RIP) Michael Crawford Tammy Wynette The first link goes to Foster's rendition of "Carol of The Bells", other links go to each star's cover version of their carol. December 10: (TW: war scenes, genocide mention) Geronimo: An American Legend (dir. Walter Hill, Streets of Fire, The Warriors) premieres in theatres. December 11: Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle is elected President of Chile. Tagle does not take the office until March 11, 1994. December 13: John Michael Montgomery releases the single "I Swear", later to be covered by All-4-One. December 13: (TW: imperialism) Israeli forces refuse to withdraw from Gaza. December 14: The last of the original tower of the Flamingo Las Vegas is demolished. December 15: John Williams makes his final appearance as conductor for the Boston Pops Orchestra. Here are excerpts from his score from Home Alone. December 15: (TW: Holocaust mention) Schindler's List (dir. Steven Spielberg) is released worldwide. December 16: Shannen Doherty is fired from Beverly Hills 90210. December 17: What's Eating Gilbert Grape? premieres in theatres. December 17: (TW: flashing lights) Mega Man X (Rockman X) is released in Japan on the Super Famicom. December 17: (TW: flashing lights) Phantasy Star IV: The End of the Millenium (commercial here) is released on the Sega Mega Drive in Japan. December 18: The current MGM Grand Las Vegas has its grand opening, originally called the Airport Marina. December 18: Kung Fu Cult Master (dir. Wong Jing), featuring Jet Li, based on Louis Cha's 1961 novel The Heaven Sword and Dragon Saber, premieres in Hong Kong theatres. December 21: WWF Rage in the Cage and Xplora1: Peter Gabriel's Secret World are released on the Sega CD in North America. December 21: Ace of Base's song "The Sign" is released as a single in North America. December 22: Ys IV: The Dawn of Ys (commercial here, article here), from the Ys series, is released on the PC-Engine. December 22: Mickey Mouse: Magic Wands! (Mickey Mouse V: The Magic Stick) premieres on the Game Boy in Japan. (article only) December 24: Tombstone premieres in theatres. December 25: Japanese actress and model Emi Takei (Rurouni Kenshin film adaptation trilogy) is born. December 25: Grumpy Old Men (dir. Howard Deutch), featuring Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Kevin Pollak, Daryl Hannah, and Sophia Loren, premieres in theatres. December 27: (TW: terrorism) In the Name of the Father (dir. Jim Sheridan), featuring Daniel Day-Lewis, Emma Thompson, and Pete Postlethwaite, premieres in Ireland, later as a limited release in the US on December 29, in the UK on February 11, 1994, and a wide release in the US on February 25, 1994. December 29: Creation of Flashing Maten is released on the Sega Mega Drive in Japan. December 30: The Vatican recognizes Israel. December 31: Barbra Streisand makes her first live public concert in 20 years at the newly opened MGM Grand in Las Vegas. Other events in 1993 include: The American rock band Train is formed. Lois Lowry's YA novel The Giver (another childhood favorite!) is published. MicroProse releases a point-and-click game Return of the Phantom on PCs. April 1: The last of the now non-canon Star Wars Thrawn Trilogy written by Timothy Zahn, The Last Command, is published on hardcover, with the previous installments Heir to the Empire and Dark Force Rising released on May 1, 1991, and 1992 respectively. August 11: Searching For Bobby Fischer (dir. Steven Zaillian, screenwriter for Schindler's List, and the US remake of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo), featuring Ben Kingsley, Joe Mantegna, Laurence Fishburne, and Joan Allen, premieres in theatres. August 26: The Bride With White Hair (dir. Ronny Yu), featuring Brigitte Lin and Leslie Cheung, premieres in Hong Kong theatres. (article only) October 1: The second adventure in the Putt-Putt series, Putt-Putt Goes to the Moon is released on PCs. This Date In History: January 1994 ??: Here's a Today show clip of the hosts figuring out the World Wide Web. January ??: Mega Man X (Rockman X) (Japanese commercial here) is localized to North America on the SNES. January ??: Skyblazer premieres on the SNES in North America. January 1: The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is passed by Congress. January 2: Doug ends its run on Nickelodeon, with the final episode, "Doug Graduates/Doug's Bad Trip". January 5: Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives Tip O'Neill passes away. January 6: Nancy Kerrigan gets her leg crushed! :( January 7: Akazukin Chacha (Red Riding Hood Chacha) (another childhood favorite yay! Article here), based on Min Ayahana's manga series serialized in Shueisha's Ribon magazine, premieres in Japan on TV Tokyo. This show would later be syndicated to Southeast Asia's Cartoon Network branch around 1998-1999. January 8: Video game ratings are in planning at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show. January 9: Australian actress Madge Ryan (Dr. Branom in A Clockwork Orange) dies. January 10: January 15: American singer Harry Nilsson ("Without You") passes away. January 19: Case Closed (Detective Conan) starts its serialization in Weekly Shonen Sunday. (article only) January 20: (TW: smoking) Four Weddings and a Funeral (dir. Mike Newell), featuring Andie MacDowell, Hugh Grant, Kristen Scott Thomas, John Hannah, Rowan Atkinson, and a screenplay by Richard Curtis, The Coen Brothers' The Hudsucker Proxy featuring Tim Robbins, and Ben Stiller's directorial debut film Reality Bites, premiere at the Sundance Film Festival. January 21: Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land is released on the Game Boy in Japan. January 21: Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. January 22: American actor Telly Savalas (On Her Majesty's Secret Service, Kojak) passes away. January 26: Babylon 5, created by J. Michael Straczynski, premieres in the Prime Time Entertainment Network in the US. January 26: (TW: a character has a gun to their head) The second film of the Three Colours trilogy, Three Colours: White (dir. Krzysztof Kieslowski) premieres. January 28: Filipino boxer "Prince" Albert Pagara (25 W) is born. January 28: American voice actor Hal Smith passes away. January 29: Brain Lord premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. (article only) January 29: CityKids ends its run on ABC, which premiered on September 18, 1993. This Date In History: February 1994 February 2: Sonic the Hedgehog 3 premieres on the Sega Genesis in North America, later released in PAL regions on February 24. February 4: Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (dir. Tom Shadyac), featuring Jim Carrey, premieres in theatres. February 5: The animated series Where On Earth Is Carmen Sandiego? (article here) premieres on Fox Kids. February 6: Marvel Comics artist and writer Jack Kirby, and American actor and Mercury theatre player Joseph Cotten (Citizen Kane, The Third Man) pass away. February 17: Randy Shilts, author of And the Band Played On, passes away from AIDS. February 18: (TW: flashing lights) Skyblazer (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan, which was released in North America on January 1994. February 19: Wario's Woods premieres on the Famicom in Japan, and is the first game to feature Toad as the main character, and the last licensed game to be released on the NES. February 23: American actress Dakota Fanning is born. February 25: American boxer Jersey Joe Walcott (51 W-18 L-2 D) passes away in Camden, New Jersey, USA. This Date In History: March 1994 March 1: Selena is the first Tejano singer to win a Grammy award, and Frank Sinatra is awarded the Grammy Legend Award. However, his speech is cut short, and other invited artists during the ceremony protest this action. March 4: Canadian comedian John Candy (Uncle Buck, Spaceballs, Cool Runnings, Planes, Trains, and Automobiles) passes away. March 4: The U.S. Senate subcommittee on video game violence re-convenes hearings, where seven video game companies propose a ratings system at the end of the season. March 10: Panasonic and GoldStar create their versions of the 3DO console. March 12: Sailor Moon R finishes its run. March 13: The Busy World of Richard Scarry, based on characters created by children's author Richard Scarry premieres on Showtime, later moving to Nick Jr. March 13: Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land is released in North America for the Game Boy. March 14: American actor Ansel Elgort (The Fault In Our Stars, Divergent) is born. March 15: American pianist Jim Brickman's debut album No Words is released. March 15: Megaman 6 (Rockman 6) (commercial here) is released on the NES in North America. March 17: (TW: insects, gore, dismemberment) Castlevania: Bloodlines (commercial here) is released on the Sega Genesis in North America, later to Japan under the title Vampire Killer on March 18, and later to PAL regions as Castlevania: The New Generation on March 20. March 17: Swedish actress and film director Mai Zetterling (The Witches) passes away. March 18: Shin Megami Tensei II (True Goddess Reincarnation II) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. (article only) March 18: The Naked Gun 33 1/3: The Final Insult premieres in theatres. March 19: Pretty Soldier Sailor Moon S, the third season of Sailor Moon, premieres on TV Asahi in Japan. (Source for the logo) March 19: Super Metroid (article here, commercial here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. March 22: American singer Dan Hartman ("I Can Dream About You") passes away. March 25: (TW: carnage, gore) A small company in Rockville, Maryland called Bethesda Softworks, release The Elder Scrolls: Arena on PCs, starting off The Elder Scrolls franchise. March 25: D2: The Mighty Ducks premieres in theatres. March 25: Skyblazer premieres on the SNES in Europe. March 27: (TW: ableist slurs, carnage mention in the video) Wing Commander III: Heart of the Tiger (article here), one of the most expensive video games produced to date, featuring Mark Hamill, Malcolm McDowell, and John Rhys-Davies, is released on PCs and Macintosh. March 31: Madonna appears on the Late Night Show with David Letterman and pushes the censors' envelope by cursing repeatedly in her interview. This Date In History: April 1994 April ??: Nintendo, along with Silicon Graphics, announce Project Reality, the soon-to-be Nintendo 64. April ??: Aero the Acro-Bat 2 (article here) is released on the Sega Genesis. April 1: Popful Mail (article here), previously released on the PC-8801 in Japan on Dec 20, 1991, premieres on the Sega CD in Japan. April 1: Ghoul Patrol, the sequel to Zombies Ate My Neighbors, is released on the SNES in North America. April 1: Sister, Sister, featuring Tia and Tamera Mowry, premieres on the WB, along with Ellen, starring Ellen DeGeneres, on NBC. April 2: (TW: flashing lights, spoilers in the intro video) Final Fantasy VI (commercial here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. The game was later re-released for the Final Fantasy Anthology compilation for the PlayStation in 1999, the Game Boy Advance in 2007, the Wii Virtual Console, and the iOS. This game was innovative for its steampunk-esque, Industrial Revolution setting instead of using the traditional medieval theme the JRPG was famous for at the time. Since we're now at this point in history, this is a...Final Fantasy VI Appreciation Post! (spoilers ahead) Here's the CG opening featured on the PS1 port of the game. Here's some more concept art of the game from the Final Fantasy wiki. The logo for the game (where Green vf evqvat ba ZntvGrx kind of reminds me of Korra riding on Naga while wielding a sword) by Yoshitaka Amano. Concept art of the characters by Tetsuya Nomura. Along with some music: FFVI Opening Theme The Prelude "Gur Zvarf bs Anefur" The battle theme "The Decisive Battle" Pnfgyr Svtneb Zhfvp ("Rqtne naq Fnova'f Gurzr") "Kids Run Through the City" "Green'f Gurzr" "Gur Svrepr Onggyr" April 4: Sheryl Crow's debut single, "All I Wanna Do" from her album Tuesday Night Music Club, is released. April 6: Rise of the Phoenix is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. (article only) April 8: Power Instinct 2 is released on arcades in Japan and the US. (article only) April 14: Vay (article here) is localized on the Sega CD in North America, with localization work done by Working Designs. April 18: Super Metroid (commercial here) is released on the SNES in North America, and later to PAL regions on July 28. April 22: US President Richard Milhouse Nixon passes away. April 25: Rurouni Kenshin: Meiji Swordsman Romantic Story (one of my favorites ever! :D :D) begins its serialization in Weekly Shonen Jump in Japan. April 26: OutKast's debut album Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik is released, featuring "Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik". April 28: The Simpsons broadcasts its 100th episode. (article only) April 30: The 39th EuroVision Song Contest takes place in the Point Theatre in Dublin, Ireland, where Paul Harrington and Charlie McGettan from Ireland were the winners with their song "Rock 'N' Roll Kids", with voting by satellite a first time option. April 30: American author and illustrator Richard Scarry passes away. This Date In History: May 1994 May 1: Brazilian race car driver Ayrton Senna passes away. May 2: Nelson Mandela speech after becoming South Africa's President. May 3: A fledgling company called Epic Games releases Jazz Jackrabbit. May 3: Ace of Base's "Don't Turn Around" is released as a single. May 4: American actor Alexander Gould (Weeds) is born. May 6: Nelson Mandela and the ANC are confirmed winners of the post-apartheid South African election. May 7: Edward Munch's "The Scream" painting is recovered after missing for 3 months. May 7: The Sign by Ace of Base regains its number one position on the Billboard Hot 100 after a four week break. The following other songs also reached their peak positions this week: Return to Innocence by Enigma at #4. Love Sneakin' Up On You by Bonnie Raitt at #19. Got Me Waiting by Heavy D & The Boyz at #20. Born to Roll by Masta Ace Incorporated at #23. Player's Ball by OutKast at #37. How Do You Like It? by Keith Sweat at #48. Low by Cracker at #64. You by Candlebox at #78. I've Been Thinking About You by Jocelyn Enriquez at #80. May 8: With Honors, starring Brendan Fraser and Joe Pesci, reaches number one at the box office in its second week of release. The following other films were released this weekend: 3 Ninjas Kick Back and the Dana Carvey comedy Clean Slate. Shocking that neither film managed to dominate the box office this weekend. May 8: American actor George Peppard (The A-Team) passes away. May 10: Nelson Mandela is officially sworn in as South Africa's first black president. May 12 - 23: The 47th Cannes Film Festival takes place, where a little film by Quentin Tarantino called Pulp Fiction wins the Palme D'Or. Other films that premiered here include: The last of the Three Colours trilogy, Three Colours: Red (dir. Krzysztof Kieslowski) The Hudsucker Proxy (dir. Joel Coen) The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert The Browning Version Shallow Grave (dir. Danny Boyle) (TW: NSFW mentions, smoking, flashing images) Sleep With Me (dir. Rory Kelly, the film where Quentin Tarantino talks about Top Gun) I Like It Like That (dir. Darnell Martin) The featured jury at the festival included Clint Eastwood, Kazuo Ishiguro (author of The Remains of the Day, Never Let Me Go), Catherine Deneuve (actress from Belle du Jour), and Lalo Schifrin (composer for Mission: Impossible and The Exorcist). May 13: Four Weddings and a Funeral (dir. Mike Newell, Donnie Brasco, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire) premieres in the UK. May 14: Ace of Base's "The Sign" is still number one on the Billboard Hot 100 this week. May 17: The Joy of Painting with Bob Ross ends its run on PBS. Here's a clip of him painting a mountain. May 17: (TW: carnage) Danny Boyle debuts with his film Shallow Grave, which premiered at the 47th Cannes Film Festival, featuring Christopher Eccleston (the Ninth Doctor) and Ewan MacGregor (prequel Obi-Wan). May 17: Lisa Loeb & Nine Stories's single "Stay (I Missed You)" from the Reality Bites soundtrack debuts. May 18: Sony forms their American Computer Entertainment branch to market the soon-to-be released PlayStation console. May 19: Actor Omar Sharif suffers a heart attack. May 19: In Living Color and LA Law end their run. May 19: American First Lady Jackie Kennedy Onassis passes away. May 20: Fox cancels The Adventures of Brisco County Jr. May 20: American comedian Bobcat Goldthwait charged with misdemeanors for fire on The Tonight Show. May 20: The direct-to-video sequel to Disney's Aladdin, The Return of Jafar premieres. May 21: Miss Universe 1994 takes place in Manila, Philippines. (article only) May 22: Rugrats goes on hiatus on Nickelodeon. May 22: Toronto's NBA team christens itself the "Raptors" and reveals their logo. May 23: Seal's second album Seal II premieres, featuring "Kiss From A Rose" and "Prayer For The Dying". May 25: American gymnast Aly Raisman is born. May 25: Beverly Hills Cop III (dir. John Landis), featuring Eddie Murphy, Judge Reinhold, and Hector Elizondo, along with Little Buddha (dir. Bernardo Bertolucci, The Last Emperor) featuring Keanu Reeves, Chris Isaak, Bridget Fonda, Ruocheng Ying, and a musical score composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto (Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence), premiere in theatres. May 27: Sonic the Hedgehog 3 (commercial here) premieres on the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis in Japan. May 27: Konami releases Tokimeki Memorial (article here), the first game in the Tokimeki Memorial series, on the PC-Engine in Japan, featuring scenario writer Koji Igarashi. May 27: The Arsenio Hall Show airs its final episode. May 27: The film adaptation of the 1960s Hanna-Barbera animated show The Flintstones (dir. Brian Levant) premieres, featuring John Goodman, Rick Moranis, Elizabeth Perkins, Rosie O'Donnell, Halle Berry, Kyle McLachlan, and Elizabeth Taylor in her final film role. May 28: "I Swear" by All-4-One is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. The following songs peaking this week is: (TW: smoking) "I'll Remember" (from the film With Honors) by Madonna at #2. "You Mean The World To Me" by Toni Braxton at #7. This Date In History: June 1994 June ??: The Twisted Tales of Spike McFang (Ultra Demon World War! Little Dorabo!) (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the SNES in North America. June ??: Puzzle Bobble, or Bust-A-Move in North America (article here), is released in arcades. June 1: The cable channel FX Network launches. June 2: Indonesian censors ban Schindler's List. June 3: (TW: ableist slurs, military images) Premiering in theatres this week is Renaissance Man (dir. Penny Marshall), featuring Danny DeVito, Gregory Hines, James Remar (Legend of Korra), and Mark Wahlberg. Also premiering is The Cowboy Way, featuring Woody Harrelson and Kiefer Sutherland. June 4: "I Swear" by All-4-One is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. Peaking this week is: "Return To Innocence" by Enigma at #4. June 5: The third unofficial Zelda game, Zelda's Adventure (intro here, article here), premieres on the CD-i. June 8: The Browning Version (dir. Mike Figgis), which premiered at Cannes, is released in theatres, featuring Albert Finney, Greta Scacchi, Matthew Modine, Julian Sands, and Michael Gambon. (article only) June 8: Ridge Racer 2 is released in arcades. June 8 - 22: The 1994 NBA Finals takes place, with the New York Knicks taking on the Houston Rockets. June 9: (TW: insects in commercial) Earthworm Jim (commercial here, article here) is released on the SNES. June 10: (TW: terrorism, bombings) Speed (dir. Jan de Bont), featuring Keanu Reeves, Sandra Bullock, Dennis Hopper, Alan Ruck, and a script ghost-written by Joss Whedon, and a soundtrack similar to Metal Gear Solid, premieres in theatres. Also premiering is City Slickers II: The Legend of Curly's Gold, featuring Billy Crystal, and Jack Palance. June 11: "I Swear" by All-4-One is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. June 12: (TW: murder) Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Lyle Goldman are murdered outside the O.J. Simpson home in Los Angeles, California, USA. June 12: Sharon Creech's novel Walk Two Moons is released. June 12 - 17: Pope John Paul II has his visit to Spain. June 14: Composer Henry Mancini, famous for his scores of Franco Zeffirelli's adaptation of Romeo and Juliet, The Pink Panther, and other movie scores, passes away from pancreatic cancer. June 15: Israel and the Vatican begin diplomatic relations. June 15: Another little movie by Disney, The Lion King (article here), premieres in theatres, eventually becoming the highest grossing hand-drawn animated movie of all time. June 17: DirecTV begins selling its cable services in Jackson, Mississippi. June 17: O.J. Simpson and Al Cowlings flee from police in a low-speed pursuit along the Los Angeles freeways, ending at Simpson's Brentwood estate, where he surrenders to police. June 17: The FIFA World Cup begins in the U.S. June 17: Premiering in theatres is Getting Even With Dad, featuring Macaulay Culkin, Ted Danson, Glenne Headly, and Saul Rubinek, and (TW: nudity) Wolf (dir. Mike Nichols, The Graduate), featuring Jack Nicholson, Michelle Pfeiffer, and Christopher Plummer. June 18 - July 30: "I Swear" by All-4-One is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "Don't Turn Around" by Ace of Base at #4. June 22: Super Star Wars: Return of the Jedi is released on the SNES in North America, later released in Europe on March 30, 1995 and in Japan on June 23, 1995. June 23: Forrest Gump has a limited premiere in Los Angeles, its wide release premiere on July 6. June 23: The International Olympics Committee celebrates its first centennial. June 24: Slayers (article here), the video game based on Hajime Kanzaka's light novel series, premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. June 24: (TW: smoking, assault, nudity) Premiering in theatres this week is the wide release of The Lion King, which had the fourth biggest opening weekend on its release, and Wyatt Earp (dir. Lawrence Kasdan, screenwriter of Indiana Jones, and Star Wars), featuring Kevin Costner, Dennis Quaid, Gene Hackman, Bill Pullman, Isabella Rosselini, and Mare Winningham. June 25: (TW; flashing lights) Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released on the SNES in North America on July 18. June 25: Peaking this week on the Billboard Hot 100 charts is: "Any Time, Any Place/And On And On" by Janet Jackson at #2. June 25: The last Cold War troops from Russia leave Germany. June 26: Microsoft refuses to sell or support MS-DOS separately from Windows. June 27: Aerosmith becomes the first band to let fans download a free full track online. June 29: American actor Cameron Mitchell passes away from lung cancer. June 30: (TW: plane crashes) An Airbus A330 crashes during a test flight in Toulouse, France, killing off its crew of 7 members. June 30: Tonya Harding is banned for life from US Ice Skating. This Date In History: July 1994 July ??: Yu Yu Hakusho finishes its run in Weekly Shonen Sunday. July 1: (TW: terrorism, bombings, carnage) Blown Away premieres in theatres, featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Jeff Bridges, Forest Whitaker, and Lloyd Bridges.
