Also premiering in theatres are Baby's Day Out and The Shadow, featuring Alec Baldwin, Penelope Ann Miller, Ian McKellen, John Lone, Tim Curry, and Jonathan Winters. July 2: Sailor Moon premieres in the Philippines on ABC 5. July 5: Hootie & the Blowfish release their album Cracked Rear View, featuring "Only Wanna Be With You", later released as a single on July 17, 1995. July 8: Enix releases Robotrek (Slapstick) on the Super Famicom in Japan. According to Next Generation magazine, this game was the precursor to Pok√©mon. July 8: Pentathlon premieres in theatres this week, featuring Dolph Lundgren. July 8: North Korean President Kim Il-Sung passes away. July 14: (TW: smoking, blurred images) Chungking Express (dir. Wong Kar-wai), featuring Brigitte Lin, Takeshi Kaneshiro, Tony Leung Chu-Wai, and Faye Wong, premieres in Hong Kong. Here's a scene from the film featuring The Mamas and Papas' "California Dreamin'". July 15: (TW: racist stereotypes, NSFW mention) True Lies, another James Cameron film, featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jamie Lee Curtis, premieres in theatres. From Walt Disney Pictures, Angels in the Outfield (dir. William Dear), a remake of the 1951 film, featuring Danny Glover, Tony Danza, Christopher Lloyd, Brenda Fricker, Neal McDonough (Yg. Unjx va Fgne Gerx: Svefg Pbagnpg), Matthew McConaughey, Adrien Brody, and a young Joseph Gordon-Levitt, also premieres in theatres. Also released is infamous director David O. Russell's debut film Spanking the Monkey (that's the actual title of the movie!). (article only) July 16: Pom Poko (dir. Isao Takahata), another Studio Ghibli film, premieres in Japan. July 16: The Three Tenors (Luciano Pavarotti, Pl√°cido Domingo, and Jos√© Carreras), along with the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, the Los Angeles Music Center Opera Chorus, and conductor Zubin Mehta, hit their peak in their one night only show in the Los Angeles Dodgers Stadium in Los Angeles, California, USA, with a sold-out audience and one billion viewers worldwide. July 18: Seal's "Kiss From A Rose" is released as a single in the UK. July 20: (TW: adultism) The film adaptation of John Grisham's novel The Client (dir. Joel Schumacher) premieres in theatres. July 21: The single "I'll Stand By You" by The Pretenders is released. July 22: (TW: brownfacing, racist stereotypes, sexism) North (dir. Rob Reiner), infamous for American critic Roger Ebert's rant against the film, premieres in theatres. Also premiering in theatres is Lassie (dir. Daniel Petrie), featuring Susan Sarandon, Tommy Lee Jones, and Mary Louise-Parker (Amy Gardner from The West Wing). July 25: Israel and Jordan sign the Israel-Jordan peace treaty. July 26: Boyz II Men's single "I'll Make Love To You" is released. July 28: The Defender (The Bodyguard from Beijing) (dir. Corey Yuen), featuring Jet Li is released in theatres in Hong Kong. July 29: The Mask (dir. Charles Russell), based on a series of comics of the same name, premieres, featuring Jim Carrey, Amy Yasbeck, and Cameron Diaz's debut. Also premiering in theatres are the film adaptation of Anna Sewell's novel Black Beauty (dir. Caroline Thompson), featuring Alan Cumming, David Thewlis (Professor Lupin), and Sean Bean (Boromir!), along with (TW: ableism) It Could Happen To You, featuring Rosie Perez, and Nicolas Cage skating into a lake. July 29: Konami releases Policenauts on the NEC in Japan. This Date In History: August 1994 August 1: Fire breaks out at the Norwich Central Library in the UK, destroying most of its historical records. August 2: (TW: flashing lights) R-Type III: The Third Lightning (article here) is released on the SNES in North America. The game is later released on the Game Boy Advance in North America on March 26, 2004, and to PAL regions on November 19, 2004. August 3: Justice Stephen Breyer is appointed to the US Supreme Court. August 3: (TW: food, animal executions, terrorism) Ang Lee's third feature, Eat Drink Man Woman, premieres in theatres. Here's the mouth-watering opening. Also premiering in theatres is Clear and Present Danger (dir. Philip Noyce), the last film adaptation of Tom Clancy's Jack Ryan series featuring Harrison Ford. August 4 - 7: The 1994 San Diego International Comic-Con takes place at the San Diego Convention Center, and the Hyatt Regency. 31,000 people are in attendance, and included guests such as J. Michael Straczynski, Rumiko Takahashi, Jean-Claude Van Damme, and Leonard Nimoy. August 5: (TW: sexism) The Little R****ls (dir. Penelope Spheeris) premieres, featuring Bug Hall, Courtland Mead (uh-huh!), and cameos by Donald Trump (BOOOO!!!), Whoopi Goldberg, Mel Brooks, George Wendt, the Olsen Twins, and Lea Thompson. August 5: Protestors in Cuba's Castillo de la Punta spread, creating the first protests against Fidel Castro's government since 1959. August 6 - 20: Lisa Loeb & Nine Stories's single "Stay (I Missed You)" makes the top spot in the Billboard Hot 100, and would stay there for three weeks. Also peaking this week is: "Can You Feel The Love Tonight" (from The Lion King) by Elton John at #4. "Prayer For The Dying" by Seal at #21. "You Better Wait" by Steve Perry at #29. "You Let Your Heart Go Too Fast" by The Spin Doctors at #42. August 8: Droopy, Master Detective, which premiered on September 11, 1993, ends its run. August 8: British pop duo Everything but the Girl release their single, "Missing" (I actually thought this song was from the Eurythmics, for some reason!). August 10: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert premieres in the US. The film later premieres in Australia on September 8, 1994. August 10: Breath of Fire: The Dragon Warrior premieres on the SNES in North America, localized by Square. August 12: The 1994-95 Major League Baseball strike begins. August 12: (TW: military images) The infamous In The Army Now (dir. Daniel Petrie, Jr.) premieres in theatres this week, featuring Pauly Shore. August 12: Wild Guns (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released on the SNES in North America on July 1995, and in Europe on October 30, 1996. The game was later released on the Wii Virtual Console and the Wii U Virtual Console. August 12: Swedish group Rednex release their single "Cotton Eye Joe". August 13: "Stay (I Missed You)" is still in the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "Funkdafied" by Da B**t at #6. "Shine" by Collective Soul at #11. "I Miss You" by Aaron Hall at #14. (TW: implied self-harm) "Come To My Window" by Melissa Etheridge at #25. August 16: The world's first smartphone, the IBM Simon, is released. August 18: American voice actress Jessie Flower (Avatar: The Last Airbender) is born. August 19: Color of Night (dir. Richard Rush) premieres in theatres, featuring Bruce Willis, Brad Dourif, Scott Bakula, and Lance Henriksen. (article only) August 19: (TW: smoking, bombings) Killing Zoe (dir. Roger Avary), premieres in theatres. August 19: American chemist Linus Pauling passes away in Big Sur, California, USA. August 21 - 23: (TW: natural disasters) Typhoon Fred (Susang), which started forming on August 12, makes landfall on Zhejiang Province in China, killing around 700 people. August 21: The last French troops leave Rwanda. August 22: DNA testing proves O.J. Simpson is connected to the double murder of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ron Goldman. August 25: My So-Called Life premieres on ABC. August 25: Macross Plus, a movie set in the Macross-verse, is released in Japan, co-directed by Shinichiro Watanabe. (article only) August 25: Ecco 2: The Tides of Time is released on the Sega Genesis in North America, later released on the Mega Drive in Japan on August 26, and in Europe on August 27. August 26: (TW: brutal violence, gore) Natural Born Killers (dir. Oliver Stone), featuring Woody Harrelson, Juliette Lewis, Robert Downey Jr., and a script by Quentin Tarantino, is released in theatres. August 26: (TW: flashing lights) Cyber Knight II: Ambitions of the Terran Empire (article here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. August 27: EarthBound (MOTHER 2) (article here), the sequel to the Famicom game MOTHER (article here), of the MOTHER series of games, is released on the Super Famicom in Japan after a long development period of over five years. August 27: Boyz II Men's single "I'll Make Love To You" hits the top of the Billboard Hot 100 charts this week, and will stay in that position for three months. August 28: The first Japanese gay pride parade, the Tokyo Pride Parade, is celebrated. August 31: Road & Track Presents: The Need for Speed is released on the 3DO in North America. (article only) August 31: Premiering in theatres this week is an awful film called Milk Money, featuring Melanie Griffith, Ed Harris, and Malcolm McDowell (Fgne Gerx: Trarengvbaf). (article only) This Date In History: September 1994 September ??: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Future's Past is released on the SNES in North America. (article only) September 1: Il Postino: The Postman premieres at the Venice International Film Festival, later released to Italian theatres on September 24, and in the US on June 16, 1995. September 1: Illusion of Gaia (Fantasy Chronicles of Gaia) (article here) premieres on the SNES in North America, later released in Europe on April 27, 1995. The game features character designs by Moto Hagio. September 1: American singer Bianca Ryan is born. September 2: (TW: alcoholism, domestic abuse, brutal violence) The film adaptation of Alan Duff's 1990 novel, Once Were Warriors (dir. Lee Tamahori) is released in New Zealand, featuring Rena Owen, and Temuera Morrison (Jango Fett!). September 3: Russia and China agree to de-target their nuclear weapons against each other. September 4: Kansai International Airport opens in Osaka, Japan. September 5: The celebrity gossip news show Extra premieres on NBC. (article only) September 5: The animated series based on the Disney film Aladdin premieres on the Disney Channel in the US. September 9: Mortal Kombat II is released on the SNES. (article only) September 9: (TW: fire) The Next Karate Kid, featuring Hilary Swank and Pat Morita, premieres in theatres. September 10: The Shawshank Redemption premieres at the Toronto Film Festival. September 10: The TV series adaptation of the 1992 film Beethoven premieres on CBS. September 10: ReBoot premieres on ABC in the US, and on YTV in Canada. September 12: The Magic School Bus premieres on PBS, featuring Lily Tomlin as Ms. Frizzle herself, and the opening theme by Little Richard. September 12: Party of Five premieres on Fox. September 12: Richard Dawson returns as host for Family Feud. September 13: President Clinton signs the Federal Weapons Assault Ban. September 13: Blues Traveler release their album Blue, featuring the song "Run-Around" which was released as a single on February 28, 1995. September 14: All-American Girl, the short lived sitcom featuring Margaret Cho, premieres on ABC. September 14: Quiz Show (dir. Robert Redford), premieres in theatres, featuring John Turturro, Ralph Fiennes, Paul Scofield, and Christopher McDonald (Lt. Castillo). September 16: Premiering in theatres this week is Blue Sky, featuring Tommy Lee Jones, and Timecop, featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme, Mia Sara, and Ron Silver (The West Wing). September 17: (TW: gore, dismemberment) Ashes of Time (Eastern Heretic, Western Poison) (dir. Wong Kar-wai), premieres in theatres in Hong Kong. September 19: (TW: flashing lights in intro) ER premieres on NBC. September 19: Andrew Wiles revises his proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, having found an error in the proof he announced last year. September 21: Daddy's Girls and Touched By An Angel premiere on CBS. September 22: Friends premieres on NBC, with "The First One". September 23: System Shock premieres on PCs in North America. September 23: Premiering in theatres this week is Terminal Velocity, featuring Charlie Sheen, Nastassja Kinski, James Gandolfini, and Christopher McDonald, and the limited theatrical release of The Shawshank Redemption. September 24: The animated adaptation of Free Willy premieres on ABC. September 24: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking this week is: "When Can I See You" by Babyface at #4. "Letitgo" by Prince on #31. September 24: Lennox Lewis vs. Oliver McCall (Lewis: 25 W, McCall: 24 W-5 L) takes place in the Wembley Arena in London, England, where McCall KOs Lewis in round 2. September 28: Cats celebrates its 5,000th performance on Broadway. September 28: (TW: brutal violence, nudity) Jason's Lyric (dir. Doug McHenry), featuring Eddie Griffin, Jada Pinkett Smith, and Forest Whitaker, premieres in theatres. September 29: (TW: ableist slur, body shaming, nudity) Muriel's Wedding (dir. P.J. Hogan), featuring Toni Collette, premieres in Australia, later released in the United States on March 10, 1995. September 30: id Software releases Doom II: Hell on Earth on PCs in North America, later released in Europe on October 10. The Macintosh edition is later released in 1995. (article only) September 30: Ed Wood (dir. Tim Burton) premieres in limited screenings, featuring Johnny Depp. Also released this week is The River Wild (dir. Curtis Hanson), featuring Meryl Streep, Kevin Bacon, and David Strathairn, and The Scout, featuring Brendan Fraser, and Albert Brooks. September ??: (TW: terrorism) The Taliban is formed in the southern city of Kandahar, Afghanistan. September ??: Adobe Photoshop 3.0 is released. September ??: Blackthorne is released on the SNES in the US. (article only) This Date In History: October 1994 October ??: The first video game in the Math Blaster series, Math Blaster Episode I: In Search of Spot, is released on PCs, Macintosh, and Sega Genesis. October 1: Robotrek (Slapstick) is released on the SNES in North America. October 1: Nelson Mandela visits the United States. October 1: Palau gains independence from the United Nations Trusteeship Council. October 1: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking this week is: "Endless Love" by Luther Vandross and Mariah Carey at #2. "Love is All Around" by Wet Wet Wet at #41. "Right Beside You" by Sophie B. Hawkins at #56. October 3: Gary Larson announces he is retiring "The Far Side" cartoon comic strip. October 4: In Switzerland, 23 members of the Order of the Solar Temple cult are found dead, and 25 of the members are discovered in Canada. October 7: Premiering in theatres this week is another Don Bluth animated film, A Troll in Central Park, as well as (TW: bombings) The Specialist (dir. Luis Llosa), featuring Sylvester Stallone, Sharon Stone, James Woods, and Rod Steiger, Only You (dir. Norman Jewison), featuring Marisa Tomei, and Robert Downey, Jr., and Ed Wood (dir. Tim Burton) has its wide theatrical release. October 8: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "All I Wanna Do" by Sheryl Crow at #2. "Lucky One" by Amy Grant at #18. "Bop Gun (One Nation) by Ice Cube ft. George Clinton at #23. "Body and Soul" by Anita Baker at #36. October 8: The Secret World of Alex Mack premieres on Nickelodeon. October 11: Final Fantasy VI is released on North American shores for the SNES as Final Fantasy III. October 11: Korn, a nu metal band, makes its debut in Bakersfield, California, USA, with their self-titled album. October 12: A film company called DreamWorks Studios is founded by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg, and David Geffen. October 12: Daddy's Girls ends its broadcast. October 12: (TW: sexual scenes, nudity) Don Juan DeMarco (prod. Francis Ford Coppola, Fred Fuchs, dir. Jeremy Leven) premieres at ShowTime Theatre in Atlantic City, New Jersey, USA. October 14: Premiering in theatres this week are the following films: The wide release of Quentin Tarantino's second film, Pulp Fiction The documentary film Hoop Dreams (dir. Steve James) The wide release of The Shawshank Redemption (dir. Frank Darabont), from Stephen King's novella, featuring Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, and Clancy Brown Exit to Eden (dir. Garry Marshall, Pretty Woman), featuring Rosie O'Donnell and Dan Aykroyd (article only) Little Giants (dir. Duwayne Dunham), featuring Rick Moranis and Ed O'Neill Wes Craven's New Nightmare (dir. Wes Craven, The Hills Have Eyes, Nightmare on Elm Street) (TW: ableist slur, sexist slur, implied child abuse) I Like It Like That (dir. Darnell Martin), featuring Lauren Velez, Jon Seda, and Rita Moreno October 14: (TW: flashing lights) Gloria Estefan releases her album Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, featuring her cover versions of "Everlasting Love" and "Turn the Beat Around". October 14: Palestinian president Yasser Arafat, Isreali prime minister Yithzak Rabin, and Shimon Peres win the Nobel Peace Prize. October 15: Nicki French's first recording of her cover of Bonnie Tyler's single "Total Eclipse of the Heart" climbs to #54 on the UK charts. October 15: After a nonviolent coup backed by the US succeeds, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide returns to Haiti after three years in exile. October 15: Iraq draws its troops away from Kuwait after threats are made by the UN Security Council and the US. October 15: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. October 18: Sophie B. Hawkins releases her album Whaler, featuring "As I Lay Me Down", later released as a single on February 7, 1995. October 18: Sonic & Knuckles premieres on the Sega Genesis worldwide except Australia. October 18: Vanessa Williams's single "The Sweetest Days" is released. October 19: (TW: smoking) Kevin Smith's debut film Clerks, first of the View Askewniverse films, premieres in theatres. October 20: American actor Burt Lancaster (Sweet Smell of Success, The Leopard (Il Gattopardo), Field of Dreams, From Here To Eternity) passes away. October 21: The Agreed Framework between the United States and North Korea is signed in Geneva, Switzerland. October 21: Demon's Crest (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. October 21: Premiering in theatres this week is: The limited release of Bullets Over Broadway (dir. Woody Allen) Love Affair, featuring Warren Beatty, Annette Bening, Katherine Hepburn, and Pierce Brosnan (TW: gore) The Puppet Masters, based on Robert A. Heinlein's novel, featuring Donald Sutherland, and Keith David (TW: smoking) Radioland Murders (scr. Willard Huyck, Gloria Katz, American Graffiti), featuring Mary Stuart Masterson, Michael Lerner, Ned Beatty, and Christopher Lloyd October 22: Cro, which premiered on September 18, 1993, ends its run. October 22: A statue of Sam Houston is unveiled in Hunstville, Texas, US. October 22: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. October 23: American actor Robert Lansing passes away from cancer. October 24: Puerto Rican actor Ra√∫l Juli√° (The Addams Family, The Addams Family Values, Kiss from a Spider Woman, Presumed Innocent, Street Fighter) passes away from cancer. October 24: Three shows premiere in the US: Allegra's Window (article only), from the creator of Doug (Nick Jr.) Gullah-Gullah Island (Nick Jr.) Gargoyles (syndication), featuring the voices of Keith David, Salli Richardson, and two Star Trek alums, Jonathan Frakes, and Marina Sirtis October 25: Canadian actress Chloe Rose (Degrassi: The Next Generation) is born. October 27: Motown guitarist Robert White passes away from complications from open heart surgery. October 28: Premiering in theaters this week is Stargate (dir. Roland Emmerich, scr. Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich), featuring Kurt Russell, James Spader, Erick Avari, and Djimon Hounsou, along with The Road to Welville (dir. Alan Parker), Silent Fall, featuring Richard Dreyfuss, Linda Hamilton, John Lithgow, and Liv Tyler, and from Walt Disney Pictures, (TW: imperialism, slavery, racism) Squanto: A Warrior's Tale. October 28: Humongous Entertainment's (the developers of Putt-Putt) first entry in the point-and-click Freddi Fish series, Freddi Fish and The Case of the Missing Kelp Seeds premieres on PCs and Macs, later re-released for the Mac in 1995, and for PCs in 1996. October 28: The infamous Shaq Fu (commercial here, article here), featuring Shaquille O'Neal, is released on the Sega Genesis, and eventually to the SNES, in North America. October 28: (TW: gore) Killer Instinct is released on arcades. (article only) October 29: (TW: insects, scary moments, flashing lights) Aaahh!!! Real Monsters! premieres on Nickelodeon. October 29: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. October 29: (TW: shootings) Francisco Martin Duran fires over two dozen shots at the White House, and is later convicted of trying to assassinate President Clinton. October 31: Venus Williams, at the age of 14, enters her first professional tennis match. Also premiering in October is: October ??: (TW: flashing lights) Namco releases Point Blank (Gun Bullet) (article here) on arcades in Japan. This Date In History: November 1994 November 1: Demon's Crest is released on the SNES in North America, later to Europe on March 5, 1995. November 1: Stevie B releases his album Funky Melody, featuring the single "Dream About You". November 3: (TW: child death) Susan Smith confesses the murder of her two children after previously claiming that they were carjacked. November 3: The Criminal Justice and Public Order Act of 1994 is enacted in the UK. November 4: Premiering in theatres this week is Mary Shelley's Frankenstein (dir. Kenneth Branagh, prod. Francis Ford Coppola, scr. Frank Darabont, The Shawshank Redemption), featuring Robert De Niro, Kenneth Branagh, Tom Hulce, Helena Bonham Carter, and John Cleese. Also premiering in theatres is the film adaptation of the video game Double Dragon, featuring Mark Dacascos (Iron Chef America's Chairman), Robert Patrick (the T-1000!), and Alyssa Milano, and The War (dir. Jon Avnet, Fried Green Tomatoes), featuring Elijah Wood, Kevin Costner, and Mare Winningham. November 4: The first World Wide Web conference takes place in San Francisco, California, USA. November 5: (TW: mention of Alzheimer's) Former US president Ronald Reagan releases a letter stating he has Alzheimer's Disease. November 5: (TW: blood, implied ageism in commentary in video) Michael Moorer vs. George Foreman (Moorer: 35 W, Foreman: 72 W-4 L) happens in the MGM Grand Garden Arena, Las Vegas, Nevada, USA. In a stunning upset, Foreman KOs Moorer in the tenth round, and wins three championship titles (WBA, IBF, and Lineal), making Foreman, at 45, the oldest heavyweight world boxing champion. November 5: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. Songs peaking this week are: "Secret" by Madonna at #3. "What's The Frequency, Kenneth?" by R.E.M. at #21. "Thuggish Ruggish Bone" by Bone Thugs-N-Harmony at #22. "Watermelon Crawl" by Tracy Byrd at #81. "Shut Up and Kiss Me" by Mary Chapin Carpenter at #90. November 8: Sting's compilation album The Best of Sting premieres. November 9: The final jury for O.J. Simpson's trial is sworn in. November 9: The element Darmstadtium (Ds) is discovered by Peter Ambruster and Gottfried Munzenburg under the direction of Professor Sigurd Hofmann in the GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research in Darmstadt, Germany. November 11: Bill Gates purchases Leonardo Da Vinci's Codex Leicester for $30.8 million at a Christie's auction. November 11: Premiering in theatres this week is the film adaptation of Anne Rice's novel Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles (dir. Neil Jordan, scr. Anne Rice) featuring Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, Antonio Banderas, Christian Slater, and Kirsten Dunst, and (TW: body issues, implied adultism) The Santa Clause, featuring Tim Allen, Judge Reinhold, and David Krumholtz. November 12: American Olympic gold medal track-and-field sprinter Wilma Rudolph passes away from cancer. November 12: Chandrika Kumaratunga is sworn in as Sri Lanka's first woman president. November 12: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking this week are: "Another Night" by The Real McCoy at #3. "Flava In Ya Ear" by Craig Mack feat. Notorious B.I.G., and LL Cool J at #9. "U Will Know" from the film Jason's Lyric by Black Men United at #28. "Get Over It" by The Eagles at #31. (lyrics only) November 13: Sweden joins the European Union. November 14: The Sega 32X addon for the Sega Genesis is released in Europe, later to North America on November 21, and to Japan on December 3, as a way to extend the Sega Genesis's life span. November 14: Nintendo announces the Virtual Boy at their annual Tokyo, Japan, Shoshinkai Show. November 15: (TW: natural disasters) A 6.7-8.1 earthquake in the Philippines strikes, resulting in 45 deaths. November 16: (TW: domestic abuse, nudity, scary images) The film Heavenly Creatures (dir. Peter Jackson), featuring Kate Winslet and Melanie Lynskey (Orngevpr from Over the Garden Wall), which premiered in New Zealand on October 14, 1994, premieres in US theatres. November 16: Gex (article here, article of the series here) premieres on the 3DO in North America. November 16: Essence of Emeril, featuring Chef Emeril Lagasse, premieres on the Food Network. November 18: (TW: mention of drugs, orientalism in video) American singer, bandleader, and regular performer at the Cotton Club, Cab Calloway ("Minnie the Moocher") passes away. November 18: Nintendo holds their Nintendo PowerFest World Championships at San Diego, CA, USA. November 18: The Swan Princess (dir. Richard Rich) (another childhood favorite!! :D), a non-Disney animated film loosely based on Swan Lake, premieres in theatres. Also premiering in theatres is the remake of the 1951 film, Miracle on 34th Street (dir. Les Mayfield) featuring Richard Attenborough, Elizabeth Perkins, Mara Wilson, Dylan McDermott, and Allison Janney, as well as L√©on: The Professional (dir. Luc Besson), featuring Jean Reno, Gary Oldman, Danny Aiello, and a young Natalie Portman, and finally, Star Trek: Generations! November 19: Spider-Man: The Animated Series premieres on Fox Kids. November 19: "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking this week is: Gloria Estefan's cover version of Vicki Sue Robinson's "Turn the Beat Around" at #13. "Lucas With the Lid Off" by Lucas at #29. "Can U Get Wit It" by Usher at #59. November 21: (TW: flashing lights in the commercial) Donkey Kong Country (commercial here) is released on the SNES by a seldom known developer company called Rare, later released to European shores on November 24, and to Japan as Super Donkey Kong on November 26. November 22: The Sega Saturn is released in Japan. November 23: A little known developer called Blizzard Entertainment release the RTS game Warcraft: Orcs and Humans (article here) on PCs, and Sierra premieres King's Quest VII: The Princeless Bride (article only) on PCs and the Macintosh. November 23: The Pagemaster (dir. Maurice Hunt, Joe Johnston, the latter directed Captain America: The First Avenger), premieres in theatres, featuring Macaulay Culkin, Patrick Stewart, Whoopi Goldberg, Christopher Lloyd, and Leonard Nimoy, with music from James Horner. Also premiering in theatres is A Low Down Dirty Shame (dir. Keenan Ivory Wayans), featuring Keenan Ivory Wayans, Jada Pinkett Smith, and Salli Richardson, as well as Junior (dir. Ivan Reitman), featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Danny DeVito, Emma Thompson, Frank Langella, and Christopher Meloni. November 25: Sony founder Akio Morita steps down as the CEO of the company. November 26: The animated adaptations of The Little Mermaid, which premiered on September 11, 1992, and Free Willy, end their run. November 26: For its final week, "I'll Make Love To You" by Boyz II Men is in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking this week are: "Something's Always Wrong" by Toad the Wet Sprocket at #41. (TW: nudity) "Fade Into You" by Mazzy Star at #44. "Out of Tears" by The Rolling Stones at #60, which its album Voodoo Lounge peaked in the top spot of the UK charts. "Supernova" by Liz Phair at #78. "Picture Postcards from L.A." by Joshua Kadison at #84. November 28: (TW: murder, gore, carnage, rape mention, dismemberment, pedophilia mention in link) Serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer is murdered in prison by a cellmate. November 29: Seoul, South Korea, celebrates the 600th anniversary of its founding. November 30: Snatcher (article here), the cult classic from Hideo Kojima, previously released in Japan for the PC-8801 on November 26, 1988, is released on the Sega CD in North America, later released in Europe on December 15, 1994. Also released in November is: November ??: Midway Games releases Cruis'n USA to arcades. This Date In History: December 1994 December 1: The Game Show Network (GSN) and the Home & Garden TV Network (HGTV) begin their broadcast. December 2: (TW: gaslighting in gameplay video) Breath of Fire II (gameplay here, article here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan, later released for the SNES in North America on December 10, 1995, and in Europe on April 25, 1996. December 2: Premiering in theatres this week is (TW: smoking, alcoholism, abuse) Cobb (dir. Ron Shelton, Bull Durham, White Men Can't Jump), featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Tom & Viv (dir. Brian Gilbert), featuring Willem Dafoe, and Miranda Richardson, and (TW: ableist slur) Trapped In Paradise, featuring Nicolas Cage, Jon Lovitz, and Dana Carvey. December 3: Sony debuts the PlayStation console in Japan. December 3: Clarissa Explains It All airs its final episode on Nickelodeon, along with Sonic the Hedgehog on ABC, and the animated Beethoven. December 3: American actor Jake T. Austin is born. December 3: (TW: ableist slur) "On Bended Knee" by Boyz II Men is in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100, and would stay there for two weeks. Also peaking this week is: "I'll Stand By You" by The Pretenders at #16. "Living In Danger" by Ace of Base at #20. December 7: Japanese figure skater Yuzuru Hanyu is born. Here's his performance from the 2014 Winter Olympics. December 9: The first game in the Tekken fighting series, Tekken (Iron Fist) debuts on arcades in Japan, later released internationally on May 12, 1995. December 9: The Need For Speed is released on the 3DO in Japan. December 9: Premiering in theatres this week is (TW: sexual harrassment, rape) Disclosure (dir. Barry Levinson), featuring Michael Douglas, Demi Moore, and Donald Sutherland, and (TW: heights) Drop Zone (dir. John Badham), featuring Wesley Snipes, and Gary Busey. December 10: Wario's Woods (commercial here) premieres on the NES and SNES in North America, the first Mario game to feature Toad as a main character. December 10: Garfield and Friends ends its original run on CBS. December 10: "On Bended Knee" by Boyz II Men is still in the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "Always" by Bon Jovi at #4. "Be Happy" by Mary J. Blige at #29. December 11: (TW: terrorism, bombings) A small bomb explodes on Philippine Airlines Flight 434, boarded for Tokyo, Japan, killing a businessman named Haruki Ikegami. The bombing was a test bomb planted by Ramzi Yousef, who was convicted for the 1993 World Trade Center bombings, to be used in Project Bojinka, which would take place early in January 1995. December 14: Nell (dir. Michael Apted, Up 7), premieres in theatres, featuring Jodie Foster, Liam Neeson, and Natasha Richardson. December 15: Palau becomes part of the United Nations. December 16: Mega Man X2 (commercial here) is released on the Super Famicom in Japan. December 16: Premiering in theatres this week: The Farrelly Brothers's "comedy" D*** and D***er, featuring Jim Carrey, and Jeff Daniels Legends of the Fall (dir. Edward Zwick, Glory), featuring Brad Pitt, and Anthony Hopkins Speechless, featuring Michael Keaton, Geena Davis, Bonnie Bedelia, Christopher Reeve, Harry Shearer, and Steven Wright Princess Caraboo, featuring Phoebe Cates, Jim Broadbent, and Kevin Kline. December 16: (TW: alcoholism) Monkees singer Davy Jones charged with drinking while driving. December 17: "Here Comes the Hotstepper" by Ini Kamoze is now on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 for two weeks. "When We Dance" by Sting at #38. December 19: The Whitewater Scandal investigation begins in Washington D.C. December 19: Sweden legalizes civil unions for gay couples. December 21: (TW: gore, flashing lights) A small game developer company called Bungie releases Marathon (article here), one of the earliest first person shooter games exclusively for the Macintosh. December 21: Premiering this week is: Richie Rich (dir. Donald Petrie), featuring John Larroquette, Michael McShane, with Jonathan Hyde as the narrator, and Macaulay Culkin as Richie Rich, with cameos from Claudia Schiffer, Ben Stein, and Reggie Jackson The film adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's novel Little Women (dir. Gillian Armstrong, scr. Robin Swicord), featuring Winona Ryder, Susan Sarandon, Claire Danes, Kirsten Dunst, Christian Bale, Gabriel Byrne, and Eric Stoltz The American flop remake of a 1982 French film Le P√®re No√´l est une ordure, Mixed Nuts (dir. Nora Ephron, Sleepless In Seattle), featuring Steve Martin, Madeline Kahn, Juliette Lewis, Rob Reiner, Adam Sandler, Christine Cavanaugh, Victor Garber, Steven Wright, and Haley Joel Osment. December 22: The following video games premiere in Japan: (TW: nudity) Lunar 2: Eternal Blue (Sega CD) Albert Odyssey 2: Sign of the Devil (article here) (Super Famicom) Bomberman: Panic Bomber (PC Engine) December 22: (TW: imperialism, blood) Fist of Legend (dir. Gordon Chan), a remake of the Bruce Lee-featured film Fist of Fury, premieres in Hong Kong, featuring Jet Li. December 23: British actor Sebastian Shaw passes away. December 23: Premiering in theatres this week: The movie based on the game Street Fighter (dir. Steven E. de Souza) premieres in theatres, featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme, Ming-Na Wen, Kylie Minogue, and Ra√∫l Juli√° as (of course!) M. Bison in his final film role. The film adaptation of Richard Russo's novel Nobody's Fool, featuring Paul Newman, Melanie Griffith, and Jessica Tandy in her final film role Death and the Maiden (dir. Roman Polanski), featuring Sigourney Weaver, and Ben Kingsley (article only) December 24: Heretic is released on PCs. (article only) December 24: British actor, playwright, and screenwriter John Osborne (Tom Jones) passes away. December 24: Brandy Norrington, or Brandy's single, "Baby" is released as a single. December 24: "Here Comes the Hotstepper" by Ini Kamoze is still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "You Want This/70's Love Groove" by Janet Jackson at #8. "You Gotta Be" by Des'ree at #16. December 25: Premiering in theatres this week: I.Q (scr. Andy Breckman, who would later create Monk), featuring Tim Robbins, Meg Ryan, Walter Matthau, Stephen Fry, and Tony Shalhoub From Walt Disney Pictures, a live-action remake of The Jungle Book (dir. Stephen Sommers), featuring Jason Scott Lee, Cary Elwes, Lena Headey, Sam Neill, and John Cleese December 28: The M**ness of King George (dir. Nicholas Hytner, Miss Saigon), featuring Helen Mirren, and Ian Holm, premieres in theatres. December 31: The first snowless December occurs in Baltimore, MD, USA. December 31: (TW: plane hijacking, terrorism) French anti-terrorist police stop a hijacked jet at Marseille, killing 4 terrorists. December 31: Is skipped by the Phoenix Islands and the Line Islands as they switch time zones (for Phoenix: UTC-11 to UTC+13, for Line: UTC-10 to UTC+14), where the Line Islands become the earliest time zone in the world (an hour earlier than Hawaii). December 31: "On Bended Knee" by Boyz II Men returns to the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week is: "I Wanna Be Down" by Brandy at #6. "I'm the Only One" by Melissa Etheridge at #10. Other events in 1994 include: May ??: The light novel series Orphen by Yoshinobu Akita, is released in Japan. (article only) August 11: British actor Peter Cushing (Hammer Horror films, Doctor Who and the Daleks, Daleks - Invasion Earth: 2150 A.D., Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope) passes away in Canterbury, UK. September 2: (TW: alcoholism, smoking) The film adaptation of Alan Duff's 1990 novel, Once Were Warriors (dir. Lee Tamahori) is released in New Zealand, featuring Rena Owen, and Temuera Morrison (Jango Fett!). September 11: American actress Jessica Tandy (Driving Miss Daisy, A Streetcar Named Desire) passes away in Easton, CT, USA. September 13: President Clinton signs the Federal Assault Weapons Ban, as well as the 1994 Crime Bill. September 14: From Beijing With Love (dir. Stephen Chow), a parody of the Bond films, premieres in Hong Kong theatres. (article only) November 4: The film adaptation of David Mamet's play Oleanna premieres in theatres, featuring William H. Macy, along with Pontiac Moon, featuring Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen. November 8: Georgia representative Newt Gingrich, along with the rest of the Republican Party, take control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate during the 1994 US midterm elections, known as the Republican Revolution, the first time in 40 years that the Republicans take control of both houses in Congress. November 8: George W. Bush is elected Governor of Texas. This Date In History: January 1999 January ??: Beyblade begins its serialization in CoroCoro Comic in Japan. January 1: The Biography Channel, later named FYI, a spin-off channel of A&E, and DIY Network, the spin-off channel of HGTV, launch. January 1: The euro is established. January 1: The following shows premiere: The Blame Game (MTV) Cold Case Files (A&E) January 1: The novel Girl With A Pearl Earring is released. January 1: City of the Rising Sun premieres in South Korea. (article only) January 1: Ayumi Hamasaki's debut album A Song for xx premieres. January 2 - 4: (TW: natural disasters) The North American Blizzard of 1999 forms, striking the Midwest of the US, causing around 15 inches of snow in Milwaukee, WI, 22 inches of snow in Chicago, IL, record low temperatures after the blizzard, closed airports, $300-$400 million ($441-$589 million in 2016 money) property damage, and 78 deaths from various causes. January 2: (TW: gore, carnage, bright lights) Might and Magic VII: For Blood and Honor (article here) premieres on PCs. January 2: Crest of the Stars premieres on WOWOW in Japan. (article only) January 2 - 9: "I'm Your Angel" by R. Kelly and C√©line Dion are still on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Also peaking are: "The Chanukah Song" by Adam Sandler at #80. January 3: The Mars Polar Lander, or the Mars Surveyour '98 Lander is launched by NASA, as part of the Mars Surveyor '98 mission. January 4: (TW: terrorism, shootings, child death) A shooting occurs in a mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, causing 17 deaths. January 4: (TW: redfacing) Sicilian American actor who portrayed Native Americans, Iron Eyes Cody, passes away. January 4: Jesse Ventura is sworn in as the Governor of Minnesota. January 4: Ed, Edd, n Eddy premieres on Cartoon Network. January 5: (TW: shootings, flashing lights) Total Recall 2070, a TV spinoff based on the 1990 film Total Recall, premieres on OnTV, or CHCH-TV, in Canada, and on Showtime in the US. January 6: American actor Bob Newhart gets a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. January 6: Sonic Underground premieres on TF1 in France, and it was Jaleel White's last show where he voiced Sonic the Hedgehog. (article only) January 6: Dennis Hastert becomes the Speaker of the US House of Representatives. January 6: Future Google CEO and chair Eric Schmidt and his wife each donate two lots containing $1,000 to the Utah Republican senator Orrin Hatch. January 7: Rod Stewart and model Rachel Hunter divorce. January 7: The Senate's impeachment trial against President Clinton begins (video of the trial continuing into January 14 here). The impeachment trial on December 19 last year was the House of Representatives' impeachment trial, where he was impeached by the House. January 8: Premiering this week in theatres are: The actual wide release of Shakespeare In Love (the December 3 release was for its initial premiere in New York, sorry again!), later released in the UK on January 29. The US release of Waking Ned (Waking Ned Devine). January 9: THE X-FILES Game premieres on the PlayStation in Europe, later to North America on October 13, 1999. January 9: (TW: alcohol, sexist slurs, STD mention) My X-Girlfriend's Wedding Reception premieres. January 9: "I'm Your Angel" by R. Kelly and C√©line Dion is on its last week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking are: "Ghetto Cowboy" by Mo Thugs Family ft. Bone Thugs-N-Harmony at #15. "Pushin' Weight" by Ice Cube ft. Mr. Short Khop at #26. "Hold Me" by Brian McKnight ft. Tone at #35. (TW: flashing lights, anti-Roma slurs, racism mention) "Rosa Parks" by Outkast at #55. January 10: (TW: smoking, shaky images) The Sopranos premieres on HBO. January 10: (TW: flashing lights) Batman Beyond premieres on Kids WB. January 10: The New Swiss Family Robinson premieres, featuring Jane Seymour and David Carradine. (article only) January 10: (TW: sexist slurs, murder) Murder In A Small Town premieres on A&E. January 11: Jon Stewart takes over as the host anchor of The Daily Show, until Trevor Noah takes over on September 28, 2015. January 11: Billy Joel receives the Special Award of Merit at the American Music Awards. January 12: American actress Betty Lou Gerson passes away. January 21: The original Super Smash Bros. (Nintendo All Star! Great Melee Smash Brothers) (Another childhood favorite! Japanese commercial here, article here), the ultimate showdown game against Nintendo characters, premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Japan. The game sold around 4.89 million copies and is considered the fifth-best selling game on the Nintendo 64. January 21: (TW: drugs mention) In the Caribbean Sea, 125 miles southwest of Jamaica, the US Coast Guard intercepts a shipment of around 9,500 pounds (or around 4,310 kilos!) of cocaine. January 21: A&M Records merges into the music label Interscope Geffen A&M. February 2: Hugo Ch√°vez is sworn in as the President of Venezuela. February 2: John Grisham's The Testament is released. February 2: Noggin, a spin-off channel of Nick Jr., is launched. February 3: (TW: ableist slur, facial distortion) Asterix & Obelix Take On Caesar premieres in French theatres. February 3: After a three-year marriage, Angelina Jolie and Jonny Lee Miller divorce. February 4: The British run of Whose Line Is It Anyway?, which premiered on Channel 4 on September 23, 1988, ends. February 4: (TW: murder, anti-Black racism, police brutality) At 12:40 A.M., a 23-year-old Guinean immigrant named Amadou Diallo is murdered in Soundview, The Bronx, NY, USA. February 4: A Panamanian freighter, the MV New Carissa runs aground near the coast of Coos Bay, OR, USA. Feburary 24: (TW: executions, armed robbery mention) In Arizona, USA, German citizen Karl-Heinz LaGrand is executed for an armed robbery with his brother, despite Germany's attempts to take him back. February 24: (TW: plane collisions) China Southwest Airlines Flight 4509 crashes into a field while approaching Wenzhou Airport, where all 61 crew and passengers perish. February 24: The 41st Grammy Awards takes place in the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, CA, USA, where Lauryn Hill becomes the first woman to win five Grammy Awards including Album of the Year, Best New Artist, while C√©line Dion wins Record of the Year, and Best Female Pop Vocal performance for "My Heart Will Go On". This Date In History: March 1999 March ??: The light novel series Scrapped Princess by Ichiro Sakaki is first released under the Fujimi Fantasia Bunko label in Japan. March ??: (TW: ableist slur) Shania Twain's "Man! I Feel Like A Woman" is released as a single. March ??: (TW: war scenes) Civilization: Call To Power (gameplay here, article here) premieres on PCs in North America, along with Giga Wing in Japanese arcades. March 1: Sony Music raises audio CD prices by 8 cents. March 1: Nick Games and Sports for Kids (Nick GaS), Nickelodeon's spinoff channel for sports and game shows, launches. March 1: The TV show adaptation of Disney's Hercules, which premiered on August 31, 1998, ends its run on ABC, on Disney's One Saturday Morning block. March 1: Need For Speed: High Stakes (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later to PCs on June 1, 1999. March 1: The Ottawa Treaty, which banned the use and manufacturing of land mines and was signed on December 3, 1997, takes effect. March 1: Pet Shop of Horrors premieres on TBS in Japan. (article only) March 2: British soul singer Dusty Springfield, famous for hits in the 1960s such as "Son of a Preacher Man", and "Wishin and Hopin'", as well as "As Long As We Got Each Other" (with B.J. Thomas), passes away. March 2: The Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas, NV, USA, opens its doors. March 2: (TW: yellowfacing) Madonna's "Nothing Really Matters" premieres as a single. March 3: The other LaGrand brother, Walter LaGrand, is executed by the State of Arizona. March 3: The website LunarNET, founded on December 1997, is renamed as RPGFan, to focus on role-playing games in general. March 3: Gamera 3: Revenge of Iris premieres in Japanese theatres, along with the French premieres of Karnaval, and (TW: alcohol) The Children of the Marshland (Les Enfants du Marais). March 4: Bandai releases the WonderSwan in Japan. March 4: Captain Richard J. Ashby is acquitted of all charges related to the Italian Alps cable car incident, which Ashby operated the Marine jet leading to the incident. March 4: American actor, teacher, and writer Del Close, notable for teaching many comedians and comedy actors such as Dan Aykroyd, Tina Fey, John Candy, Amy Poehler, Bill Murray, Dave Thomas, and Jon Favreau, passes away. March 4: American Associate Justice of the US Supreme Court Harry Blackmun (1970-94), a liberal justice who notably authored the Court's opinion on the Roe v. Wade case, passes away. March 4: Joanne Harris's novel Chocolat is published. March 4: Psychic Force 2012 premieres on the Sega Dreamcast in Japan. (article only) Also premiering are: (TW: bright lights) Puyo Puyo 4 (article here) for the Dreamcast in Japan. Pepsiman for the PlayStation in Japan. (article only) (TW: spinning images, bright lights) AeroWings (Aero Dancing ft. Blue Impulse) (article here), a flight simulator, for the Dreamcast in Japan. March 4: The TV movie It's The Rage (All The Rage) premieres. (article only) March 5: American singer Madison Beer is born. March 5: Paul Okalik is elected Nunavut's first premier in Canada. March 5: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: shootings) Analyze This (dir. Harold Ramis, Caddyshack, Groundhog Day, Multiplicity), featuring Billy Crystal, Robert De Niro, Lisa Kudrow, Chazz Palminteri, Max Casella, Tony Bennett, and Aasif Mandvi. Moritz), featuring Sarah Michelle Gellar, Ryan Phillippe, Reese Witherspoon, Selma Blair, Louise Fletcher, Joshua Jackson, and Tara Reid. A Star Wars fan film, The Dark Redemption. March 7: American film director, screenwriter, producer, photographer, and cinematographer Stanley Kubrick (I remember having to research him for a project in high school!) passes away in St. Albans, Hertfordshire, England at the age of 70. March 7: Beast Wars: Transformers, which premiered on September 16, 1996 in syndication, ends its run. March 7: Digimon Adventure (I remember watching this a lot and being a fan of this show when I was young!) premieres on Fuji TV in Japan. March 7: Beavis and Butt-head Do U. premieres on PCs. (article only) March 8: MLB center fielder and baseball legend "Joltin'" Joe DiMaggio of the New York Yankees (1936-51), known for his 56-game hitting streak, passes away. March 8: B*Witched's "Blame It On The Weatherman" premieres as a single. (audio only) March 9: Shadow Man premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Europe. (article only) March 11: The animated series of Jumanji, which premiered on September 8, 1996 on UPN, ends its run on BKN. March 11: Infosys, an IT service company from Bengaluru, India, becomes the first Indian company to be listed on the NASDAQ Stock Exchange. March 11: Final Fantasy VI (article here) is re-released in Japan for the PlayStation, as part of the Japan-only Final Fantasy Collection, which also includes PlayStation re-releases of Final Fantasy IV, re-released on March 21, 1997, and Final Fantasy V, re-released on March 19, 1998. March 11: The mockumentary Dill Scallion premieres. (article only) March 12: Hungary, Poland, and the Czech Republic join NATO. "At the Stars" by Better Than Ezra at #78. March 14: Road Kill premieres in theatres. March 15: In Brussels, Belgium, the Santer Commission resigns due to accusations of corruption. March 15: Pluto is declared to be the outermost planet of the Solar System. March 15 - 19: The Game Developers Conference, or the GDC, formerly called the Computer Game Developers Conference, takes place in San Jose, CA, USA. Also, the first Independent Games Festival takes place at the GDC. March 16: (TW: flashing lights) The MMORPG EverQuest (gameplay here, article here) launches. March 16: The Neo Geo Pocket Color is released in Japan. March 16: The RIAA introduces the Diamond certification, for albums or singles that have sold over ten million copies. March 16: Joey McIntyre (of the New Kids on the Block)'s solo album Stay the Same, featuring the single of the same name "Stay the Same", is released. March 17: Six International Olympic Committee members are kicked out of the committee for their involvement in the bribery scandal for the 2002 Winter Olympics venue bid. March 21: Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones complete a nonstop travel around the world in a hot air balloon from March 1, 1999 in the Chateau d'Oex in Switzerland to Egypt in 19 days, 21 hours, and 47 minutes. March 21: The 71st Academy Awards are hosted for the third time by Whoopi Goldberg and broadcast by ABC, taking place at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, CA, USA. The following Oscars are given to: Best Picture: Shakespeare In Love Best Director: Steven Spielberg (Saving Private Ryan) Best Actor: Roberto Benigni (Life Is Beautiful) Best Actress: Gwyneth Paltrow (Shakespeare In Love) Best Supporting Actor: James Coburn (Affliction) Best Supporting Actress: Judi Dench (Shakespeare In Love) Best Original Screenplay: Mark Norman and Tom Stoppard (Shakespeare In Love) Best Adapted Screenplay: Bill Condon (Gods and Monsters) (TW: bright, flashing lights in music video) Best Original Song and Score: Stephen Schwartz ("When You Believe", The Prince of Egypt) Best Foreign Language Film: Roberto Benigni (with his surprise entrance! March 24: (TW: car collisions) The Mont Blanc Tunnel fire occurs when a Belgian transport truck, delivering flour and butter, is set on fire, leading to 38 deaths, and to the tunnel's closure for 3 years. (article only) April 1: Nunavut becomes officially separated from the Northwestern Territories in Canada, and Paul Okalik is sworn in as its first premier. April 1: Isard's Revenge, the eighth novel in the Star Wars: X-Wing series, is published. April 1: Square releases SaGa Frontier 2 (article here) for the PlayStation in Japan. April 1: The National Minimum Wage Act 1998 takes effect, where the minimum wage in the UK is set to ¬£3.60 an hour for workers over the age of 21, and ¬£3 an hour for workers under 21. The wage rates are adjusted every October (until this year and 2016, which now adjusts the rates every April and October) and eventually expanded to include apprentices, workers around the ages of 16-17, and to 21-24 year olds. April 1: American record producer, musician, and songwriter Jesse Stone passes away. April 1: Beowulf premieres in theatres, featuring Christopher Lambert, along with the Hong Kong premiere of Prince Charming (dir. Wong Jing), featuring Andy Lau, Michelle Reis, and Nick Cheung. April 14: (TW: genocide, bombings) In western Kosovo near Gjakova, NATO planes bomb Albanian refugee convoys for 2 hours, mistaking them for Serbian military trucks, leading to 73 deaths. April 20: (TW: shootings, murder, suicide mention) The Columbine High School Massacre takes place in Columbine, CO, USA, at 11:19 AM-12:08 PM, where 12 students and one teacher are killed. As a result, the shootings sparked moral outrage and debate over gun control, video game violence, bullying, and toughened school zero-tolerance policies in the US. :( April 22: (TW: shootings mention) Investigations into the Columbine shooting are still ongoing. April 22: (TW: war, bombings) In Belgrade, Yugoslavia, NATO air forces bomb President Milo≈°eviƒá's estate, though he and his family are absent. Other songs peaking are: "One More Try" by Divine at #29. "Blue Monday" by Orgy at #56. April 25: In Littleton, CO, USA, a memorial takes place for the vicitms of the Columbine shooting. April 25: Irish journalist, sports official, and the IOC's sixth president, Michael Morris, 3rd Baron Killanin, or Lord Killanin, passes away. April 25: (TW: suicide mention, shootings) American composer, songwriter, "talk box" player, and founder of the band Zapp, Roger Troutman, along with his brother, Larry Troutman, pass away. April 25: Side Streets has its wide UK release, featuring Valeria Golino, Rosario Dawson, Jennifer Esposito, Art Malik, Leon, and Shashi Kapoor, along with the premiere of the TV movie Durango. (article only) April 26: The original Super Smash Bros. (Nintendo All Star! Great Melee Smash Brothers) (article here), the ultimate showdown game against Nintendo characters, premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later released on November 19, 1999 in PAL regions. The commercial here features the King of Announcers, Don LaFontaine, announcing the commercial. April 26: Sultan Salahuddin of Selangor, becomes the 11th Yang di-Pertuan Agong ("He Who Was Made Lord"), or the monarch, of Malaysia. April 26: (TW: shootings) British TV presenter Jill Dando is assassinated in her home in Fulham, London, UK. April 26: (TW: suicide mention) English musician Adrian Borland of the post-punk band The Sound passes away. April 26: The film adaptation of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream premieres in limited screenings. April 27: The album Songs From Dawson's Creek premieres. April 28: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers get a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. April 28: American physicist Arthur L. Schawlow passes away. April 28: h2g2, an online encyclopedia project, sort of a precursor to Wikipedia, is founded by Douglas Adams, as "an unconventional guide to cover the life, the universe, and everything". April 28: (TW: flashing lights) Cotton: Fantastic Night Dreams (more gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. (TW: flashing lights) Also premiering is Soul of the Samurai (New Jidaigeki Action: Blade of the Rakshasa) (article here) for the PlayStation in Japan. April 29: (TW: alcohol, shootings, explosions, nudity) The Craic premieres in Australian theatres. April 30: Britney Spears's "Sometimes" premieres as a single. April 30: (TW: mention of terrorism, bombings, homophobia, ethnicism, racism, Nazism) At 6:37 P.M., a third bomb is set off in the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho, London, leading to 3 deaths, and injuring 70 others. David Copeland was found as the perpetrator of this bombing, along with two previous ones around London. April 30: Scottish drummer Darrell Sweet of the hard rock band Nazareth passes away from a heart attack. April 30: Aerosmith visits Columbine victim Lance Kirklin in the hospital before a concert in Denver, CO. April 30: Cambodia joins the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN. April 30: Pok√©mon Stadium (technically, this was the second Pok√©mon Stadium game in Japan, but the first for Western audiences, article here) debuts on the Nintendo 64 in Japan, later released in North America on February 29, 2000. Other video games premiering are: (TW: explosions, bright, flashing lights) Ehrgeiz (commercial here, gameplay here, article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later to PAL regions on February 8, 2000. Super Mario Bros. Deluxe (Super Mario Bros. DX) (article here) for the Game Boy Color in North America. (TW: flashing lights and images) Street Fighter Alpha 3 (article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on June 25, 1999. Samurai Shodown! 2 for the Neo Geo Pocket Color. Aliens vs. Predator for PCs and Macintosh in North America, later to Europe on May 25, 1999. (article only) Intellivision Lives, a compilation of Intellivision games, premieres on PCs. (article only) (TW: flashing lights) Star Wars Episode I: Racer (article here) and the video game tie-in of the upcoming Star Wars Episode I for PCs in North America. April 30: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: partial nudity, shootings, car collisions, flashing images) Entrapment, featuring Sean Connery, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Ving Rhames, Will Patton, and Maury Chaykin. Paul Morrison), featuring Ioan Gruffudd, Nia Roberts, Sue Jones-Davies, and Mark Lewis Jones. (TW: murder, shootings) Restraining Order, featuring Eric Roberts, and Dean Stockwell. Sarfarosh (article only) This Date In History: May 1999 May ??: Shania Twain's "You've Got A Way" is released as a single. May 1: Starz launches two spinoff channels, Starz Cinema, and Starz Edge. May 1: Hybrid Theory, later known as Linkin Park, release their first EP. May 1: (TW: shootings) Love and Action In Chicago premieres on video, featuring Courtney B. Vance, Regina King, Kathleen Turner, Jason Alexander, and Ed Asner. May 1: Pok√©mon ends its first season of the Indigo League arc in North America with the episode "The Breeding Center Secret". May 1: After the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards, a two-full episode preview (plus a short) of the upcoming show SpongeBob SquarePants premieres on Nickelodeon. May 1: An exhibit featuring 70 paintings from Paul McCartney are shown in the Lynz Art Forum in Siegen, Germany. The exhibit lasts until July 25, 1999. May 1: (TW: flashing lights) R4: Ridge Racer Type 4 (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America. May 1: "No Scrubs" by TLC is on its final week at the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking are: "Kiss Me" by Sixpence None The Richer at #2. "Please Remember Me" by Tim McGraw at #10. "Sweet Lady" by Tyrese at #12. (TW: alcohol, smoking, police brutality) "Back 2 Good" by Matchbox Twenty at #24. "I'll Think of a Reason Later" by Lee Ann Womack at #38. "Ordinary Life" by Chad Brock at #39. (TW: body horror/distortion) "Get Involved" by Raphael Saadiq ft. Q-Tip at #67. "I Can't Get Enough" by Patty Loveless at #96. (audio only) May 2: (TW: murder) In Weimar, TX, USA, the Sirnic couple is found dead. May 2: Denver Broncos quarterback John Elway officially announces his retirement from the NFL. May 2: British actor Oliver Reed passes away. May 2: Sonic Underground premieres on ITV in the UK. May 3: The Venetian Resort & Casino, located on the site of the old Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, NV, USA, opens its doors. May 3: To cash in on the hype for the upcoming Star Wars Episode I, Hasbro releases its first toys advertising the film. May 3: (TW: natural disasters) The 1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak occurs at 7:00 in the morning, affecting the Oklahoma City area, and causing 36 deaths and $1.5 billion ($2.2 billion 2017 money) in damages, and is on record to have the fastest winds on Earth at 301 mph (484 kph). May 3: The Dow closes above 11,000 points for the first time. May 4: Raven-Symon√© releases her second album Undeniable. May 4: (TW: ableist slurs) Smash Mouth's hit "All-Star" is released as a single, along with Jennifer Lopez's single (TW: flashing lights) "If You Had My Love", and Will Smith's single (TW: flashing lights, ableist slur, spiders, shootings) "Wild Wild West" (for the upcoming movie of the same name). May 4: NewsRadio, which premiered on March 21, 1995, airs its final episode on NBC. May 6: Elections are held for the first time for the Scottish Parliament and the Wales National Assembly. May 6: HBO launches two channels: HBO Zone and HBO Comedy. May 6: High Time To Kill, a James Bond novel by Raymond Benson, is released. May 7: Pope John Paul II travels to Romania, which marks the first time a Catholic Pope has visited an Orthodox country since the Schism of 1054. May 7: (TW: homophobia) A jury finds The Jenny Jones Show and Warner Bros. negligent for the death of Scott Amedure. May 7: (TW: war, bombings) NATO aircraft bomb the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Yugoslavia. May 7: Premiering this week in theatres are: (TW: fire, shootings, explosions) The Mummy (dir. and scr. Stephen Sommers), an action-packed remake of the 1932 Universal horror classic, featuring Brendan Fraser, Rachel Weisz, John Hannah, Oded Fehr, Erick Avari, Kevin J. O'Connor, Jonathan Hyde, and Arnold Vosloo as Imhotep. The wide release of Election. May 8: Nancy Mace becomes the first woman to graduate from the The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina. May 8: British actor Dirk Bogarde (The Damned, A Tale of Two Cities, Death In Venice, A Bridge Too Far) passes away. May 8: Biochemist Edward Abraham, notable for his work in the development of penicillin and other antibiotics, passes away. May 8: The New Woody Woodpecker Show premieres on Fox Kids. May 8: (TW: flashing lights, alcohol mention, ableist slurs) "Livin' La Vida L***" by Ricky Martin is now on the top of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. Songs peaking are: (TW: shaky images, flashing lights, partial nudity) "Fly Away" by Lenny Kravitz at #12. (TW: NSFW mention, ableist slur) "Anywhere" by 112 ft. Lil' Zane at #15. May 10: American author, screenwriter, poet, illustrator, and singer-songwriter Shel Silverstein (Where The Sidewalk Ends, A Light In The Attic, Falling Up, Playboy's Teevee Jeebies, The Giving Tree) passes away. May 10: Michael Learns To Rock release their third compilation album in Asia called MLTR, later released to Denmark on May 19, 1999, and to the UK on August 30, 1999. May 10: (TW: flashing lights) Swedish pop music group A-Teens release their cover of ABBA's "Mamma Mia", their first single. May 10: Shania Twain's single "That Don't Impress Me Much" is released in the UK. May 10: Ken Griffey Jr.'s Slugfest premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America. (article only) May 11: Ricky Martin's fifth album premieres, featuring "Livin' La Vida L***", "She's All I Ever Had", and (TW: bright, flashing lights, ableist slur) "Shake Your Bon-Bon". May 11: American singer-songwriter and actress Sabrina Carpenter (Girl Meets World) is born. May 11: Lycanthrope (Bloody Moon) premieres in theatres. May 12: David Steel becomes the first Presiding Officer of the Scottish Parliament. May 12: (TW: flashing images) Street Fighter III: The 3rd Strike (article here) premieres in arcades. May 12: (TW: fat shaming, smoking, flashing images) Trippin' premieres in theatres, featuring Deon Richmond, Donald Faison, Countess Vaughn, and Anthony Anderson. May 12 - 23: The 52nd Cannes Film Festival takes place, where Jean Pierre and Luc Dardenne's Rosetta wins the Palme d'Or. Other films in the festival included: Atom Egoyan's Felicia's Journey Tim Robbins's Cradle Will Rock Kevin Smith's Dogma Werner Herzog's My Best Fiend Lynne Ramsay's Ratcatcher Jim Jarmusch's Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai John Sayles's Limbo Takeshi Kitano's Kikujiro's Summer Michael Winterbottom's Wonderland (TW: alcohol, ableist slur) Ron Howard's EDtv Steven Soderbergh's The Limey David Mamet's The Winslow Boy The jury for the festival that year included David Cronenberg, Dominique Blanc, George Miller, Holly Hunter, Jeff Goldblum, and Barbara Hendricks. May 13 - 15: The fifth annual E3 takes place (another article here), along with the 2nd annual Game Critics Awards in Los Angeles, CA, USA, where the Sega Dreamcast is showcased, a "next-generation PlayStation" is announced, and Sid Meier is inducted into the Hall of Fame. May 13: Wonderland has its premiere in Cannes. May 14: Premiering this week in theatres are: (TW: partial nudity, flashing lights and images) The wide release of the film adaptation of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream (dir. Michael Hoffman, One Fine Day), featuring Rupert Everett, Michelle Pfeiffer, Anna Friel, Calista Flockhart, Christian Bale, Dominic West, David Straithairn, Sophie Marceau, Bernard Hill, John Sessions, Kevin Kline, Roger Rees, and Stanley Tucci as Puck. (TW: alcohol, smoking, war, ableist slur, fascism mention) The US and Canadian release of Tea With Mussolini (dir. Franco Zeffirelli), featuring Cher, Judi Dench, Joan Plowright, Maggie Smith, Lily Tomlin, Claudio Spadaro, and Michael Williams in his final film role. Scott, Judd Hirsch, and Penelope Ann Miller. Steve Oedekerk), a short film parody of Star Wars, premieres. May 19: The much-anticipated and later hated Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace premieres in theatres, featuring Liam Neeson, Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman, Keira Knightley, Samuel L. Jackson, Brian Blessed, Ian McDiarmid, Jake Lloyd, Pernilla August, Anthony Daniels, and Ahmed Best as the infamous Jar-Jar Binks. This film would go on to make $64.8 million (around $94.8 million in 2017 money) at the box office in its opening weekend, eventually making a box office total of $1 billion ($1.5 billion in 2017 money). Ra√∫l Ruiz), featuring Catherine Deneuve, Emanuelle B√©art, Vincent Perez, and John Malkovich. May 21: Susan Lucci finally wins a Daytime Emmy after being nominated nineteen times for Best Actress in previous years. May 21: Homicide: Life on the Street, which premiered on NBC on January 31, 1993, ends its run. Roger Michell, scr. Richard Curtis, Four Weddings and a Funeral), featuring Julia Roberts, Hugh Grant, Hugh Bonneville, Rhys Ifans, Alec Baldwin, Mischa Barton, and Emily Mortimer. This Date In History: June 1999 June 1: The music sharing peer-to-peer website Napster is launched. June 1: Carmen Sandiego's ThinkQuick Challenge (article here) premieres on PCs and Macintosh. June 1: (TW: plane collisions) American Airlines Flight 1420 overruns the runway in Little Rock National Airport in Little Rock, AR, USA, and crashes, leading to 11 deaths. June 1: The following albums premiere: Jennifer Lopez's On The 6, featuring (TW: flashing lights) "If You Had My Love", "No Me Ames" (with Marc Anthony), (TW: flashing lights and images) "Waiting For Tonight", and "Let's Get Loud". Dido's No Angel, featuring "Here With Me", "Don't Think of Me", and "Thank You". Lonestar's Lonely Grill, featuring "Amazed". June 1: (TW: military images, shootings, drugs mention, explosions) TV movie The Base premieres, featuring Mark Dacascos. June 2: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, covering Harry Potter's second year in Hogwarts, is released to the US. June 2: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan allows TV to be broadcast and Internet access in the Kingdom for the first time as part of his celebration as 25 years as King. June 2: The film adaptation of Gabriel Garc√≠a M√°rquez's novel No One Writes to the Colonel premieres in Mexican theatres. (article only) June 2: The Backstreet Boys break first-week sales records with their album Millennium, where it sold over 1.13 million copies in its first week. June 2: Star Trek: Deep Space Nine ends its run with the episode "What You Leave Behind". (I'm going to miss this show! Jon Turteltaub, Cool Runnings), featuring Anthony Hopkins, Cuba Gooding, Jr., Donald Sutherland, George Dzundza, and Maura Tierney. Wim Wenders). (TW: drugs mention) The UK premiere of Human Traffic (dir. and scr. Justin Kerrigan), featuring the debut of Danny Dyer. Grant, and Anna Friel. Also premiering is the TV movie based on the 1982 film That Championship Season, featuring Vincent D'Onofrio, Tony Shalhoub, Gary Sinise, and Paul Sorvino. (article only) June 7: S Club 7's "Bring It All Back" premieres as a single. June 8: Smash Mouth release their second album, Astro Lounge, featuring their single (TW: ableist slurs) "All-Star", along with the release of 98 Degrees' (TW: flashing lights) "The Hardest Thing" as a single. June 8: Colombia announces illegal drugs as part of the country's gross national product. June 8: Former UK Cabinet Minister Jonathan Aitken is sentenced to 18 months in prison for lying under oath, and obstructing justice. June 8: Thomas Harris's novel Hannibal is published. June 8: Conker's Pocket Tales (article here) premieres on the Game Boy Color in North America. June 8: The red carpet premiere of Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me takes place. June 9: Yugoslavia and NATO sign a peace treaty. June 10: Square releases Racing Lagoon (gameplay here, article here), a racing game with RPG elements, for the PlayStation in Japan. June 10: NATO ceases airstrikes after President Milo≈°eviƒá withdraws his troops from Kosovo. June 11: Dr. Leonard "Bones" McCoy himself, American actor DeForrest Kelley, who was also well-known for being in Westerns, passes away. June 11: Mario Golf (commercial here, article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Japan. June 11: The Cartoon Cartoon Fridays block debuts on Cartoon Network. June 11: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: ableist slur, explosions, partial nudity, KKK mention) Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (dir. Jay Roach, prods. Mike Myers, Demi Moore), featuring Mike Myers, Heather Graham, Michael York, Robert Wagner, Mindy Sterling, Seth Green, Elizabeth Hurley, Verne Troyer, Clint Howard, Tim Robbins, and cameos by Jerry Springer, Woody Harrelson, and Willie Nelson. Just A Little Harmless Sex (that's a creepy title), featuring Alison Eastwood, Rachel Hunter, Lauren Hutton, and Jessica Lundy. June 12: The NATO-led Kosovo Force, or KFOR, enters Kosovo, on a peacekeeping mission. June 12: The Esquire Network is launched as The Style Network. June 12: Texas governor George W. Bush (BOOOO!) announces his run for the presidency for the Republican Party in the 2000 presidential elections. His campaign is formally launched two days later. June 12: Disney's Tarzan has its El Capitan Theatre red carpet premiere. June 12 - July 10: (TW: flashing lights) "If You Had My Love" by Jennifer Lopez is now on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Also peaking are: "That Don't Impress Me Much" by Shania Twain at #7. (TW: assault mention) "Chante's Got A Man" by Chante Moore at #10. "Did You Ever Think" by R. Kelly at #27. "Holla Holla" by Ja Rule at #35. "Stranger In My Mirror" by Randy Travis at #81. June 14: (TW: ableist slur) "Bills, Bills, Bills" by Destiny's Child premieres as a single. June 14: Thabo Mbeki is elected president of South Africa. June 15: Rosa Parks is awarded the Congressional Gold Medal of Honor, the highest honor an American citizen can be awarded by Congress. June 15: (TW: flashing lights) Enrique Iglesias's single "Bailamos" is released, featured in the film Wild Wild West, along with Phil Collins's (TW: flashing lights and images) "You'll Be In My Heart" for the film Tarzan. June 15: Santana's album Supernatural premieres, featuring "Smooth" (with Rob Thomas), "Maria Maria", and (TW: flashing lights) "Put Your Lights On" (with Everlast). Also premiering is Sarah McLachlan's album Mirrorball is released, featuring a live performance of a song from the film The Brothers McMullen, "I Will Remember You", along with "Building A Mystery", "Sweet Surrender", "Adia", and "Angel". June 16: David Mamet's play Boston Marriage premieres in theatres. June 16: (TW: flashing lights) Disney's 37th feature (and my brother's favorite, IIRC), Tarzan, premieres in theatres. June 17: (TW: flashing lights) MediEvil (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. June 17: The Worst Forms of Child Labor Convention, prohibiting and ending the worst forms of child labor, takes place in Geneva, Switzerland. June 17: (TW: flashing lights, shaky images, explosions) Descent 3 (trailer here, article here) premieres on PCs in North America. June 17: Survival Kids: Adventurer of the Solitary Island premieres in Japan for the Game Boy and Game Boy Color. (article only) June 18: Heavy Gear II premieres on PCs. (article only) June 18: Anti-globalization protests are carried out in cities around the world, notably J18, or the Global Carnival Against Capital in cities such as London, Tel Aviv, Glasgow, Los Angeles, New York, and Eugene, OR, USA. June 18: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: explosions, shootings, rape mention) The General's Daughter, featuring John Travolta, Madeleine Stowe, James Cromwell, Timothy Hutton (Nate Ford!), and James Woods. (TW: alcohol) The US release of the film adaptation of Oscar Wilde's play An Ideal Husband, featuring Cate Blanchett, Minnie Driver, Rupert Everett, Julianne Moore, Jeremy Northam, Jeroen Krabb√©. The UK release of Croupier. June 19: Turin, Italy is decided as the venue for the 2006 Winter Olympics. June 19: (TW: car collisions) Stephen King is hit by a van and is hospitalized for three weeks, resuming writing in July. June 19: "If You Had My Love" by Jennifer Lopez is on its second week at the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Also peaking are: (TW: flashing images) "Where's My Girls At?" by 702 at #4. "Happily Ever After" by Case at #15. "Almost Doesn't Count" by Brandy at #16. "Write This Down" by George Strait at #27. "With You" by Lila McCann at #41. "One Honest Heart" by Reba McEntire at #54. "Rollercoaster" by B*Witched at #67. "Hello L.O.V.E." by John Michael Montgomery at #71. "Millennium" by Robbie Willaims at #72. Hertzler (Martok!) as Ridley Scott, along with (TW: alcohol, drugs mention) Late Last Night (dir. Steven Brill), featuring Emilio Estevez, Steven Weber, and Catherine O'Hara. June 27: Tony Hawk becomes the first skateboarder to perform a 900 and succeed at X Games 5. June 27: American actor Chandler Riggs is born. June 28: Pok√©mon Pinball (commercial here, article here) premieres on the Game Boy Color in North America, later to Australasia on July 13, 1999, and to Europe on October 6, 2000. June 29: American producer and stage manager Allan Carr passes away. June 29: Northern Irish character actor Declan Mulholland, known as the original Jabba the Hutt, passes away. June 29: Rugrats: Scavenger Hunt premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later to Europe on August 10, 1999. This Date In History: July 1999 July ??: (TW: bright, flashing lights) Tekken Tag Tournament (article here) premieres on arcades. July 1: The Scottish Parliament has its official opening by Queen Elizabeth II. Here's a video of the opening ceremonies. July 1: Europol, or the European Police Office, which formed on October 1998, begins its full operations. July 1: American actress Sylvia Sidney passes away. July 1: Hard Merchandise, a Star Wars novel, is released. July 1: From the creators of Resident Evil, Dino Crisis (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. Other games premiering are: X: Beyond the Frontier for PCs. (article only) Attack of the Saucerman for PCs and the PlayStation. (article only) Slayers Royal 2 for the PlayStation in Japan. (article only) July 2: Italian American author and screenwriter Mario Puzo, notable for novels such as The Godfather, The Dark Arena, The Sicilian, and the original screenplay for Superman, passes away. July 2 - 4: (TW: neo-Nazism, shootings, racism, ethnicism, suicide mention in article) Benjamin Nathaniel Smith goes on a 3-day shooting spree in Illinois and Indiana, targeting people of color, and Jewish people, killing 3 people, and injuring 10. July 2: Medabots (Medarot) premieres on TV Tokyo, later released on Fox Kids, later Jetix! in the US, and YTV in Canada on September 1, 2001. July 2: (TW: shootings, smoking, alcohol, ableist slurs, flashing lights and images) Summer of Sam (dir. Spike Lee) premieres in theatres this week, featuring John Leguizamo, Adrien Brody, Mira Sorvino, Jennifer Esposito, Anthony LaPaglia, Bebe Neuwirth, Patti LuPone, and John Savage, along with Benaam (article only). July 3: Billy Mitchell gets the highest score on the original Pac-Man game at 3,333,360 points. July 3: The anime adaptation of Hoshin Engi (Soul Hunter) premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. July 3: "If You Had My Love" by Jennifer Lopez is on its fourth week at the top of the Billboard Hot 100. (article only) July 5: (TW: harrassment, assault, transphobia mention) US Army Private Barry Winchell is beaten by his roommate Calvin Glover in Ft. Campbell, KY, USA, and dies of his injuries. July 5: Passions premieres on NBC. July 7: (TW: food) Good Eats premieres on Food Network. Here's a recipe from the show. July 7: Magic User's Club premieres on WOWOW in Japan. July 7: In Rome, Italy, Moroccan runner Hicham El Guerrouj breaks the world record for the fastest mile at 3:43:13. July 7: The Dilettante premieres in French theatres. July 8: (TW: floodings, natural disasters) A flash flood occurs in Las Vegas, NV, USA, leading to property damage, and 2 deaths. July 8: American astronaut Pete Conrad passes away. Frank Marshall, Kathleen Kennedy), featuring Haley Joel Osment, Bruce Willis, Toni Collette, Olivia Williams, Mischa Barton, and Donnie Wahlberg. This film would go on to become the second-highest grossing film of 1999, behind Star Wars Episode I, at $672.8 million ($983.8 million in 2017 money) in box office receipts.
