August 10: Chocobo Racing (Chocobo Racing: Road to the Spirit World) (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on OCtober 11, 1999. August 10: The Atlantique incident occurs, where a Pakistan navy aircraft is shot down by the Indian Air Fore, reigniting tensions between Pakistan and India 2 months after their recent war, the Kargil War. August 11: (TW: shaky images) From Ken Levine, System Shock 2 (article here) premieres on PCs. August 11: A solar eclipse is seen in Europe and Australia. August 13 - 16: The 1999 San Diego Comic-Con takes place at the San Diego Convention Center, with an attendance of 42,000 people, featuring guests such as Paul Dini, Mike Mignola, Neil Gaiman, Mark Mothersbaugh, and Bruce Timm. August 13: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: ableist slur, drugs mention, manipulation, smoking, beatings) Brokedown Palace, featuring Claire Danes, Kate Beckinsale, Lou Diamond Phillips, Bill Pullman, Paul Walker, and Jacqueline Kim. (TW: NSFW mention, ableist slur) Detroit Rock City (TW: partial nudity) Bowfinger (prod. Brian Grazer, dir. Frank Oz, scr. Steve Martin), featuring Steve Martin, Eddie Murphy, Heather Graham, Terence Stamp, Robert Downey, Jr., Jamie Kennedy, John Cho, and Phill Lewis. (TW: flashing images, nudity, smoking, sexual scenes) The US limited and Canadian wide release of Better Than Chocolate. August 14 - 15: At Paisley Park Studios in Chanhassen, MN, USA, The Artist holds a yard sale, selling off memorabilia, with proceeds going to underprivileged youth. August 14: Digimon Adventure, or the first season of Digimon: Digital Monsters premieres on Fox Kids in the US, UK, and Australia, and on CTV in Canada. August 14: (TW: nudity) Adolescence of Utena (Revolutionary Girl Utena: Adolescence Apocalypse) (dir. Kunihiko Ikuhara) premieres in Japanese theatres. August 14: Ghost In Love premieres in South Korean theatres. (article only) August 14: Woman Wanted (dir. Kiefer Sutherland under Alan Smithee) premieres in theatres, featuring Holly Hunter, Michael Moriarty, and Kiefer Sutherland. (article only) August 14: "Genie In A Bottle" by Christina Aguilera is in its third week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking are: "Tell Me It's Real" by K-Ci and JoJo at #2. August 16: Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver (gameplay here, commercial here, article here) is released on the PlayStation in North America. August 17: (TW: natural disasters) The Izmit earthquake occurs in Northwestern Turkey, measuring at 7.6 Mw, causing around 17,000 deaths and 50,000 injuries. August 17: UmJammer Lammy (commercial here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on September 10, 1999, and to Japanese arcades on September 15, 1999. August 17: Brian McKnight's "Back At One" premieres as a single, along with Mandy Moore's debut single (TW: ableist slur) "Candy". August 17: Chicken Soup for the Soul, based on the series of inspirational books of the same name, premieres on PAX. August 17: Belle's Tales of Friendship premieres on video. (article only) August 17: (TW: flashing images, torture) Wishmaster 2: Evil Never Dies premieres on DVD. August 19: Dr. Brain: Action Reaction premieres on PCs. (article only) August 19: In Belgrade, its citizens call for President Milo≈°eviƒá to resign. August 20: (TW: drugs mention) American musician Bobby Sheehan, the bassist for Blues Traveler, passes away. August 21: The TV movie Genius premieres on the Disney Channel. (article only) August 21: Cardcaptor Sakura: The Movie (dir. Morio Asaka) premieres in Japanese theatres. August 21: American actor Maxim Knight is born. August 21: "Genie In A Bottle" by Christina Aguilera is on its fourth week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Master P at #96. "Better Than Me" by Terry Dexter at #99. August 22: Canadian actor Dakota Goyo (Real Steel, Rise of the Guardians) is born. August 22: (TW: plane collisions) Flight 642 of China Airlines crashes at the Hong Kong International Airport, leaving 3 deaths, and 208 injuries. August 22: The TV movie Au Pair premieres on Fox Family. August 23: (TW: ableist slurs, bright, flashing lights) Britney Spears's "(You Drive Me) C***y" premieres as a single. August 30: (TW: flashing lights) The Parkers premieres on UPN, the spinoff show of Moesha. August 30: Sonic Underground premieres in the US in syndication. August 30: In a referendum, East Timor votes for independence from Indonesia. August 31: Greg Bear's novel, Darwin's Radio, is released. August 31: Apple releases the PowerMac G4 to the public. August 31: Vitamin C's self-titled album premieres, featuring (TW: flashing lights) "Smile (with Lady Saw)", and "Graduation (Friends Forever)". This Date In History: September 1999 September 1: (TW: fire, bright lights) Fire Emblem: Thracia 776 (article here) premieres on the Super Famicom in Japan. Also premiering is: Tiny Tank premieres for the PlayStation in North America. (article only) September 1: Paris Las Vegas opens its doors in Las Vegas, NV, USA. September 1: Northern Irish musician Van Morrison is the first person to be inducted into the Irish Music Hall of Fame. September 1: Zambian-born American computer scientist and writer, known for his work on UNIX operating systems, W. Richard Stevens, passes away. September 1: (TW: bombings, shootings, explosions, ableist slur) Chill Factor premieres in theatres, featuring Cuba Gooding, Jr., Skeet Ulrich, and Kevin J. O'Connor, along with (TW: alcohol) Outside Providence (story: Peter Farrelly), featuring Shawn Hatosy, Amy Smart, Alec Baldwin, George Wendt, and Richard Jenkins. September 2: Wild Arms 2 (Wild Arms: 2nd Ignition) (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. Here's some fanart from Wild Arms 2: Group art by HeavyMetalHanzo. Tim Rhymeless by zakkvanburace. Along with official art here, and here. Also some music from the game: Main title "Dungeon Exploring" "Magical Girl Entrance" "Roaming" (world map theme) Battle theme "Condition Green!" "You'll Never Be Alone No Matter Where You Go" September 2: (TW: war scenes) Square releases Front Mission 3 (article here) for the PlayStation in Japan. September 3: The Backstreet Boys' "Larger Than Life" premieres as a single. September 3: From the developers of Mischief Makers, Bangai-O (Explosive, Invincible Bangaioh) (article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Japan, later released to the PlayStation on December 9, 1999. September 3: (TW: NSFW mention) The mockumentary The Mating Habits of the Earthbound Human premieres in theatres, featuring David Hyde Pierce, Carmen Electra, Lucy Liu, and Mackenzie Astin (article only), along with (TW: smoking, shootings) Sweet and Lowdown, featuring Anthony LaPaglia, Sean Penn, Uma Thurman, and John Waters. September 4: Zoids: Chaotic Century (article here) premieres on MBS and TBS in Japan. September 4; 8; 13; 16: (TW: terrorism, bombings) A series of four bombings occur in apartment buildings in Russia, affecting the cities of Buynaksk, Moscow, and Volgodonsk, leaving a total of 293 deaths, and around 1,000 injuries. September 4: Black and White premieres at Telluride, and Holy Smoke premieres at the Venice Film Festival. September 4 - 11: (TW: flashing lights) "Bailamos" by Enrique Iglesias is now at the top of the Billboard Hot 100 charts for two weeks. Peaking this week are: (TW: ableist slur) "Never Gonna Let You Go" by Faith Evans at #17. (TW: alcoholism, flashing lights) "Out Of My Head" by Fastball at #20. (TW: racial stereotypes) "Hey Leonardo (She Likes Me For Me)" by Blessid Union of Souls at #33. (TW: nudity) "All That I Can Say" by Mary J. Blige at #44. (TW: alcoholism mention) "The Secret of Life" by Faith Hill at #46. "Southern Gul" by Erykah Badu ft. Rahzel at #76. (audio only) September 5: American host and original creator of the show Candid Camera, Allen Funt, passes away. September 5: After the Rain (dir. Takashi Koizumi, scr. Akira Kurosawa) premieres at the Venice Film Festival, and Jesus' Son at Telluride. (article only) September 6: The 3rd President of Nauru, Lagumot Harris, passes away. September 6: Cybersix premieres on Teletoon in Canada, on Fox Kids in the US, on Telefe in Argentina, and on Kids Station in Japan. September 6: PTV is rebranded as PBS Kids, with Dragon Tales premiering on the rebranded network. September 6: Disney's One Too, a spinoff block of Disney's One Saturday Morning on ABC, premieres on UPN, featuring shows such as: Disney's Doug Pepper Ann Recess Sabrina, The Animated Series September 6: Diamonds premieres in theatres, featuring Kirk Douglas, Dan Aykroyd, Jenny McCarthy, Lauren Bacall, and John Landis. September 6: The Wind Will Carry Us (dir. Abbas Kiarostami, Taste of Cherry) premieres at the Venice Film Festival. September 7: (TW: natural disasters) An earthquake strikes near Athens, Greece at 2:56 P.M., causing 143 deaths, and leaving 2,000 injured. September 7: Chinese Cinderella hits bookstores. September 7: For $35.6 billion ($52 billion in 2017 money), Viacom and CBS begin their merger. September 8: American composer, poet, and musician Moondog, passes away. September 8: Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver premieres on PCs in North America. (article only) Also released is: (TW: flashing images) Wipeout 3 (article here) for the PlayStation in Europe, later released to North America on September 30, 1999, and to Japan on February 3, 2000. September 8: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, covering Harry Potter's third year in Hogwarts, hits bookstores in the US, eventualy winning many awards, including a Hugo Award nomination. September 8: American Beauty has its red carpet premiere in Grauman's Theatre in Hollywood, CA, USA. September 9: The Sega Dreamcast, the last of Sega's home consoles, premieres in North America, along with the following games: (TW: natural disasters, flashing lights and images, nudity in profile pic of gameplay video) Sonic Adventure (gameplay here, article here), later released in Europe on October 14, 1999. Mortal Kombat Gold (article only) Hydro Thunder (article here) PenPen TriIcelon (article here), later released to Europe on October 4, 1999. Tokyo Xtreme Racer (article here), later released to PAL regions on October 14, 1999. Ready 2 Rumble Boxing (article only) Here's a series of commercials advertising the console. September 9: (TW: flashing lights and images) Square premieres Final Fantasy VIII (gameplay here, commercial here, article here) for the PlayStation to North American audiences, eventually becoming the number-one selling video game for the PlayStation for three weeks straight. Here's a link to the Appreciation Post for this game. September 9: Early Today premieres on NBC. September 10 - 24: If memory serves me right, Iron Chef (Ironmen of Cooking), has its grand finale with "The King of Iron Chefs" tournament. Here are the four battles: 1st Battle 2nd Battle The King of Iron Chefs Battle Final Battle September 10: Premiering in theatres this week are: India's premiere of 1947: Earth (dir. Deepa Mehta). Rupert Wainwright), featuring Patricia Arquette, Gabriel Byrne, Jonathan Pryce, Nia Long, Enrico Colantoni, and Portia de Rossi. The loose adaptation of Richard Matheson's book Stir of Echoes (dir. The Venice FF premiere of Fight Club. September 11: Detention! premieres on Kids WB. September 11?: A Martin Scorsese documentary, My Voyage To Italy, premieres. September 11: "Bailamos" by Enrique Iglesias is on its last week at the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Also peaking are: "Lost In You" by Garth Brooks as Chris Gaines at #5. (TW: flashing lights, alcohol) "Bliss" by Tori Amos at #91. September 12: The search engine Naver is launched in South Korea. September 12: Under international pressure, Indonesian President B.J. Habibie launches a peacekeeping force into East Timor. September 12: (TW: anti-Roma slur, shaky images, body horror) Mystery Science Theater 3000 (MST3K), which originally premiered on KTMA in Minneapolis, MN, USA, on November 24, 1988, which later moved to Comedy Central, and later to Sci-Fi, ends its original run. September 12: New Waterford Girl and But I'm A Cheerleader premiere in the Toronto Film Festival. September 13: Himalaya (dir. Eric Valli) premieres in US theatres, the first Nepalese film to be nominated for an Oscar, along with the Sundance premiere of The Third Miracle. September 14: Kiribati, Nauru, and Tonga join the United Nations. September 14: American skateboarder Tom Schaar is born. September 14: (TW: smoking in article) English film director Charles Crichton, well known for directing A Fish Called Wanda, and Ealing Studios comedies such as The Lavender Hill Mob, and Hue and Cry passes away. September 14: Marc Anthony's self-titled album premieres, featuring (TW: ableist slur, shaky images, partial nudity) "I Need To Know", "You Sang To Me", "My Baby You", and "Da La Vuelta". September 14: Cabela's Big Game Hunter III premieres on PCs. September 14: Deborah Cox's "We Can't Be Friends" (with R.L. from Next) premieres as a single. September 14: Stephen King's Hearts In Atlantis is released. September 14: Shower premieres at the Toronto Film Festival, along with Wayward Son, featuring Harry Connick, Jr., Pete Postlethwaite, Patricia Clarkson, and Vinessa Shaw. September 15: Goemon's Great Adventure (gameplay here, article here) premieres in North America. Also premiering are: Torneko: The Last Hope (Torneko's Great Adventure 2: Mystery Dungeon) (article here) for the PlayStation in Japan. September 17: (TW: ableist slur, stalking, alcohol, abuse, shootings, nudity) Premiering in theatres this week is the wide release of Sam Mendes's directorial debut film American Beauty (scr. Alan Ball), featuring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Thora Birch, Wes Bentley, Mena Suvari, Chris Cooper, Allison Janney, Peter Gallagher, and John Cho. Reilly, Jena Malone, Vin Scully, Brian Cox, Daniel Dae Kim, and J.K. Simmons. September 19: American songwriter, musician, and producer Ed Cobb passes away. September 19: Judging Amy (opening here) premieres on CBS. September 20: Eminem is sued by his own mother for slander for $10 million. September 20: The following shows premiere: (TW: carnage, mentions of rape, sexual assault) Law and Order: Special Victims Unit (NBC) (TW: bright lights, partial nudity, alcohol) Family Law (CBS) Blind Date (syndication) The return of Family Feud, with Louie Anderson as host (ABC). September 20: Superstation WGN drop Kids WB and The WB programming from their network. (nooooo!) September 21: (TW: natural disasters) At 1:47 A.M. the 921 Earthquake, or the Jiji Earthquake hits Taiwan, causing up to 2,415 deaths, 11,305 injuries, and property damage up to NT$300 billion ($10 billion in US dollars, or $14.6 billion in 2017 money). September 21: Brian McKnight's album Back At One premieres, featuring the single of the same name. September 21: David Bowie's album Hours premieres, becoming the first complete album available to be downloaded from the Internet. September 21: Mariah Carey's "Heartbreaker" (with Jay Z)" premieres as a single. September 21: The Mike O'Malley Show premieres on NBC. September 21: Naruto begins its serialization in Shonen Jump magazine in Japan. September 22: The West Wing* premieres on NBC in the US. September 22: (TW: gore, carnage, body horror/distortion, explosions) Resident Evil 3: Nemesis (Biohazard 3: Last Escape) (article here) premieres in Japan for the PlayStation. Also premiering is: Apocalypse premieres in Japan for the PlayStation. September 22: Premiering in theatres are: The French wide release of The Letter. The Belgian release of Rosetta. Spain's premiere of Human Resources. September 22: American actor George C. Scott (Dr. Strangelove, Patton, A Christmas Carol, Anatomy of a Murder, The Rescuers Down Under) passes away. September 22: (TW: bombings, terrorism) At 8:30 P.M., another apartment bomb is planted in Ryazan, Russia, but the bomb is reported and disarmed. September 23: NASA announces that it has lost contact with the Mars Climate Orbiter, which was launched on December 11, 1998 to study Mars's climate. September 23: In Don Mueang International Airport in Bangkok, Thailand, Qantas Flight 1 accidentally overruns the runway, causing 38 minor injuries and $100 million ($146 million in 2017 money) in aircraft repairs. This incident is considered the worst incident in Qantas's history. September 24: Based on the British series, Cold Feet premieres on NBC, which was cancelled a month later because of low ratings. September 24: Mission Hill premieres on the WB. September 24: If memory serves me right, Iron Chef (Ironmen of Cooking), which premiered on October 10, 1993, ends its run on Fuji TV in Japan. September 24: Timon & Pumbaa, which premiered on syndication on September 8, 1995, ends its run. September 24: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: smoking) The US release of Dog Park (dir. Bruce McCulloch), featuring Luke Wilson, Natasha Henstridge, Janeane Garofalo, Bruce McCulloch, and Peter MacNeill. (TW: smoking, alcohol) The limited release of Guinevere, featuring Sarah Polley, Stephen Rea, Gina Gershon, Emily Procter, Gedde Watanabe, and Sandra Oh. (TW: shootings, flashing lights and images, explosions) The infamous Simon Sez, featuring Dennis Rodman, and Dane Cook. The Hong Kong release of The Truth About Jane and Sam. (article only) Treehouse Hostage, featuring Jim Varney, Joey Zimmerman, and Vincent Schiavelli. Lawrence Kasdan), featuring Hope Davis, Jason Lee, Martin Short, Jason Ritter, Alfre Woodard, Ted Danson, and Zooey Deschanel in her film debut. Spain's release of Butterfly's Tongue. September 25: Suikoden II (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later released in Europe on July 28, 2000, and in China for PCs in 2003. September 25: American writer Marion Zimmer Bradley passes away. September 25: Xyber 9: New Dawn premieres on Fox Kids. September 25: Himitsu (dir. Yojiro Takita) premieres in Japanese theatres. September 26: Vanessa Williams ties the knot with Lakers small forward Rick Fox at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Upper Manhattan, New York, NY, USA. September 26: (TW: mentions of police brutality, murder, racism) Sirens premieres on Showtime. September 27: British singer Gary Barlow, formerly of the boy band Take That, releases his single "For All That You Want". Other singles released are: Macy Gray's "I Try" (TW: alcohol, bright lights) Pet Shop Boys' "New York City Boy" September 28: The hard rock band Creed release their second album Human Clay, featuring (TW: bright lights) "Higher", "What If", and "With Arms Wide Open". September 28: Homeworld (gameplay here, article here) premieres on PCs. Other games released are: (TW: flashing lights) Kingsley's Adventure (article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on October 22, 1999. Gex 3: Deep Cover Gecko (article here) for the Nintendo 64 in North America, later released to Europe on July 24, 2000. September 28: Alvin and the Chipmunks Meet Frankenstein premieres on video. September 28: Kolobos (Haunted House) premieres in theatres. (article only) September 29: (TW: alcoholism mention) Rosetta premieres on French theatres. (article only) September 30: The novel series (and one of my childhood favorites) A Series of Unfortunate Events, by Lemony Snicket (alias of Daniel Handler), is released, starting with The Bad Beginning and The Reptile Room. September 30: The following video games premiere: Grand Theft Auto II for PCs. (article only) Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings (gameplay here, article here) premieres on PCs and Macintosh. (TW: blurred images, flashing lights in intro) CTR: Crash Team Racing (intro here, commercials here and here, article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later to PAL regions on October 20, 1999, and to Australasia on January 9, 2000. (article only) Toy Commander for the Dreamcast in North America, later to Europe on October 14, 1999, and to Japan under the title Toy Ranger on January 6, 2000. (article only) Puzzle Link (article here) for the Neo Geo Pocket Color in North America. This Date In History: October 1999 October ??: (TW: mentions of trauma, PTSD, rape) Laurie Halse Anderson's Speak is released. October ??: Mr. Driller (article here) premieres on arcades, along with San Francisco Rush 2049. (article only) October ??: The short film Judgement (dir. Park Chan-wook) premieres in South Korean theatres. October ??: The last Russian troops withdraw and equipment dismantled from the Baltic states. October 1: Shanghai Pudong International Airport opens in Shanghai, China. October 1: Transformers: Beast Wars Transmetals premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Japan. October 1: Spy Fox 2: Some Assembly Required (article here) premieres on PCs and Macintosh. October 1: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: shootings, explosions) The US release of Three Kings (dir. David O. Russell), featuring George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg, Ice Cube, Spike Jonze, Nora Dunn, Jamie Kennedy, Mykelti Williamson, Cliff Curtis, and Alia Shawkat. (TW: fat shaming) Mystery, Alaska (dir. Jay Roach), featuring Russell Crowe, Hank Azaria, Burt Reynolds, Mary McCormack, Lolita Davidovich, Colm Meaney (O'Brien!), Maury Chaykin, Jason Gray-Stanford (Lt. Disher!), and Mike Myers. Gregg Araki), featuring Kathleen Robertson, and Kelly Macdonald. The Italian release of But Forever In My Mind. October 2: Audition premieres at the Vancouver Film Festival. (article only) October 2: (TW: spiders, flashing lights) Spider-Man Unlimited premieres on Fox Kids. October 2: "Unpretty" by TLC is on its last week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs also peaking are: (TW: smoking, alcohol) "Someday" by Sugar Ray at #7. "Scar Tissue" by Red Hot Chili Peppers at #9. "Ready to Run" by Dixie Chicks at #39. October 3: Japanese businessman and one of the founders of Sony, Akio Morita, passes away. October 3: American actor Aramis Knight (Into The Badlands) is born. October 3: (TW: alcohol, explosions) TV movie based on George Orwell's novel, Animal Farm (I remember watching this in high school!), premieres on TNT. October 3: H-E Double Hockey Sticks, based on the opera Griffelkin, premieres on the Wonderful World of Disney on ABC, featuring Will Friedle, Matthew Lawrence, Gabrielle Union, Rhea Perlman, and Tyler Labine (Hunk!). (article only) October 4: British pop group S Club 7 release their debut album, S Club, featuring "Bring It All Back". October 4: Faith Hill's "Breathe" premieres as a single. October 4: Disciples: Sacred Lands (article here) premieres on PCs. October 4: From the creator of Pepper Ann, Angela Anaconda premieres on Fox Family. October 5: (TW: train collisions) The Ladbroke Grove rail crash occurs, causing 31 deaths, and 520 injuries. October 5: The spinoff series to Buffy: The Vampire Slayer, Angel* premieres on The WB. October 5: (TW: nudity in article pic) Steel Angel Kurumi (article here) premieres on WOWOW in Japan. October 5: Terrestrial Defense Corp. Dai-Guard (article here) premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. October 5: Canadian singer Chantal Kreviazuk's second album Colour Moving and Still premieres. October 5: (TW: flashing lights) Scooby-Doo and the Witch's Ghost premieres on video. October 5: Star Wars: The New Jedi Order - Vector Prime is released. October 5: The Final Fantasy Anthology is released in North America on the PlayStation, which includes the North American debut of Final Fantasy V, and a re-release of Final Fantasy VI. October 6: (TW: bright lights) Roswell premieres on The WB. October 6: (TW: bright lights) Infinite Ryvius (article here) premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. October 7: The anime adaptation of Excel Saga (article here), based on Rikdo Koshi's manga, premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. October 7: House Hunters premieres on HGTV. (article only) October 7: Wasteland premieres on ABC. October 7: The video game adaptation of Xena: Warrior Princess (article here) premieres on the PlayStation. October 7: The Hi-Line premieres at the Austin Film Festival. October 7: (TW: terrorism, bombings, explosions) Final Voyage premieres, featuring Dylan Walsh, Ice-T, and Erika Eleniak, and (TW: ableist slur) the documentary My Best Fiend (dir. Werner Herzog). Kimberly Peirce), featuring Hilary Swank, Chlo√´ Sevigny, and Peter Saarsgard. (TW: plane collisions mention, sexual scenes) Random Hearts (dir. October 9: NASA's SR-71 "Blackbird" aircraft has its last flight before being retired. October 9: TV movie Don't Look Under the Bed premieres on the Disney Channel. October 9: Kiss the Sky premieres in theatres, featuring William Petersen, Gary Cole, Sheryl Lee, and Terence Stamp. (article only) October 9 - 11: The first Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival is held in Coachella, CA, USA. October 9: "Heartbreaker" by Mariah Carey & Jay Z is now on the top of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. The only song peaking this week is: (TW: alcohol) "Angels Would Fall" by Melissa Etheridge at #51. October 10: Blue Gender premieres on TBS in Japan. October 10: The London Eye, or the Millennium Wheel is lifted into place in the South Bank of the Thames in London, England, UK. October 11: Shooting begins on THE LORD OF THE RINGS film trilogy. October 11: (TW: bright, flashing lights, insects, explosions) Rare releases Jet Force Gemini (gameplay here, article here) on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later released to Europe on November 2, 1999. October 12: The six billionth-human is born in Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina. October 12: Pac-Man World (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America. Also premiering is: (TW: bright lights) WWF WrestleMania 2000 (article here) on the Nintendo 64 in Europe, later to North America on October 31, 1999, and to Japan on September 15, 2000. October 12: Harlem Globetrotter, and NBA center whose career included playing for the San Francisco/Philadelphia Warriors, the 76ers, and the Lakers, Wilt Chamberlain, passes away. October 12: (TW: bright, flashing lights, ableist slur) Ricky Martin's "Shake Your Bon-Bon" premieres as a single. October 13: The US Senate rejects the ratification (51-48) of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test Ban Treaty, or the CTBT. October 13: (TW: spinning images) The Big O premieres on WOWOW in Japan. October 13: Bridge of Dragons has its US release, featuring Dolph Lundgren, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, along with the premiere of The Story of Us. (article only) October 14: Square premieres Threads of Fate (Dewprism) (commercial here, article here) on the PlayStation in Japan. October 14: Now and Then, Here and There premieres on WOWOW in Japan. October 15: American actress Bailey Madison is born. October 15: A National Geographic press conference announces the discovery of an Archaeoraptor from China, which later turned out to be a forgery made up from several real fossils. October 15: (TW: assault, smoking, gore, explosions, shootings, car collisions) The film adaptation of Chuck Palahniuk's novel Fight Club (dir. David Fincher, which one does not talk about!), premieres widely in theatres, featuring Edward Norton, Brad Pitt as Tyler Durden, Helena Bonham Carter, Meat Loaf, and Jared Leto. Rob Reiner), featuring Bruce Willis, Michelle Pfeiffer, Rita Wilson, Rob Reiner, Julie Hagerty, Tim Matheson, Red Buttons, and Betty White. October 17: Greek American physicist and mathematician Nicholas Metropolis passes away. October 18: The Messenger: The Story of Joan Arc has its US limited premiere, later released in France on October 27, 1999, along with (TW: alcoholism, car collisions, implied rape, flashing lights) Body Shots, featuring Sean Patrick Flanery, Jerry O'Connell, Tara Reid, and Emily Procter. October 24: Sim Theme Park (Theme Park World) (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, and to PCs in North America on October 31, 1999. October 25 - November 1: (TW: natural disasters) The Odisha cyclone, the strongest cyclone on record, is formed in the Andaman Sea. October 25: (TW: flashing lights) Phil Collins's "Strangers Like Me" from Disney's Tarzan premieres as a single. October 26: Grandia (trailer here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America. Also premiering is: Revenant (article here) for PCs in North America and Europe. October 26: Norwegian duo M2M's single "Don't Say You Love Me", featured from the Pok√©mon: The First Movie soundtrack, premieres. October 26: The House of Lords (221-81) pass a bill ending the practice of hereditary peers in the House of Lords. However, as a compromise, only 92 hereditary peers were allowed. October 27: (TW: terrorism, shootings) At 5:15 p.m., gunmen open fire in the Armanian Parliament in the captial city Yerevan, Armenia, assassinating the Prime Minister, the Parliament Speaker, and six others. October 28: Tomba! 2: The Evil Swine Return (Tomba! The Wild Adventures) (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. Also premiering for the PlayStation in Japan are: (TW: nudity, explosions, body horror/distortion, carnage) Baroque (article here) (TW: flashing lights, explosions) Silent Bomber (article here) October 29: (TW: natural disasters) The Odisha cyclone makes landfall, with wind speeds peaking up to 160 mph (260 kph), leading to around 10,000 deaths, and $4.44 billion ($6.43 billion in 2017 money) in property damages. October 29: Rayman 2: The Great Escape (another childhood favorite! :D , commercial here, article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in Europe, later localized to North America two days later. This game is later released on many different consoles. Other video games premiering are: (TW: flashing lights) Arc the Lad III (article here) for the PlayStation in Japan. Dino Crisis for the PlayStation in Europe. Super Robot Wars 64 for the Nintendo 64 in Japan. Donal Lardner Ward), featuring Jennifer Love Hewitt, Donal Lardner Ward, Amy Brenneman, Craig Bierko, Will Ferrell, Ben Stiller, and Robert Loggia. (TW: drugs mention, alcohol, anti-Irish slurs) "Cowboy" by Kid Rock at #82. October 31: The Roman Catholic and Lutheran churches sign a doctrine ending a centuries-old debate on the nature of faith and salvation. (Doctrine here) October 31: Australian sailor Jesse Martin returns to Melbourne, Australia after a nonstop, unassisted round-the-world trip on a yacht, becoming the youngest to circumnavigate the world in a yacht. October 31: (TW: plane collisions) EgyptAir Flight 990 boarded for Cairo, Egypt, from New York, NY, USA, crashes in the Atlantic off the coast near Nantucket, MA, USA, causing all 217 deaths of crew and passengers. November 1: C√©line Dion's "That's The Way It Is" premieres as a single, along with (TW: flashing lights and images) Jennifer Lopez's "Waiting For Tonight". November 1: The Early Show premieres on CBS. November 1: (TW: shootings, flashing images) Bangkok Dangerous (dir. The Pang Bros.) premieres in Thai theatres. A remake of this movie is later released in 2008, featuring Nicolas Cage. November 2: LFO's "Girl On TV" premieres as a single. November 5: Vocalist Gary Cherone, formerly of Extreme, leaves Van Halen after three years of being with the band. November 5: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: burglary) The UK premiere of Christopher Nolan's debut film Following. November 6: Shower has its premiere in Chinese theatres. (article only) November 6: "Smooth" by Santana and Rob Thomas is on its third week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100. November 7: The TV movie Annie premieres on ABC's The Wonderful World of Disney block. November 7 - 8: Two movies premiere: The documentary Not For Ourselves Alone (dir. Ken Burns), about the women's suffrage movement in the United States. (article only) The TV movie The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns, featuring Randy Quaid, Colm Meaney (O'Brien!), Zo√´ Wanamaker, Kieran Culkin, Kevin McKidd, and Whoopi Goldberg. (article only) November 7: Destiny's Child's "Say My Name" is released as a single. November 8: The World Is Not Enough has its red carpet premiere. November 9: (TW: plane collisions) In Uruapan International Airport, TAESA Flight 725, boarding for Mexico City, Mexico, crashes a few minutes after takeoff, causing 18 deaths of all crew and passengers. November 9: Faith Hill's album Breathe is released, featuring the single of the "Breathe", (TW: ableist slur) "The Way You Love Me", and "If My Heart Had Wings", along with Savage Garden's final album Affirmation, featuring (TW: ableist slur) "The Animal Song", (TW: ableist slur) "I Knew I Loved You", and "The Best Thing". November 9: Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head To Your Feet (article here) premieres on PCs in Canada. November 9: Herod's Law (La Ley de Herodes) premieres in Mexico. November 9: Mickey's Once Upon A Christmas and Passport To Paris, featuring the Olsen Twins, premiere on video. November 10: American actress Kiernan Shipka (Jinora in The Legend of Korra, Sally Draper in M*d Men) is born. November 10: The Diet of Japan, or Japan's Parliament, holds its first Question Time session, where Diet members ask the Prime Minister questions during a session, which was taken from the UK Parliament's Question Time model. November 10: (TW: gore, carnage, war scenes) Resident Evil 3 (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on March 17, 2000. Also premiering are: Cool Boarders 4 (article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on February 25, 2000, and to Japan on March 4, 2000. Rippin' Riders Snowboarding (Cool Boarders Burrrn) (article here) for the Dreamcast in North America, later released to PAL regions on November 15, 1999. November 10: Pok√©mon: The First Movie (Mewtwo Strikes Back) has its limited release in North American theatres. November 10: (TW: flashing images) Light It Up premieres in theatres, featuring Usher, Robert Richard, Forest Whitaker, Rosario Dawson, Sara Gilbert, Clifton Collins, Jr., Vanessa Williams, and Judd Nelson. November 11: American voice actress Mary Kay Bergman, which her credits include Dr. Blight in Captain Planet and the Planeteers, Beauty and the Beast, The Fairly Oddparents, South Park, and many others, passes away. November 19: Shenzhou 1, China's first unmanned spacecraft, has lifted off. Gonz√°lez and two others float at sea until fishermen spot them and hand the three survivors over to the U.S. Coast Guard. Laz√°ro, along with other Cuban Americans, decide that Eli√°n should stay in Miami. This Date In History: January 2000 (happy Y2K!) January 1: Disney's 38th animated feature, Fantasia 2000 has its IMAX-only release. January 1: Prince performs "1999" live at Times Square, New York City, NY, USA. January 1: Gisborne, New Zealand, is the first major city to see the first sunrise of the new millennium. January 1: Pope John Paul II opens the holy doors of the Basilica of St. Mary Major to celebrate the new millenium. January 1: The musical piece Longplayer begins, meant to play until December 31, 2999. January 6: The Pyrenean ibex species, or the bucardo, becomes extinct after a falling tree kills Celia, the last ibex. January 7: Former UK Cabinet Minister Jonathan Aitken is released from prison after serving 9 months out of an 18-month sentence. January 8: American actress Noah Cyrus is born. January 14: (TW: genocide mention, Islamophobia) The United Nations holds a tribunal, where they sentence five Bosnian Croats to 25 years in prison for the murder of over 100 Muslims in Bosnia in 1993. February 21: Canadian composer, music teacher, pianist, and organist, Violet Archer, passes away. February 21: UNESCO celebrates the first International Mother Language Day. February 21: David Letterman returns to work after his heart surgery, and introduces the doctors who performed on him on stage. February 22: Spiral: The Bonds of Reasoning (one of my favorites yay!) starts its serialization in the Enix-owned (now Square-Enix-owned) magazine Monthly Shonen GanGan in Japan. February 22: M2M's "Mirror Mirror" is released as a single in the US. February 22: Aaliyah's "Try Again", from the movie Romeo Must Die, premieres as a single. February 23: (TW: explosions, fire, war scenes) Army Men: Sarge's Heroes (commercial here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America. February 23: (TW: murder) The TV miniseries Perfect Murder, Perfect Town premieres, featuring Ann-Margret, Marg Helgenberger, and Kris Kristofferson. February 23: The 42nd Grammy Awards takes place in the Staples Center in Los Angeles, CA, USA, where Santana wins eight Grammy Awards (including the Album of the Year), tying Michael Jackson's win of eight awards, and Christina Aguilera wins the Best New Artist award. February 24: Enrique Iglesias's "Be With You" premieres as a single. (audio only) February 24: Electronic Arts announces their acquisition of DreamWorks Interactive. February 24: (TW: blurred images, mentions of death, gore) Fear Effect (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later released to Europe on August 3, 2000. Also released are: Strider 2 for the PlayStation in Japan. (article only) AeroWings 2: Airstrike (Aero Dancing F) (article here) and The Lost Golem (article only) for the Sega Dreamcast in Japan. February 25: Visual novel Phantom of Inferno premieres on PCs in Japan. February 25: (TW: smoking, shootings, alcohol) Wonder Boys (I remember my English teacher in high school had this poster in his classroom! Dir. Curtis Hanson, LA Confidential, scr. Steve Kloves), featuring Michael Douglas, Tobey Maguire, Frances McDormand, Katie Holmes, Rip Torn, and Robert Downey Jr., premieres in theatres. Also premiering this week in theatres are: (TW: ableist slur, explosions, shootings, smoking) Reindeer Games (dir. John Frankenheimer, scr. Ehren Kruger), featuring Ben Affleck, Gary Sinise, Charlize Theron, Dennis Farina, Isaac Hayes, Ashton Kutcher, and Danny Trejo. The US release of Not of This World (Fuori Dal Mondo) (article only) February 26: Two new shows premiere: (TW: flashing lights) Max Steel on Kids WB, the first CGI animated TV series for the network block. The Weekenders on ABC for Disney's One Saturday Morning block. February 26: The Avengers: United They Stand, which premiered on October 30, 1999, ends its run on Fox Kids. February 26: Charisma (dir. Kiyoshi Kurosawa) has its Japanese premiere. (article only) February 26: "I Knew I Loved You" by Savage Garden returns to the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100 for this week only. (TW: spinning images) "Back At One" by Mark Wills at #36. February 28: AC/DC release their album Stiff Upper Lip. February 29: A rare century leap year occurs, which will not occur again until 2400. February 29: An Extremely Goofy Movie premieres on video. February 29: (TW: ableist slur) Faith Hill's "The Way You Love Me" is released as a single. March 1: The rewritten Constitution of Finland takes effect. March 1: (TW: gore) Deception III: Dark Delusion (gameplay here, article here) premieres for the PlayStation in North America. Also premiering is: (TW: flashing lights) Battlezone: Rise of the Black Dogs (article here) for the Nintendo 64 in North America. March 1: fXM: Movies is renamed Fox Movie Channel. DJ Pooh) premieres in theatres, featuring Brian Hooks, Faizon Love, David Alan Grier, DJ Pooh, Meagan Good, Mo'Nique, and Vincent Schiavelli, with cameos from Anthony Anderson, and Mike Epps. March 2: Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet returns to his home in Chile (booo!) after the UK Parliament rejects Spain's request for his extradition. March 3: Madonna's cover of Don McLean's "American Pie" premieres as a single. March 3: Ghost Dog: Way of the Samurai has its red carpet premiere. March 3: The following films premiere this week: (TW: smoking) The wide release of My Dog Skip, featuring Frankie Muniz, Diane Lane, Kevin Bacon, Luke Wilson, Cody Linley, Caitlin Wachs, Clint Howard, and Harry Connick, Jr. (TW: flashing images, torture, dismemberment) The Japanese release of Audition (Odishon) (dir. Takashi Miike). Mike Nichols, The Graduate), featuring Garry Shandling, Annette Bening, Greg Kinnear, Ben Kingsley, Linda Fiorentino, John Goodman, Judy Greer, Richard Jenkins, Camryn Manheim, and Phill Lewis. Anjelica Huston), featuring Anjelica Huston, Ray Winstone, and Tom Jones. March 4: The PlayStation 2 is released in Japan, launching with the following games: (TW: objectification of women) Ridge Racer V (article here) Street Fighter X3 (article only) Drum Mania (article only) Kessen (article only) (TW: bright, flashing lights, gore) Eternal Ring (article here) March 4 - 11: "Amazed" by Lonestar is now peaking at the top of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs also peaking this week are: "That's The Way It Is" by C√©line Dion at #6. "American Pie" by Madonna at #29. "I Don't Wanna" (from the film Next Friday) by Aaliyah at #35. March 5: TV movie Life-Size premieres on the ABC's Wonderful World of Disney block, featuring Lindsay Lohan, and Tyra Banks. March 5: If These Walls Could Talk 2 (dirs. Jane Anderson, Martha Coolidge, Anne Heche) premieres on HBO. March 5: Flint the Time Detective premieres on Fox Kids in the US. March 6: (TW: car collisions) Foxy Brown crashes her car in Brooklyn, NY, USA, and is hospitalized. She is found by the police to have a suspended driver's license. March 6: Canadian stage actor John Colicos, memorable for his role as Klingon Commander, later Dahar Master Kor in Star Trek: The Original Series, and Deep Space Nine, along with his role as Count Baltar in the original Battlestar Galactica, and three episodes in Mission: Impossible, and in plays such as Trollus and Cressida, and King Lear, passes away. March 6: (TW: shootings, bright lights) Mobile Suit Gundam Wing (New Mobile Report Gundam Wing), which premiered in Japan on TV Asahi on April 7, 1995 and ended on March 29, 1996, premieres in the US on Cartoon Network's Toonami block. March 7: British actor Charles Gray, notable for being in two Bond movies, as Henderson in You Only Live Twice, and Blofeld in Diamonds Are Forever, as well as the Criminologist in The Rocky Horror Picture Show, along with many other roles, passes away. March 7: A-Teens' single, "Dancing Queen", is released, featuring Paul Gleason in the music video. March 7: English evolutionary biologist W.D. Hamilton passes away. March 7: ChuChu Rocket! (article here) premieres on the Sega Dreamcast in North America, later released to Europe on June 9, 2000. March 7: Secret Agent Man premieres on UPN. March 8: (TW: train collisions) In Meguro, Tokyo, Japan, at around 9:00 A.M., near the Naka-Meguro station, the Naka-Meguro train disaster occurs, leading to 5 deaths, and 63 injuries. March 8 - 12: The 7th annual Game Developers Conference, or the GDC, along with the Independent Games Festival, take place in San Jose, CA, USA, where Bill Gates announces the XBox's arrival. March 9: Art forger Ely Sakhai is arrested by the FBI in New York City, NY, USA. March 9: M2M's album Shades of Purple is released. March 9: Protective gloves are offered by Nintendo to US audiences after people have reported injuries while playing Mario Party. March 9: FantaVision (article here) premieres for the PS2 in Japan. March 9: Born Romantic premieres in UK theatres. March 9: Ecuador signs into law the use of the US dollar as its official currency, replacing the Ecuadorian sucre. March 10: American actress Judith Barrett passes away. March 10: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: war, nuclear weapons mention) Deterrence (dir. Rod Lurie in his debut), featuring Kevin Pollak, Timothy Hutton, Sheryl Lee Ralph, Sean Astin, and Mark Thompson with his awesome voice. (TW: bright lights, explosions) Mission to Mars (dir. Brian de Palma), featuring Gary Sinise, Tim Robbins, Don Cheadle, Connie Nielsen, and Armin Mueller-Stahl. The US release of The Ninth Gate, featuring Johnny Depp, Lena Olin, and Frank Langella. March 11: 311 hold their first 3-11 Day concert near Tower Records in the French Quarter in New Orleans, LA, USA. Get Up" by Amel Larrieux at #97. (audio only) March 12: Pope John Paul II apologizes for the sins committed by the Roman Catholic Church throughout the ages. March 12: A Zenit-3SL rocket launching from Christmas Island carrying a mobile communications satellite fails to make it to its destination due to a bug in its software. March 12: TV movie Model Behavior premieres on ABC's The Wonderful World of Disney, featuring Maggie Lawson (Jules!), Justin Timberlake, Daniel Clark, Kathie Lee Gifford, and Ann Turnbull. March 13: Blink-182 ends its European concert tour early after two band members, Tom DeLonge, and Travis Barker, come down with strep throat. March 14: The world's first wide e-book publication, Stephen King's Riding the Bullet, is published. John Landis) premieres on video, featuring Nastassja Kinski, Dan Aykroyd, Billy Zane, Rob Schneider, Thomas Haden Church, Michael Biehn, and Lisa Edelstein. March 18: The TV movie Alley Cats Strike! premieres on the Disney Channel, featuring Robert Ri'chard, Kyle Schmid, and Kaley Cuoco. March 18: After being banned by Stanley Kubrick after its initial release, A Clockwork Orange premieres on Channel 4 in the UK. March 18 - April 1: "Say My Name" by Destiny's Child is now at the top of the Billboard Hot 100 for three weeks. Songs peaking are: "Show Me The Meaning of Being Lonely" by at #6. "Left, Right, Left" by Drama at #73. March 21 - 26: Pope John Paul II travels to Israel, becoming the first pontiff to do so. March 21: A new class of composite material is created by physicists in the University of San Diego, CA, USA, with physical properties never seen before in either man-made or natural materials. March 21: (TW: drugs mention) The Supreme Court rules that the FDA lacks authority to regulate tobacco as an addictive drug. March 26: The 72nd Academy Awards are hosted for the seventh time by Billy Crystal and broadcast by ABC at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, CA, USA. The following Oscars are given to: Best Picture: American Beauty Best Director: Sam Mendes (American Beauty) Best Actor: Kevin Spacey (American Beauty) Best Actress: Hilary Swank (Boys Don't Cry) Best Supporting Actor: Michael Caine (The Cider House Rules) Best Supporting Actress: Angelina Jolie (Girl, Interrupted) Best Original Screenplay: Alan Ball (Shakespeare In Love) Best Adapted Screenplay: John Irving (The Cider House Rules) (TW: flashing lights, and images in music video) Best Original Song and Score: Phil Collins ("You'll Be In My Heart", Disney's Tarzan) Best Foreign Language Film: Pedro Almod√≥var (All About My Mother) Best Visual Effects and Sound Effects Editing: The Matrix (TW: adultism, one person has a tape in mouth) Here's Robin Williams's performance of "Blame Canada". March 26: Digimon Adventure ends its run on Fuji TV in Japan. March 26: The 2000 Russian Presidential elections take place, where Vladimir Putin is elected President of Russia. March 26: The Seattle Kingdome is demolished. March 27: Britney Spears's "Oops! ...I Did It Again" premieres as a single. March 27: (TW: fire, explosions) The Phillips explosion occurs, where one is killed, and 71 are injured in Pasadena, TX, USA. March 27: NSYNC's album, No Strings Attached, sells a record 2.4 million copies on its first week. March 28: Former Led Zeppelin guitarist Jimmy Page wins a libel lawsuit against Ministry magazine. The magazine offers to pay off Page's legal bills, and Page donates the lawsuit money to the Action for Brazil's Children Trust. March 28: (TW: natural disasters) A tornado hits Fort Worth, TX, USA, leaving 2 dead, 80 injured, and $450 million ($637 million in 2017 money) in property damages. March 28: UFO Baby (Daa! Daa! Daa!) premieres on NHK-BS2 in Japan. (article only) March 28: Dai-Guard, which premiered on TV Tokyo in Japan on October 5, 1999, ends its run. Speed Punks (article here) for the PlayStation in North America. This Date In History: April 2000 April ??: Nintendo announces that it has sold its 100 millionth Game Boy. April 1: (TW: anti-Latinx racism mention) While opening for Kiss in their Farewell Tour concert, Ted Nugent (boooo!) makes anti-Latinx remarks, and is banned from the Cynthia Woods Mitchell Pavilion in The Woodlands, TX, USA. (article only) April 13: Metallica sues Napster, Yale, the University of Southern California, and the University of Indiana for copyright infringement. Yale and U of Indiana are dropped from the lawsuit after banning Napster on their campuses. April 14: The PlayStation 2 has export restrictions imposed on it by the Trade Ministry of Japan since its technology is powerful enough to control missiles. April 14: American computer programmer, known for his work on data compression, and his invention of the compressed .ZIP file format, Phil Katz, passes away at the age of 37. April 14: (TW: bright lights, war scenes) Banner of the Stars (article here), the sequel series to Crest of the Stars, premieres on WOWOW in Japan. April 14: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: murder, gore, alcohol, smoking, objectification of women, nudity, explosions, ableism) The wide release of the film adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's novel, American P****o (dir. Martian Gothic: Unification for PCs in North America. (article only) This Date In History: May 2000 May 1: The first celebrity edition of the UK version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? premieres. May 1: The pay-per-view service ONrequest begins launching in the UK. May 1: President Clinton announces the removal of Selective Availability, giving more accurate GPS access for civilian use. May 1: Gladiator has its red carpet premiere. May 2: (TW: bright lights, ableist slur, explosions, shaky images) Colony Wars: Red Sun (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America. May 2: Princess Margriet of the Netherlands unveils the original Man with Two Hats sculpture near Het Loo Palace, Apeldoorn, NL, to honor Canadian WWII veterans. Here's more information about the statue. May 3: The first geocaching event takes place, where the first cache is placed and the location is posted on Usenet. May 3: Party of Five, which premiered on Fox on September 12, 1994, airs its series finale. May 3: The San Antonio-based computer company Datapoint files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. May 3: Company Man premieres in French theatres. May 4: Another James Bond novel, DoubleShot, is published. May 4: An appeals court overturns a federal court ruling where another emulation software company, bleem!, could not use screenshots for PS1 games, or any intellectual property from Sony, to advertise their product. May 4: The first Mayor of London, "Red" Ken Livingstone, is elected. May 5: Boy Meets World, which premiered on September 24, 1993 on ABC, has its series finale. May 5: The Sun, Mercury, Venus, Earth, the Moon, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn align. May 5: Rod Stewart undergoes throat surgery in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, CA, USA. May 5: Brigandine: Grand Edition (article here) premieres for the PlayStation in Japan. May 5: (TW: slavery mention) Gladiator (dir. Ridley Scott) has its US wide release in theatres this week, featuring Russell Crowe as Maximus Decimus Meridius (I got the name right! Yesss!), Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus, Connie Nielsen, Derek Jacobi, Djimon Hounsou, Spencer Treat Clark, Sven-Ole Thorsen, Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius, and Oliver Reed in his final film role. This film would go on to make $34.8 million in its opening weekend, reaching the top spot for the box office this week, and would go on to gross $457 million total. Also premiering this week are: (TW: abandonment mention) The US wide release of The Hi-Line, featuring Rachael Leigh Cook, Tantoo Cardinal, Ryan Alosio, and Margot Kidder. (TW: snakes) I Dreamed of Africa (dir. Hugh Hudson, Chariots of Fire), featuring Kim Basinger, Eva Marie Saint, Vincent Perez, Liam Aiken, and Daniel Craig. The documentary Michael Jordan to the Max. The Indian release of Chal Mere Bhai. (article only) The film adaptation of the Maugham novel, Up At the Villa, featuring Kristin Scott Thomas, Sean Penn, Anne Bancroft, James Fox, and Derek Jacobi. May 6: John Mellencamp receives an honorary Doctor of Musical Arts degree, and delivers a commencement speech at Indiana University. May 24: An E. coli outbreak occurs in Walkerton, Ontario, Canada, where the water supply of the town is contaminated with the virus, leading to seven deaths, and thousands falling ill. May 24: Israel begins to withdraw its troops from South Lebanon, after 22 years of occupation. May 25: A Canadian World War I soldier's body is moved from its burial spot in Vimy Ridge, laying in state for three days in the Hall of Honour in Parliament Hill. Three days later, the soldier's body is moved into the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Ottawa, Canada. (article only) (TW: shootings, smoking, partial nudity, ableist slur) The Replacements (dir. Howard Deutch), featuring Keanu Reeves, Gene Hackman, Jack Warden, Brett Cullen, Jon Favreau, Orlando Jones, Faizon Love, with John Madden, and Pat Summerall. August 12: The Russian submarine Kursk (K-141) sinks in the Barents Sea, with all 118 crewmembers on deck perishing with it. August 12: American actress and singer Loretta Young (The Farmer's Daughter, The Call of the Wild, The Bishop's Wife, The Loretta Young Show) passes away. August 12: Nicholas Markowitz's body is found near the Lizard's Mouth Trail in the Santa Ynez Mountains in Goleta, CA, USA. August 12: Bloody Beach premieres in South Korean theatres. August 12 - 19: "Incomplete" by Sisq√≥ is now on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Songs peaking are: "I Need You" by LeAnn Rimes at #11. "I Think I'm In Love With You" by Jessica Simpson at #21. "I Wanna Be With You" by Mandy Moore at #24. "What Chu Like" by Da B**t ft. Tyrese at #26. "I Will Love Again" by Lara Fabian at #32. "Prayin' For Daylight" by Rascal Flatts at #38. "Flowers on the Wall" by Eric Heatherly at #50. "West Side Story" by LFO at #84. August 14 - 17: (TW: riots mention) The 2000 Democratic National Convention takes place in the Staples Center in Los Angeles, CA, USA. Protests took place outside the convention, which included a concert by Rage Against the Machine, protesting against the two-party system. August 14: The Weakest Link premieres on BBC2 in the UK. August 14: Dora the Explorer premieres on Nick Jr. in the US. (article only) August 14: Beyond the Pale premieres in Ireland. August 15: Chrono Cross (intro here, commercial here, article here) is released in North America for the PlayStation. August 17: Green Day's "Minority" premieres as a single. August 18: (TW: anti-Black racism) The federal court jury finds the EPA guilty of racial discrimination against EPA policy analyst Marsha Coleman-Adebayo after she filed complaints of the United States mining vanadium and causing environmental damage in South Africa. August 18: The TV movie Quints premieres on the Disney Channel, featuring Kimberly J. Brown, Shadia Simmons, Jake Epstein, and Don Knotts. Tarsem Singh in his director debut), featuring Jennifer Lopez, Vince Vaughn, Vincent D'Onofrio, Jake Weber, Dean Norris, and Pruitt Taylor Vince. "Treat Her Like A Lady" by Joe at #63. "Imagine That" by LL Cool J at #98. August 20: After many debates, Czar Nicholas II and his family are canonized as saints by the Orthodox Church. August 20: Tiger Woods wins the 2000 PGA Championship, his third major championship, becoming the second golfer to win three championships in one season. August 21: Zambian prime minister Daniel Lisulo passes away. August 22: (TW: alcohol) LeAnn Rimes's "Can't Fight the Moonlight" from the film Coyote Ugly, premieres as a single. August 22: American pro wrestler, boxer, actor, football player, and martial artist Charlie J. Kalani, Jr., aka Professor Toru Tanaka (The A-Team, Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, The Running Man, Dark Man, 3 Ninjas, Last Action Hero, 3 W-2 L), passes away. August 23: The Republic of Nicaragua becomes part of the Berne Convention Treaty. August 23: (TW: plane collisions) Gulf Air Flight 072, attempting and failing to land in Bahrain International Airport, crashes near the Persian Gulf near Manama, Bahrain, causing the deaths of all 8 crewmembers and 143 passengers. August 23: (TW: flashing lights) Power Stone 2 (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the Dreamcast in North America, and released to Europe a day later. August 23: The following films premiere: The UK release of Guy Ritchie's second film, snatch. The Edinburgh Film Festival premiere of Beautiful Creatures. August 24: Nintendo unveils their next-generation console, the Nintendo GameCube. August 24: Argon hydrofluoride (ArHF), the first argon compound, is discovered in the University of Helsinki, Finland. August 24: (TW: war scenes) Age of Empires II: The Conquerors (I remember playing this one! Article here), the expansion pack to Age of Empires II, premieres on PCs and Macintosh. August 24: Patrick Stewart weds film producer Wendy Neuss. August 25: (TW: gore, flashing lights) Terracon (article here) premieres for the PlayStation in Europe. A North American release was planned, but cancelled. August 25: American comics artist, and painter Carl Barks, known as "The Duck Man" for his Donald Duck comics, for being the creator of Scrooge McDuck, and for being one of the first three inductees in the Will Eisner Hall of Fame, passes away. "Baby U Are" by Gerald Levert at #89. August 27: (TW: fire) The Ostankino Tower in Moscow, Russia, is set ablaze, causing four deaths (three firefighters, one lift operator). This Date In History: September 2000 September 1: Tokyo Xtreme Racer 2 (article here) premieres on the Dreamcast in North America, later to Europe on December 22, 2000. September 1: Son of the Shadows by Juliet Marillier is published. September 1: Premiering this week in theatres are: Wildflowers, featuring Clea DuVall, Daryl Hannah, Eric Roberts, and Irene Bedard. (TW: smoking, drugs mention) The US wide release of Saving Grace, featuring Brenda Blethyn, Craig Ferguson, Martin Clunes, and Bill Bailey. (TW: fire, explosions, flashing lights) Highlander: Endgame, featuring Adrian Paul, Christopher Lambert, Bruce Payne, Lisa Barbuscia, Donnie Yen, and Jim Byrnes. Whipped, featuring Amanda Peet, and Bridget Moynahan. (article only) The Venice Film Festival premiere of Comedy of Innocence. September 2: Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin is published. September 2: The Day I Became A Woman premieres at the Venice Film Festival. September 2: The Bugs Bunny Show ends its 40-year run. September 2: "Doesn't Really Matter" by Janet Jackson is on its second week on the top spot of the Billboard Hot 100. Peaking this week are: (TW: sexual innuendo) "No More" by Ruff Endz at #5. "Callin' Me" by Lil' Zane ft. 11 at #21. "Just Be A Man About It" by Toni Braxton at #32. "It Must Be Love" by Alan Jackson at #37. "One Voice" by Billy Gilman at #38. "Kernkraft 400" by Zombie Nation at #99. September 4: Destiny's Child's (TW: explosions, one character has their mouth taped, fire) "Independent Women, Pt. 1", from the film Charlie's Angels, and Aaron Carter's cover version of "I Want Candy" premiere as singles. (PBS Kids) Judge Hatchett (syndication, article only) September 5: Evan and Jaron's debut self-titled album premieres. September 5: (TW: flashing images, mentions of depression, suicide) Blink-182's "Adam's Song", and American girl group Dream's debut "He Loves U Not" premiere as singles. September 5: The Haverstraw-Ossining Ferry has its maiden voyage. September 5: Tuvalu joins the United Nations. September 5: Christopher Nolan's second film Memento premieres at the Venice Film Festival. September 6 - 8: The UN holds the Millennium Summit in New York, NY, USA, where the delegation adopts the Millennium Declaration. and passed. September 7 - 14: Fuel protests take place in the UK, ceasing petrol production and supply during this time. September 7: Eminem's "The Way I Am" premieres as a single. September 10: Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Cats, which premiered on October 7, 1982, closes on Broadway after its 7,485th show. September 13: At the Apple Paris Expo in Porte de Versailles, Paris, France, Steve Jobs announces the public beta for Mac OS X, codenamed Kodiak, for $29.95. September 16: Ukranian journalist Georgiy Gongadze disappears. September 16: Sammy Sosa becomes the second person to hit over 50 home runs in three back-to-back seasons. September 16: Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori calls for snap elections, though he will not run for re-election. September 17: American cyclist Nicole Reinhart passes away at the age of 24. September 17: Crimson Skies (gameplay here, article here) premieres on PCs in North America, later to Europe on October 13, 2000. September 18: Madonna's album Music is released. September 18: (TW: mentions of self-harm, suicide) Papa Roach's "Last Resort" premieres as a single. September 18: Gate Keepers, which premiered on April 3, 2000, ends its run on WOWOW in Japan. September 19: The Mizuho Holdings, Inc. is formed by the merger of Fuji Bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, and the Industrial Bank of Japan. September 19: Typhoon Saomai (Ph. name Osang) begins to dissipate around Russia. September 19: P!nk's "Most Girls" premieres as a single. September 19: American character actress Ann Doran (Rebel Without A Cause, Leave It To Beaver, McHale's Navy, M*A*S*H) passes away. September 19: Ken Griffey, Jr. makes his 400th home run. September 19: Disney's The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea premieres on video. September 20: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later to Europe on September 29, 2000, and to Japan on March 8, 2001. September 20: The RSA cryptograph algorithm patent expires, though the algorithm was released to public domain two weeks earlier, on September 6, 2000. September 20: (TW: terrorism) The MI6 building is attacked by a Mark-22 anti-tank missile 300 meters away in Vauxhall, London, England, UK. September 21: Genso Suikogaiden: Swordsman of Harmonia (article here, Suikoden wiki article here) premieres on the PlayStation in Japan. October 1: American pianist and songwriter Robert Allen passes away. October 1: Stunt Racer 64 (article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America. October 1: The Eyes of Tammy Faye premieres. October 2: The following shows premiere: (TW: bright lights, explosions) Gene Roddenberry's Andromeda (syndication) Pelswick (Nickelodeon) Buzz Lightyear of Star Command (UPN, later Toon Disney) Yes, Dear (My brother watched this show a lot! Second opening here) (CBS) Street Smarts (article only) (GSN) Tucker (NBC), ending on October 23, 2000. Descendants of Darkness (WOWOW, Japan) October 2: A new pricing game, Triple Play, is introduced in The Price Is Right, where the winning prizes are three new cars! October 3: Bassist and singer for The Cars, Benjamin Orr, passes away. October 3: (TW: bright lights) Matchbox Twenty's "If You're Gone" premieres as a single. October 3: Two shows premiere in Japan: (TW: bright, flashing lights, explosions) Vandread (article here) (WOWOW) (TW: gore) The anime adaptation of the long-running boxing manga Hajime no Ippo (article here) (NTV) October 3: (TW: food, flashing lights) Scooby-Doo and the Alien Invaders premieres on video. October 3: (TW: flashing images, explosions, sexist slur) Dark Angel premieres on Fox, co-created by James Cameron. October 3: The TV movie Cutaway premieres, . October 4: Primetime soap opera Titans premieres on NBC, ending on December 18, 2000. October 4: British Canadian biochemist, and Nobel Prize winner Michael Smith passes away. October 6: The last original Mini car is produced. October 6: (TW: ableist slur) Evan and Jaron's "C***y For This Girl" premieres as a single. October 6: (TW: flashing lights and images in intro, suicide mention, carnage) CSI: Crime Scene Investigation premieres on CBS. Here's some scenes from the pilot episode. October 6: Argento Soma (article here) premieres on TV Tokyo in Japan. October 6: (TW: suicide mention) American actor and stuntman Richard Farnsworth (The Grey Fox, uncredited roles in Gone With the Wind, and The Wild One, along with Spartacus, Papillon, Bonanza, Little House on the Prairie, Anne of Green Gables, Misery, The Two Jakes, Lassie, The Straight Story) passes away. October 6: Blue's Big Musical Movie premieres on video. October 6: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: explosions) Digimon: The Movie (TW: ableist slur) Meet the Parents (dir. Jay Roach, Austin Powers film series, prod. Robert De Niro), featuring Ben Stiller, Robert De Niro, Teri Polo, Blythe Danner, James Rebhorn, Jon Abrahams, and Owen Wilson. (TW: bright, flashing lights, spinning images) The limited release of Bootmen, featuring Sam Worthington. October 7: The last football match at the old Wembley Stadium takes place, which is a qualifying match between England and Germany for the 2002 World Cup, before the stadium is officially closed down. October 7: The following shows premiere: (TW: flashing images) Noah Knows Best (Nickelodeon) The District (CBS) (TW: explosions) Queen of Swords (syndication) October 7: "Music" by Madonna is on its last week on the top of the Billboard Hot 100 charts. Songs peaking are: "Bag Lady" by Erykah Badu at #6. "Don't Think I'm Not" by Kandi at #24. "Deep Inside of You" by Third Eye Blind at #69. "My Baby You" by Marc Anthony at #70. (audio only) "Hey Papi" by Jay Z ft. Memphis Bleek at #76. October 8: Ed premieres on NBC. October 8: The TV film Baby premieres on TNT, featuring Jean Stapleton, Farrah Fawcett, Keith Carradine, and Alison Pill. October 8: Citizen Toxie: The Toxic Avenger IV premieres at Sitges Film Festival. (article only) October 9: Nikki premieres on The WB. (article only) October 10: (TW: ableist slur) Ricky Martin's "She Bangs" premieres as a single. October 10: The Geena Davis Show premieres on ABC. (article only) October 10: (TW: surgical experimentations, flashing lights, gore) The video game adaptation of Alien: Resurrection (article here) premieres on the PlayStation in North America, later released in Europe on December 1, 2000. Also premiering are: Frogger 2: Swampy's Revenge (gameplay here, article here) for the PlayStation. (TW: flashing lights) Galaga: Destination Earth (article here) also for the PlayStation in North America, later released in Europe on November 10, 2000. October 11: Jim Wallace, Baron Wallace of Tankerness is appointed as the Acting First Minister of Scotland. October 11: A coal sludge spill occurs in Martin County, KY, USA. This environmental disaster was 30 times worse than the 1986 Exxon Valdez oil spill, and considered as one of the worst disasters in the southeastern part of the US. October 11: The 100th Space Shuttle mission, STS-92, launches from Kennedy Space Center, FL, USA. October 12: (TW: terrorism, bombings) The USS Cole (DDG-67) is bombed while refueling in the Aden harbor in Yemen, leaving 17 crewmembers dead, and 39 injured. October 13: (TW: flashing lights in commercial) Pok√©mon Gold and Pok√©mon Silver (gameplay here, commercial here, article here) premieres in Australasia for the Game Boy Color, later released in North America two days later, and released in Europe on April 6, 2001. October 13: Trading Spaces, the US version of the UK's Changing Rooms, premieres on TLC, Discovery Home, and Discovery Channel. October 13: The TV movie Mom's Got A Date With A Vampire premieres on the Disney Channel, featuring Caroline Rhea, Charles Shaughnessy, and Robert Carradine. October 13: Premiering in theatres this week are: (TW: smoking, alcohol, ableist slur) Dr T. & The Women (dir. Robert Altman), featuring Richard Gere, Helen Hunt, Farrah Fawcett, Laura Dern, Shelley Long, Kate Hudson, Liv Tyler, Tara Reid, Robert Hays, Andy Richter, Lee Grant, and Janine Turner. October 15: German American biochemist and Nobel Prize winner Konrad Emil Bloch passes away. October 15: American film and theatre critic for the New York Times, Vincent Canby, passes away. October 15: PB&J Otter, which premiered on the Playhouse Disney block on Disney Channel on December 10, 1997, airs its final episode, a Halloween special. October 15: Curb Your Enthuasiasm premieres on HBO, featuring Larry David, Cheryl Hines, Jeff Garlin, and Susie Essman. October 16: Bernard Cornwell's novel Harlequin, the first in the Grail Quest series, is released. October 16: The Pocket Pikachu Color, or the Pok√©mon Pikachu 2 is released. October 16: The anime adaptation of InuYasha (article here) premieres on NNS in Japan, featuring music by Kaoru Wada, who would go on to compose Princess Tutu's score. Also premiering is: (TW: nudity, dismemberment) Android Kikaider: The Animation (article here) on Kids Station in Japan. October 16: Dragon Valor (gameplay here, article here), the third game in the Dragon Buster series, previously released in Europe on June 30, 2000, premieres on the PlayStation in North America. Also premiering are: (TW: clowns) Cruis'n Exotica (article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later released for the Game Boy Color on November 6, 2000. October 17: The video game adaptation of The World Is Not Enough (article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later to Europe on December 8, 2000. October 17: Franklin and the Green Knight premieres on video. October 17: (TW: train collisions) The Hatfield Rail Crash occurs south of Hatfield station in Hertfordshire, UK, leading to four deaths, and over 70 injured. October 18: After 13 years of marriage, Demi Moore and Bruce Willis divorce. October 18: Zack de la Rocha leaves Rage Against the Machine. October 19: Napple Tale: Arsia in Daydream (Napple Tale) (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the Dreamcast in Japan, featuring music by Yoko Kanno. Also released is: Donald Duck: Quack Attack premieres on the Game Boy Color, later to PAL regions a day later. October 31: American singer, actress, and dancer Willow Smith, or Willow is born. October 31: The last Multics machine is shut down at the Canadian Department of National Defence in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada. October 31: (TW: plane collisions) Singapore Airlines Flight 006 takes off from the wrong runway during a typhoon, crashing into construction equipment in Chiang Kai-shek Airport in Taipei, Taiwan, causing the deaths of 79 passengers, and 4 crewmembers. October 31: Napster and BMG Music announce their merger, changing Napster into a subscription-based music service. October 31: Gen13 premieres on video. October 31: The animated movie based on the song Grandma Got Run Over By A Reindeer premieres on The WB. (article only) October 31: (TW: terrorism, 9/11 mention) The Prometheus Deception by Robert Ludlum is released. October 31: Backstreet Boys' "Shape of My Heart" is released as a single. October 31: Mercy Streets premieres in theatres, featuring Eric Roberts, and Stacy Keach. (article only) This Date In History: November 2000 November 1: Mario Tennis (article here) is released for the Game Boy Color in Japan. November 1: Michael Learns To Rock release their fifth album Blue Night. November 1: Balance Point, a New Jedi Order novel, is published. November 1: American voice and stage actor Bernard Erhard passes away. November 1: Serbia joins the United Nations. November 2: (TW: mention of death) Jacqueline Wilson's novel Vicky Angel hits bookshelves in the UK. November 2: Aqua Aqua: Wetrix 2 (Aquaqua) (more gameplay here, article here) premieres on the PS2 in Japan. Also premiering is: LOL: Lack of Love for the Dreamcast in Japan. (article only) November 2: Wheel of Fortune has its Halloween special, where the contestants are costumed celebrities. November 2: The first crewmembers (a team of two cosmonauts and one astronaut) enter, for the first long-duration expedition, aboard the International Space Station. November 3: Rune (article here) premieres on PCs in Europe, later to North America four days later. The Macintosh version of the game is released on December 12, 2000, and the Linux version on June 21, 2001. Also premiering are: Mobile Phone Beast Telefang for the Game Boy Color in Japan. (article only) The video game adaptation of Chicken Run also for the Game Boy Color in North America, later released in Europe on November 24, 2000. McG in his film debut, We Are Marshall, Terminator Salvation), featuring Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore, Lucy Liu, Bill Murray, the voice of John Forsythe as Charlie, Sam Rockwell, Crispin Glover, Tim Curry, Matt LeBlanc, Luke Wilson, LL Cool J, Melissa McCarthy, and a cameo by Alex Trebek. Robert Redford), featuring Will Smith, Matt Damon, Charlize Theron, with Lane Smith in his final film role, and an uncredited Jack Lemmon in his final film role. November 4: X-Men: Evolution, the third-longest running Marvel animated series, premieres on Kids WB. November 5: The Mainichi Shimbun exposes archaeologist Shinichi Fujimura as a fraud. November 5: 25 years after his death, the Emperor of Ethiopia, Haile Selassee I, is given a funeral and burial (article here) by the Orthodox Church. November 5: (TW: flashing lights) The Growing Pains Movie premieres on ABC's Wonderful World of Disney. (article only) November 7: (TW: drugs mention) The DEA finds an LSD manufacturing lab inside a missile silo in Wamego, KS, USA. November 7: The 2000 US Presidential Election takes place, where the results in Florida are still in deadlock. November 8: Japanese Red Army leader Fusako Shigenobu is arrested in Osaka, Japan. November 8: American actress Jade Pettyjohn (School of Rock) is born. November 8: Saxophonist Dick Morrissey passes away. November 8: Escape From Monkey Island (article here) premieres on PCs in North America, later released for PCs in Europe on November 17, 2000. November 8: (TW: discussion of death penalty, immigration issues, bombings, genocide, mass incarceration, drugs, ableism, racism, racial profiling) Democracy Now! journalist Amy Goodman meets President Clinton in this "accidental encounter" (first link goes to full interview, second link goes to a partial transcript of the interview), where Clinton calls up the network to "get out the vote" for Vice President Gore, and where Clinton infamously loses his temper. November 9: (TW: nudity, incest mention) Cruel Intentions 2: Manchester Prep premieres on video, featuring Robin Dunne, Sarah Thompson, Keri Lynn Pratt, and Amy Adams. Adam Sandler, Steven Brill, Tim Herlihy), featuring Adam Sandler, Patricia Arquette, Harvey Keitel, Reese Witherspoon, Rhys Ifans, Tommy "Tiny" Lister Jr., Rodney Dangerfield, Kevin Nealon, Dana Carvey, and many cameos. November 11: (TW: fire) In Kaprun, Austria, a funicular train catches fire while traveling in a tunnel, killing 155 people aboard. November 11: "With Arms Wide Open" by Creed is on the top of the Billboard Hot 100 for this week only. Songs peaking this week are: (TW: insefocts, flashing lights, ableist slur) "Kryptonite" by 3 Doors Down at #3. "You Won't Be Lonely Now" by Billy Ray Cyrus at #80. November 12: Leah Rabin, wife of former Israeli prime minister Yithzak Rabin, passes away. November 12: Ms. Pac-Man's Maze M*dness (article here) premieres on the Nintendo 64 in North America, later released for the Dreamcast in North America a day later. Also released is: Star Wars: Demolition (article here) for the PlayStation in North America, later released to Europe on December 15, 2000. The game is later released for the Dreamcast on November 19, 2000, and to Europe on December 15, 2000. November 12: (TW: ableism, institutionalization mention) The Miracle Worker premieres on ABC's The Wonderful World of Disney, featuring Hallie Kate Eisenberg as Helen Keller, Alison Elliott as Anne Sullivan, David Strathairn, Lucas Black, and Kate Greenhouse. November 13: Philippine Speaker of the House Manuel B. "Manny" Villar, Jr., with 115 signatures from other representatives, passes articles of impeachment against Philippine President Estrada to the Senate for crimes such as bribery, corruption, and violation of the Constitution. November 13: (TW: bright, flashing lights, explosions) Final Fantasy IX (gameplay here, commercials here, and here, article here) is released on the PlayStation in North America, and later to Europe on February 16, 2001. Songs peaking are: (TW: bright lights) "If You're Gone" by Mathcbox Twenty at #5. (TW: flashing lights, spinning images) "Stronger" by Britney Spears at #11. "Beautiful Day" by U2 at #21. (TW: flashing lights) "Georgia" by Carolyn Dawn Johnson at #98. January 29: Phantasy Star Online (gameplay here, article here) premieres on the Dreamcast in North America, later released in Europe on February 23, 2001. January 29: Magical Doremi Sharp, which premiered on TV Asahi on February 6, 2000 in Japan, airs its final episode. January 29: Pace announces its integration of Sega Dreamcast video game technology into its upcoming set-top boxes, or DVRs. January 29: (TW: riots, police brutality mention) Student protests occur outside the Indonesian Parliament in Jakarta, demanding for Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid's resignation uue to his corruption scandals. January 30: Michel Navratil, Jr., the last male survivor of the Titanic, passes away. January 31: (TW: mentions of terrorism, bombings) In the Scottish Court in the Netherlands, judges convict a Libyan, Abdelbaset al-Megrahi, and acquit another Libyan, Lamin Khalifah Fhimah, involved in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.
